IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Continued development of safe and effective novel antidepressants relies on understanding how these drugs modify brain activity. I propose a multi-level approach to investigate actions of a rapid-acting neurosteroid antidepressant at levels ranging from single neurons to brain network activity. These efforts will advance our understanding of how novel antidepressant agents shape complex neurophysiology, and help inform future efforts to produce safe, effective, rapid-acting antidepressants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of hypertension and cardiovascular related consequences remain high in African Americans (AA), despite treatment advances and evidence-based practice guidelines that have shown positive results in blood pressure control. Mobile Health (mHealth) technologies are promising tools to facilitate behavioral change and sustain self-managing chronic diseases; however, there is a lack of evidence of mHealth long-term impact on clinically relevant health outcomes and data specific to AA older adults. The proposed project will test a technology-based intervention approach, OPtimizing Technology to Improve Medication Adherence and BP Control (OPTIMA-BP), focused specifically on AA older adults with hypertension to improve hypertension self- management, medication adherence, and blood pressure control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Degenerative valve diseases are very common and often lead to death. However, we do not understand the mechanisms that underlie the progression of valve diseases. The information generated from this project will provide a better understanding of valve diseases, which may allow for the creation of novel non-invasive therapies able to prevent and heal degenerating valves in children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Development of type 2 diabetes (T2D) prior to the age of 20 years has been associated with more aggressive disease progression and earlier dependence on insulin therapy than in adults with T2D. Current recommended first-line treatment for T2D in adolescents (metformin and insulin) does not slow disease progression or effectively reduce elevated body mass index (BMI), one of the primary risk factors for the development and perpetuation of T2D. By studying the effects of an anti-obesity medication (liraglutide 3.0 mg/day) on BMI, insulin sensitivity and beta cell function, this project will contribute the understanding of treatment of T2D in adolescents using a novel BMI-centric approach and weight loss medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Although there are many theories, the cause of late onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) remains unknown. However, one of the earliest reported perturbations of normal brain function in the pathogenesis of LOAD is disruption of the endosomal-lysosomal network. The goal of this proposal is to quantitate differences induced by LOAD pathogenesis on protein-protein interactions and protein structure within the endosomal-lysosomal network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We propose to achieve highly comprehensive characterization of the protein composition of extracellular vesicles in human brain tissues, and determine their emerging roles on enhancing neuronal uptake of vesicle associated tau and spread of tau pathology in human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neurons. The candidate molecules will be specifically targeted by specific antagonistic reagents for their therapeutic potential for halting tau propagation in vivo. These studies will lead to a better understanding of vesicle-mediated disease spread mechanism in Alzheimer's disease and related tauopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability of lymphocytes (white blood cells) to provide local immunity, but also their pathogenic role in diseases from atherosclerosis to cancer and autoimmune disorders, requires their migration from the blood into target tissues through specialized blood vessels, exemplified by the high endothelial venules (HEV). HEV are induced in immunized lymphoid tissues and in tumors and sites of chronic tissue inflammation, but what controls their generation and their role in disease has been unclear. Our studies will define mechanisms that control HEV generation and specialization, and may lead to new ways to enhance vaccine and tumor responses and control inflammatory diseases through therapeutic manipulation of these vascular entry sites for lymphocyte recruitment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes is a leading risk factor for the global burden of disease, and there is an urgent need to better understand this collection of diseases. This proposal aims to define the molecular profile of a subset of diabetes resulting from a human pathogenic variant of MAFA, a fundamental pancreatic islet-enriched transcription factor differentially expressed in mice and humans. These studies will identify β-cell signatures with special emphasis on sex-dependent differences, such as male cellular senescence, in hopes of identifying new therapeutic strategies and targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative: In order to understand complex biological and disease processes a number of highly valuable rat models have been developed. These models take advantage of natural genetic variation to provide a platform to study these processes. Since this genetic variation is embodied within the genomes of these rat models, a full understanding of the link between genetics and biology of disease cannot be reached without full knowledge of the genomes of animals providing these models. We will use new genome sequencing, assembly and scaffolding methods and we will provide annotated genome assemblies for 9 important rat strains that contribute to numerous genetic models of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a major global and domestic health issue. We have found that Immune-modifying nanoParticles (IMP) are a strong candidate for a clinically translatable acute pharmacologic intervention for TBI. The proposed studies will help to understand the mechanisms underlying the protective effects of IMP and help to develop a potentially effective practical therapy for human TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Slowing the ultimate clinical expression of Alzheimer disease (AD) will likely require understanding and treating the factors that influence early brain pathology, before the illness progresses to dementia, such as in amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI). This project aims to test the efficacy and safety of transcranial photobiomodulation (t-PBM) over 8 weeks compared to sham in improving clinical symptoms of aMCI. By evaluating the efficacy of t-PBM, an innovative, non-invasive technology with a well-established safety profile, and by exploring the association of t-PBM treatment effects with important biomarkers relevant for AD illness progression, this study will be a key first step in developing a novel, easy to administer neuromodulation treatment for aMCI and for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pathological anxiety, which remains one of the most common forms of mental illness, tends to emerge during early adolescence and does so to a greater degree in girls than boys. The object of this proposal is to identify the adolescent- and sex-specific biological mechanisms that increase risk for anxiety during adolescence, with a focus on testosterone and myelination of prefrontal-subcortical circuits. This research has the potential to significantly impact public health by identifying developmental pathways that increase risk for anxiety, which will enhance the identification and treatment of at-risk kids before trajectories crystalize.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy is the primary treatment option for prostate cancer, however delineation between tumor and nerve tissue in the operating room continues to challenge even experienced surgeons. This difficulty leaves patients with tumor positive margins and nerve damage resulting in mortality and morbidity, respectively. Herein, we will develop a two-color fluorescence guided surgery solution that will enable ready differentiation between tumor and nerve tissue in the operating room for future clinical translation to improve surgical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: ––– PROJECT NARRATIVE ––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Alcohol abuse disorders are a chronic human condition where initial consumption leads to long lasting behavioral changes, including tolerance to repeat exposure. The results of the proposed studies will provide valuable mechanistic insight into the initial levels of response to alcohol and into the development of tolerance. This will highlight novel targets for therapeutic intervention with alcohol addiction, which are largely lacking.

PHR: Project Narrative HIV infection and methamphetamine abuse remain substantial public health concerns and despite the availability of antiretrovirals (ARVs) and combined ARV therapy (cART). While cART has shifted the overall picture of HIV-1 disease by providing significant benefits the virus cannot be eliminated and persists. Methamphetamine abuse is known to increase the risk of contracting HIV-1 and the psychostimulant seems to directly affect viral load. The purpose of the proposed research is to better understand the cellular and molecular mechanism underlying the compromising effect of the psychostimulant on cART-dependent optimal viral suppression in order to better counter viral persistence and recrudescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We hypothesize that airway mucus plugs are an under-appreciated cause of airflow obstruction in severe forms of asthma and that muco-active treatment in mucus plug-high asthma will improve airflow in these patients. We further hypothesize that intelectin has a pivotal role in mediating airway mucus plug formation in asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will establish a comprehensive, prospective myopathy cohort in systemic sclerosis (SSc or scleroderma) to ultimately devise a novel classification schema for SSc-associated myopathy that is predictive of outcomes such as treatment response, disability, cardiopulmonary disease trajectory, and death. Advanced muscle MRI techniques include diffusion weighted imaging, diffusion tensor imaging, and T2 mapping will also be used to detect and quantify early muscle disease related changes in SSc associated myopathy. The knowledge gained from this study will lay the foundation for discovering predictive biomarkers of disease course and to allow future studies of the specific biological process involved in each phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study is the only US study with 20-years of clinical and vision- related quality of life outcomes in a cohort of 1,636 participants. The 20 year follow-up is meaningful because it approaches the life expectation of participants whose age was 55 at baseline. We will analyze the long-term effect of treatment, clinical and demographic factors on vision-related quality of life. Results from this study will provide a unique opportunity to understand the long-term patient burden of ocular hypertension and glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to prove that it is possible to measure change in brain structures in people with Alzheimer’s disease or Frontotemporal Lobar Degeneration over intervals much shorter than typical in the field (as short as 3 months). Capitalizing on recent advances in fast brain scanning methods, we have collected pilot data in a few patients showing that we can precisely measure change in each individual within 3-month intervals. If we show that this can be done in a larger group of patients with a diverse array of dementias, this will pave the way for these methods to be used in large natural history studies or clinical therapeutic trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Leveraging deep learning for markerless motion management in radiation therapy Project Narrative This project is aimed at establishing a deep learning-based image guidance strategy for motion management in prostate and pancreas radiation therapy. Successful completion of this investigation will significantly advance the current beam targeting technique and provide radiation oncology discipline a powerful way to safely and reliably escalate the radiation dose for precision radiation therapy. The research should thus lead to a widespread impact on the management of various neoplasmic diseases affected by organ motion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) can be successfully prevented or delayed in high-risk individuals with behavioral or pharmacologic intervention, however, there is a significant amount of inter-individual differences in the effect of these treatments. The goal of this proposal is to identify new molecular pathways involved in the development of diabetes—some of which could modulate the effect of preventive interventions—through integrating genetics, metabolomics, and clinical phenotypes and endpoints from a completed randomized control trial of diabetes prevention treatments. In parallel with these aims, a pilot prospective cohort study is proposed to externally validate these metabolites as biomarkers for incident T2D and glycemic traits in a real-world population of individuals with prediabetes that will provide a framework for a future clinical biomarker trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance abuse and HIV infection are highly prevalent, commonly co-occur, and have adverse effects on brain structure and function, but too few scientists are properly trained to study these important areas. The “Training on Addictions in Interdisciplinary NeuroAIDS (TRAIN)” program has been highly successful in its first two cycles in recruiting and preparing remarkably productive and culturally diverse pre- and post-doctoral scholars to conduct cutting edge research in this field. In seeking a second renewal of TRAIN we propose building on this success in preparing future leaders, with enhanced emphases on the biologic mechanisms by which HIV and substance use affect the CNS, as well as other factors that may improve or worsen these problems.
PROJECT_TERMS: addiction;neuroAIDS;Research;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Research on Addictions in Interdisciplinary NeuroAIDS (TRAIN)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we build on a unique randomized controlled trial of foster care as an alternative for institutional care based in Bucharest, Romania. This valuable sample of children will be studied when participants are 22 years of age when we will examine the long-term consequences of early psychosocial deprivation and early intervention on cardiometabolic risk factors and health behaviors at the start of adulthood. This project will contribute significantly to our understanding of ways in which children exposed to early psychosocial deprivation are affected by their experiences and will directly inform policies and clinical practices.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This research is relevant to public health because language processing skills are essential to successful functioning in everyday life, and the domain of language undergoes significant change during childhood and adolescence. Atypical language production is a symptom of developmental disorders such as stuttering, cluttering, and speech delay, and thus understanding the unfolding of language production skills is important for understanding these points of vulnerability in the language system as well as for identifying and intervening with these disorders. The project is relevant to the mission of advancing our knowledge of how two core cognitive systems, language and vision, function, interact, and emerge over the course of human development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Although patients with mental disorders who present to emergency departments have over a 30-fold increased odds of suicide, most are not identified as at risk during these visits. This project will apply machine learning methods to electronic health records and medical claims in order to develop and evaluate point-in-time short- term longitudinal suicide risk algorithms for patients presenting to the emergency department with mental health complaints. This new knowledge will provide emergency department clinicians with interpretable, patient-specific information about short-term risk of suicide attempts and suicide.

PHR: Poxviruses comprise a large family of viruses including species that are highly pathogenic for humans as well as animals. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: The glymphatic and meningeal lymphatic clearance systems play a critical role in the removal of toxic amyloid and tau burden associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) from the brain. We recently found that application of GENUS, a noninvasive regime using patterned light and sound to elicit gamma entrainment, reduced the accumulation of amyloid and tau and ameliorated cognitive functions in multiple disease mouse models, but the beneficial effects by which GENUS potentially impacts the brain clearance system are not clear. We will identify the effects and potential mechanisms by which GENUS impacts the physiological, cellular, and molecular responses of and subsequent clearance of AD-associated toxic amyloid by the glymphatic and meningeal lymphatic systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Approximately two-thirds of patients diagnosed with cancer in the United States will be cured of their disease using a combination of surgery, radiation and chemotherapy, but progress towards enhanced survival in adults with advanced and metastatic disease has been painfully slow, even in the era of targeted therapies, and new, more effective therapies are desperately needed. MERTK and AXL, members of the TAM-family of receptor tyrosine kinases, are aberrantly expressed in a wide variety of different tumor types and are potential therapeutic targets in majority of human tumors, therefore, agents targeting both MERTK and AXL may be particularly effective. The studies described here aim to develop potent and selective dual MERTK and AXL inhibitors suitable for clinical application and as such, may have a direct impact on outcomes and/or quality of life for patients with advanced cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Summary This proposal aims to develop new causal inference methods to tame bias due to hidden confounding factors in obser- vational studies as well as in randomized experiments subject to non-adherence. The proposed methods are firmly grounded in modern semiparametric theory which will be used to obtain more robust and efficient inferences about causal effects in a broad range of public health applications including in Epidemiology of Aging, Environmental Health Epidemiology and HIV/AIDS Prevention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The characterization of innate immune regulation of skin wound-repair will provide insights into the pathology and therapeutic options for autoimmune/autoinflammatory skin conditions such as psoriasis and atopic dermatitis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persons with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) frequently suffer from dysphagia, an impaired ability to swallow food and drink, that can lead to serious health consequences such as malnutrition, decreased quality of life, increased care partner burden, and pneumonia. However, there are major gaps in our understanding of how swallowing function declines over time and risk factors for this condition in persons with AD/ADRD. This project aims to comprehensively characterize swallowing function in persons with AD/ADRD to inform the development of improved methods to identify, prevent, and treat this serious condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This research project is relevant to public health because both heart failure (HF) and mild cognitive impairment (e.g., trouble remembering and concentrating beyond normal aging) are highly prevalent among older adults in the United States. Despite advances in health care, there are no effective interventions for treating cognitive impairment in HF, which if left untreated, leads to suboptimal health, quality of life, and shorter survival. Therefore, we propose to test the effect of a dual-component intervention comprised of a virtual reality-based cognitive restoration intervention and computerized cognitive training on cognitive function and overall health among 172 older adults with HF who experience mild cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative While the recent national focus has been on the opioid crisis, 1 million Americans suffer from methamphetamine use disorder and 1 million more from cocaine use disorder, with stimulants being the second leading cause of overdose deaths behind opioids. However, unlike opioids, there is currently no pharmacological treatment approved by the FDA for stimulants. This project aims to collaborate with the Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network (BPN) team for lead optimization of our novel, cyclase-biased, selective cannabinoid receptor 2 (CB2R) agonists class, developed at Stanford with support from a U18 NIDA pilot grant, into preclinical/clinical development for the treatment of methamphetamine use disorder.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This research proposal aims to improve the diagnostic capabilities of detecting neurodevelopmental delay in resource-limited settings such as Malawi to evaluate the impact of chewing a low-cost, xylitol gum during pregnancy compared to no xylitol gum on rates of neurodevelopmental delay in offspring. This proposal is in alignment with my life-long intent to build a career centered upon improving neonatal outcomes, including neurodevelopment, through innovative, low-cost maternal interventions. I propose to leverage our institutions’ infrastructure in Malawi, global health mentors and leaders, and research expertise in neonatal neurodevelopmental outcomes research to develop a framework that will translate into future neurodevelopmental and interventional studies aimed at improving neonatal outcomes globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to understand how to engage and retain older adults in use of mHealth technologies that permit in-home monitoring of health including cognitive function. In the community-based Framingham Heart Study, we propose to enhance engagement strategies and study factors associated with successful use of a smartphone application and smartwatch in older adults. We will investigate the usefulness of the digital data for monitoring risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease and we will relate the digital data to brain aging outcomes including preclinical Alzheimer’s disease using neuropsychological testing and brain MRI data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adenosquamous cancer of the pancreas (ASCP) is a devastating disease with high metastatic potential and a bleak clinical outcome. Despite aggressive surgical and medical managements, the median survival has been reported to be consistently less than 1 year. In this application we propose to investigate the mechanism driving this dismal disease and develop a new approach to treat patients with ASCP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  As Alzheimer’s disease progresses, pathological forms the tau protein accumulate in progressively more brain regions in a predictable manner by transfer from one brain cell to another. This project investigates how chemical modifications of tau that occur in Alzheimer’s disease influence the transfer of pathological tau from cell to cell. Understanding this process in greater detail will provide deeper insights into the disease process in Alzheimer’s disease and may suggest new treatment strategies for slowing the progression of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The goal of this current application is to fully characterize a new animal model mimicking the tau pathology development and cognitive dysfunction as seen in the early stage of Alzheimer’s disease. We will map the synaptic pathways mediating disease progression by activating or inhibiting specific synapses, and then evaluate the effect of amyloid deposition for acceleration of tau accumulation. Characterization of the new animal model will be beneficial for the development of effective therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The broad, long-term goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive understanding of the regulatory network that regulates the differentiation and maintenance of articular cartilage, which plays a central role in maintaining the low-friction environment of the joint space. A hallmark of cells comprising the articular cartilage is their expression of proteoglycans, such as the protein lubricin, encoded by the Prg4 gene, that lubricates the joint and protects against the development of arthritis. Successful completion of this proposal will provide fundamental new insight into the events that maintain lubricin expression in articular cartilage, with additional implications for regeneration of articular cartilage in degenerative joint diseases including osteoarthritis (OA) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We have identified a novel marker of inflammation in the fatty tissue of the breast, which are crown-like structures that can be detected in surgical pathology specimens, and this measure of breast white adipose tissue inflammation (B-WATi) is associated with obesity and dysregulated metabolic factors. In the Pathways Study, a prospective cohort study of women diagnosed with invasive breast cancer in Kaiser Permanente Northern California, we will identify factors that influence B-WATi presence and severity, and determine whether B-WATi is associated breast cancer recurrence and survival. This project brings together ground- breaking and innovative work on B-WATi with the outstanding resources of the Pathways Study, and has the potential to identify actionable and modifiable risk factors to improve breast cancer outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The broad objective of the Overall Program is to develop ready-made, off-the-shelf, allogeneic immune effector cells with precise targeting of tumor associated antigens without risks of effector cell exhaustion or on- target/off-tumor and other adverse effects. To accomplish this goal, we will engineer regulatory T cells and NK cells for better tumor targeting, extended in vivo persistence and anti-tumor potency with the potential for production at an industrial scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reductions in cardiorespiratory fitness, mobility, and muscle strength/power have been linked to poor cognitive performance and increased risk for dementia. The precise relationships among these physical attributes and various aspects of cognition, such as memory, planning, and inhibition, are unknown, thereby precluding the development of an optimal lifestyle approach to maintain cognitive functions with aging. Given the continued absence of a pharmacological cure for Alzheimer’s disease, the primary goal of the current study it to identify which modifiable physical attributes are most strongly linked to memory and brain health, with a long-term goal of mitigating cognitive decline and thereby increasing high quality-of-life years among older adults prior to mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The broad objective of Project 1 is to develop a safe and potent off-the-shelf cell therapy. To accomplish this, we are proposing an alternative immune effector cell vehicle, specifically Regulatory T Cells (Treg) as they are capable of suppressing the release of inflammatory factors and host mediated immune rejection, and are amenable to industrial scale expansion, and additional engineering to enhance function, persistence and tumor killing with reduced risk of side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Sphingolipid metabolites are critical lipid-derived second messengers for oncogenesis and several sphingolipid-based therapeutics have shown great promise as cancer therapeutics. This research focuses on the regulation of sphingolipid metabolism by the androgen receptor and the use of ceramide nanoliposomes (CNL) as a novel therapeutic for prostate cancer patients. Moreover, the synergistic dynamics between epigenetics and lipid biology will be studied in tumors to uncover new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Our goal is to develop new therapies for treating patients with relapse/refractory acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). This application proposes to tackle allogeneic hematopoietic cell (alloHCT) complications by using chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tlineage cells in a novel approach with unexpectedly potent cell type, induced regulatory T cells (iTregs) that has the dual capacity of preventing alloHCT side-effects and killing AML cells. Using drug regulated system to induce CAR expression for periods of time to restrain AML followed by rest periods to prevent T cells from being exhausted and dysfunction. This is accomplished by administration of a nontoxic drug to turn CAR expression on and stop drug to turn the system off in order to best treat AML, reducing toxicity and improving efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While antiretroviral therapy (ART) has achieved remarkable success, with AIDS patients now living long, full lives, HIV-1 infection remains incurable due to the presence of a persistent viral reservoir, capable of rebounding upon interruption of treatment. The RID-HIV (Reversing Immune Dysfunction for HIV-1 eradication) Collaboratory brings together leading university scientists from more than twelve academic institutions as well as Merck Research Laboratories, with the goal to understand the molecular and cellular basis for the loss of immune homeostasis in HIV infected patients. This knowledge will be harnessed to create a therapeutic paradigm encompassing immune restorative treatments, utilized in concert with enhanced viral reactivation and elimination strategies, to establish a HIV-1 cure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postnatal care and support is critical for ensuring healthy mothers and infants, yet very few women receive any postnatal care in rural India. Maa Shishu Swasthya Sahayak Samooh (MeSSSSage) is a mobile platform developed by our team to provide group education and support about postpartum and infant health, including referral. We will evaluate the impact of MeSSSSage on exclusive breastfeeding, met need for family planning, and postpartum mental health, with the long-term goal of scaling up educational and support resources for mothers during a neglected period to optimize family health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging is a key factor in many diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases. This project aims at integrating computational modeling and innovative measurement technologies to understand the complexity of single-cell aging and the emergent dynamics from the underlying regulatory networks. Computational models developed from this project will advance a quantitative understanding of mechanisms underlying aging dynamics, laying foundations for strategies for mitigating age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Accurate, routine screening reduces deaths among the 1-in-8 women who will get breast cancer in their lifetime. Contrast-enhanced MRI screening has tremendous potential to improve on mammography screening, but it is limited by cost, discomfort, and concerns over the risks and beneﬁts of annual gadolinium contrast injections. We propose to develop non-contrast-enhanced breast MRI screening approaches that are accurate, more comfort- able and avoid the need for intravenous gadolinium contrast, and study these approaches for screening women at high risk of developing breast cancer.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE We have developed a novel off-the-shelf therapeutic (called FT538) using a triple gene modified induced pluripotent stem cell that can be differentiated and manufactured into hundreds of doses of highly active natural killer cells that can be targeted with antibodies or chimeric antigen receptors to treat acute myelogenous leukemia. We will test the best way to use this knowledge in first-in-human clinical trials with the goal of making the treatment off-the-shelf for easy and feasible export to the cancer community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sickle cell disease and β-thalassemia are the most common inherited disorders in man and affect millions of people around the world. If it were possible to increase the amount of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), a hemoglobin type found primarily in babies in utero, in the blood of patients with both diseases this would ameliorate disease severity and might even help cure these diseases. Our proposed studies targeting a new pathway that we discovered to induce HbF in human primary erythroid progenitor cells would have the potential to lead to the development of a novel and safer inducer to therapeutically increase HbF in people with these severe hereditary diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Aggressive and invasive glioblastoma with very poor prognosis and high mortality rate remains a big healthcare challenge. Repurposing brain-permeable FDA-approved molecules can be a successful strategy for glioblastoma therapy. Our objective is to repurpose an FDA-approved antiepileptic drug stiripentol for glioblastoma via studying its mechanistic pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, and preclinical efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Recently described molecular phenotypes of the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) have distinct clinical trajectories and differential responses to treatments in secondary analyses of randomized controlled trials, but the mechanisms underlying these differences are poorly understood. The research proposed in this K23 will use tracheal aspirate RNA sequencing to identify the cellular circuits driving dysregulated pulmonary inflammation, test for the differences in microbial communities, and study the evolution and resolution of ARDS in each molecular phenotype. These aims complement a training plan designed to prepare me to apply for an R01 grant to study the interaction of pulmonary and systemic inflammation in ARDS phenotypes as an independent investigator within 5 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone grafting remains the preferred treatment for bone defects, but this practice is limited by donor site morbidity. Alternatively, we seek to develop therapies that exploit the bone-regenerating potential of a specific type of bone marrow-derived stem cells. Here, we propose studies to understand how blood vessels regulate these human stem cells' activity, paving the way to more rational therapeutic strategies in the regeneration of bone defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to create a pathway for bioengineering undergraduates to analyze rural health systems, create engineered devices to address health disparities, and implement their designs to improve rural communities in Maine. The objectives of this proposal are consistent with the goals of NIH R25 education projects and will have a significant impact on public health by developing a curriculum to support students in innovative design for rural communities. The unique nature of this proposal is the integration of community networks in supporting engineering design for rural healthcare, leveraging the expertise of four partner institutions to support the students in authentic learning that will ensure commitment to the rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Training Program in Molecular Metabolism enlists faculty from the of Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health and the Harvard Medical School to provide didactic and research opportunities to trainees interested in a research career in molecular metabolism. We request funding to support 3 students and 1 postdoctoral fellow per year. The program will prepare trainees to apply cutting edge multi-omic, genetic, and physiological methods to advance our understanding of areas including metabolic health and diseases such as diabetes; gastrointestinal health, such as the role of the microbiome; inflammatory and immune effects on health; obesity; and the role of factors such as aging or disease state on metabolic processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis B (HBV) is a leading infectious killer in sub-Saharan Africa, despite the existence of an effective vaccine. Children are especially vulnerable to HBV-related complications, but our knowledge of patterns of childhood HBV transmission in African children are incomplete. In this career development proposal, Dr. Thompson will apply comprehensive epidemiological, spatial and modeling analyses to enhance our knowledge of childhood HBV in Africa, to identify hotspots of disease, and to model spatially targeted vaccination strategies to avert future cases of HBV in African children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative With experiments in this R35 grant, we hope to unravel the complexities of human neurodegenerative diseases. We will take advantage of discoveries we have made in the last decade and the lessons we have learnt from modelling human neurodegenerative diseases in cells and in animals. We will search for mechanisms that explain the death of adult nerve cells across different diseases, from those affecting coordination to those that affect muscle strength or the ability to think.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 encodes proteins that modify the host cell to create an environment that is hospitable for replication. This project aims to understand a specific interaction between an HIV-1 protein, Vif, and a human protein complex, PP2A-B56. By understanding how this interaction occurs and why this interaction is important for HIV-1 infection, we aim to identify critical weaknesses that can be targeted for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will benefit society by helping Black and Latino youth who live in communities facing multiple, intersecting health inequities, and have most recently been disproportionately affected by COVID-19, to discover how public health professionals contribute to protecting vulnerable communities from future epidemics and pandemics and how they can pursue specific public health- and medicine-focused career pathways. The proposed project will engage the New York Hall of Science with scientists and public health experts from local hospitals and universities, as well as community youth and leaders from a local community-based organization, to collaboratively develop strategies for educating the public about the role of public health in addressing long-standing obstacles to positive health outcomes for Black and Latino populations. The proposed project will create exhibits and programming that can be scaled to a wide variety of informal STEM learning institutions and help broad audiences better understand the roles that they and public health experts can play in mitigating the impact of future health crises in their own communities and in others suffering from poor health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Lay Summary The annual National MD/PhD Student Conference in Copper Mountain, CO is the only meeting held specifically for MD/PhD students. This 2 ½-day conference brings 5 featured Keynote speakers, many of who are Nobel Laureates, members of the National Academy of Sciences, Howard Hughes Medical Institute Investigators, and from the National Institutes of Health, to interact with the ~190 student attendees who come from across the country. Students present their work in oral and poster sessions, with these renowned Keynote scientists providing critical review of their work, mentorship, and role models. Finally, the conference also incoporates career advising Break Out sessions, Career Panels, and PSTP/RiR Recruitment Fair to optimize the career outcomes of these MD/PhD trainees. Given the national concern regarding the paucity and risk of loss of the physician-scientist, we propose that supporting the MD/PhD students' conference is a valuable and durable investment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urgency urinary incontinence (UUI) is common in older people and vastly reduces quality of life, yet the cause and mechanism of disease are not well understood. This study will investigate the role of adding behavioral sleep intervention to the standard pharmacotherapy in treatment of UUI among older adults, and the brain mechanisms involved in continence by evaluating brain changes. This will expand our current knowledge of how the sleep affects bladder control, and better characterize the brain mechanisms in maintaining continence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tracking and predicting viral outbreaks remains an open epidemiological problem with deadly consequences. Dr. Holbrook will attack the problem with his Bayesian phylogenetic Hawkes processes, a class of models tailored to simultaneously reconstruct evolutionary histories and predict viral diffusion dynamics. With the mentorship of Profs. Marc Suchard (primary) and Kristian Andersen (secondary), Dr. Holbrook will develop open-source, high-performance computing software and apply his statistical computing methodology to the analysis of the 2015-2016 Zika virus epidemic of the Americas, learning key routes of transmission and identifying phylogenetic clades with enhanced infectiousness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke is leading cause of disability in the US and large vessel occlusion (LVO) comprises the majority of strokes with poor outcomes. The current stroke care relies on EMS triage systems to facilitate access to timely high-quality emergency care for Intravenous thrombolysis therapy (IVT) but not for Endovascular therapy EVT, the most effective treatment for LVO. We propose to develop an innovative, reproducible geospatial algorithm of stroke triage that maximizes neurological recovery for all stroke patients in the US and that can be integrated in a point-of-care decision support application for easy use by paramedics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: RELEVANCE:  Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) is widely used and safe technique for non-invasive modulation of human brain activity with several FDA-approved clinical applications. However, most diagnostic and therapeutic applications of TMS administer the stimulation to a single brain region. This proposal addresses the currently unmet need for non-invasive mapping of the causal roles of multiple cortical areas participating in network-level cognitive functions such as hearing, speech, and language processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young children and those living with HIV are at the highest risk of progressing from Mtb exposure to tuberculosis (TB) disease and of developing severe forms of TB. We will use stored samples from young children already recruited to longitudinal clinical TB studies in South Africa and use transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and antibody approaches to identify biomarkers associated with progression to TB disease and treatment response. We will integrate the different approaches, together with information on viral coinfection and clinical and epidemiological covariates, to identify the optimal signatures to allow targeted TB preventive therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Effective treatment for hematological malignancies and blood cancers remains an outstanding open problem. The only existing cure for most blood disorders is bone marrow transplant, which is only feasible for a minority of patients and has poor prognosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE African Americans experience higher rates of Alzheimer's disease (AD) in which half of the cases are a result of risk factors that can be modified by diet. However, limited research has specifically focused on the development of culturally tailored dietary strategies aimed to reduce the risk of AD among older African Americans. This study will (1) design an adapted brain-healthy soul food diet intervention by identifying the cultural context under which a brain-healthy diet is perceived and practiced among African Americans; (2) use a community-based approach to pilot test an adapted brain-healthy soul food diet intervention; (3) explore the effect of adapted brain-healthy soul food diet intervention on cognitive function as preliminary data to design an RCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms underlying the degeneration of substantia nigra dopaminergic (SN DAergic) neurons and the emergence of abnormal brain activity and movement deficits in Parkinson’s disease (PD) remain poorly understood. To help fill this gap, we propose to study the progression of brain circuit and motor dysfunction in a genetic mouse model of PD that mimics the pattern of DA loss in humans. Through this research, we hope to understand why brain function is initially resilient to–but ultimately dysregulated by–the degeneration of SN DAergic neurons, and whether correction of abnormal circuit activity at early or more advanced stages of parkinsonism can rescue movement and/or prevent further neurodegeneration.

PHR: Optical methods are a primary technique for the study of cellular physiology. This research concerns the development of new optical probes that will enable photocontrol of membrane excitability in vitro and in vivo. Since almost all cell signaling is bidirectional or symbiotic, these new methods will revolutionize our ability to control function and therefore uncover many fresh details of cell physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The goal of the studies outlined in this proposal is to explore the neural circuits utilizing pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) derived peptides in regulating binge-like ethanol intake as well as sex differences in ethanol consumption. These studies will provide novel information on the mechanisms by which binge-like ethanol intake engages and is regulated by components of the endogenous opioid system. Information gained from this line of research will ultimately guide the development of neuromodulatory or other types of approaches for reducing binge-like ethanol intake, which may reduce the medical, socioeconomic and legal costs of alcohol abuse to society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite concerted efforts to address the opioid epidemic in the United States, the opioid overdose death rates are still high, and the opioid use is still on the rise. This unfortunate reality demands the development of novel therapeutic approaches, preferably with non-opioid mechanisms of action. NMDAR-mediated pathways are implicated in several processes underlying the development and maintenance of addiction, and therefore NMDAR antagonists may be able to prevent the formation of compulsive drug-taking behaviors, reduce physical opioid withdrawal symptoms, and/or prevent relapse. In an effort to contribute to the fight against OUD, we developed a novel NMDAR-targeting nanotherapeutic that is expected to exhibit enhanced therapeutic efficacy and improved safety profile because it can only block NMDARs outside the synapses. In the proposed project, we will evaluate the safety and abuse potential of our nanotherapeutic, and explore the entire spectrum of its potential therapeutic effects in animal models of opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (2-3 sentences maximum) This project is relevant to public health because prediction of endometriosis risk can enhance the quality of life for more than 200,000 women per year in the United States and the mediating risk models benefit not only endometriosis but also screening individuals for preventive measures to reduce illness due to associated morbidities such as depression, anxiety, ovarian cancer, and myocardial infraction. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: For years the field has struggled with the question of whether TDP-43 protein deposited in the brains of the elderly with limbic-predominant age-related TDP-43 encephalopathy (LATE) is biologically different from TDP- 43 deposited in FTLD-TDP brains. We propose to isolate and characterize TDP-43 species or strains from LATE-NC and FTLD-TDP brains to determine whether specific structural properties and/or biological activities are associated with these differing TDP-43 proteinopathies, which could lay the foundation to engineer small molecules that bind to specific TDP-43 strains for use as biomarkers or ligands for imaging studies in humans. Disease-specific diagnoses are needed for clinical trials to identify appropriate patients and perhaps therapeutic candidates that are specific for different TDP-43 proteinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: This K12 training program from partner institutions at the Wright Regional Center for Clinical and Translational Research will train scholars to translate research observations to clinical application in our unique communities. Our program will continue its commitment to providing early career faculty/late-stage postdoctoral fellows with a comprehensive “blueprint” for transitioning to research independence. We will further leverage our bidirectional partnerships with local institutions (EVMS, ODU, and VSU), further synergize with internal programs (UM1, T32 and RC2) and Center on Health Disparities pipeline training grants to promote the development of a diverse research workforce (K12, T32, R25), and to further build a community of scholarship while fostering the development of a pipeline beyond our K12 scholars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Understanding the signaling pathways and networks that control development and stem cell production in plants will enable us to elucidate the common regulatory principals which govern stem cell biology and development across all species, including humans. This knowledge could help in efforts to engineer synthetic signaling circuits to probe human disease pathways and develop new clinical applications. Additionally, as projected population increases impact future food challenges, the ability to modify these pathways could help improve yield and nutritional qualities of critical crop species.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic Phantom Limb Pain (PLP) is recognized as very difficult to treat as it is often resistant to classical pharmacological and surgical treatment approaches. Our previous R01 and research studies have shown significant and robust results to support a combined therapy with tDCS and somatosensory training. In this study we propose to test the real-world effects of home-based tDCS combined with a somatosensory training in a pragmatic trial design and a machine-learning analysis to find the best predictors of response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: O-GlcNAcylation is the attachment of a single O-linked β-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine moiety to serine/threonine residues of nuclear, mitochondrial, and cytoplasmic proteins; as such, this modification regulates numerous cellular process such transcription, translation, cell cycle, and signaling. Importantly, O-GlcNAc is a critical regulator of mitochondrial function and disruption in the normal homeostatic levels of O-GlcNAc impairs respiration. This proposal will develop a new understanding of how O-GlcNAc regulates mitochondrial respiration and anti-oxidant response in the context of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: TRAINING PROGRAM IN PHARMACOLOGY Project Narrative (Public Health Statement) The Training Program in Pharmacology at UC Davis provides unique training in drug discovery and development to educate future biomedical researchers, who will be involved in the creation of novel therapeutic treatments of diseases in various areas. It builds on the existing strengths in the interdisciplinary collaborative research and training environment at UC Davis, where training program faculty have developed and clinically test new drugs and other therapeutics and diagnostics. It will train predoctoral PhD students in pharmacology and foster interdisciplinary training and research collaborations in drug discovery and development for graduate students in Pharmacology, Neuroscience, Physiology, and Biomedical Engineering graduate programs. A combination of formal and informal research training experiences will provide trainees with an understanding of how basic and clinical sciences are integrated to translate therapeutic target discovery to drug development, screening, mechanistic preclinical and clinical studies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Pharmacology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Clinical data in electronic health records is annotated with a freely accessible coding system (LOINC® codes from Regenstrief). While helpful for interoperability, these codes do not optimally support data science and reasoning. We will overlay reasoning relationships onto LOINC codes, and make this a new, open resource for data science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Using a prospective 2-stage randomized controlled trial design,the proposed project will evaluate the efficacy of a personalized and automatized m-Health intervention targeting both intentional and non-intentional non- adherence, iTAB-CV + Self-Monitoring, compared to Self-Monitoring alone to improve medication adherence and lower systolic blood pressure in individuals with bipolar disorder (BD) and hypertension. Given the serious negative consequences of uncontrolled hypertension, including early mortality, an intervention that successfully improves adherence to antihypertensive medications while simultaneously addressing psychiatric medication adherence and which can be administered via text messaging would be of substantial public health benefit. This project will explore the mechanism of action of the intervention and its results will form the basis for future implementation-effectiveness trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Discovering the genetic underpinnings of Mendelian disease to enable patient diagnosis and guide treatment is greatly facilitated by diverse genomics assays and computational methods. To enable the next stages in Mendelian disease diagnoses, our Mendelian Genomics Research Consortium Center will study in high detail 500 individuals and their families where current clinical genomics technologies have not achieved diagnoses. Our Center will provide essential insights into emerging functional genomics and targeted approaches for gene and variant discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A small number of adult red blood cells are able to express fetal hemoglobin; increasing the number of these cells is an important approach to the treatment of sickle cell disease. This project proposes to analyze the cells that are able to activate fetal hemoglobin and to study potential factors involved in control of fetal hemoglobin in healthy individuals, those with sickle cell disease, and following treatment with specific medications. Results from this study will provide new potential approaches for the treatment of sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite significant gains in colorectal cancer (CRC) screening promotion, disparities persist among low-income individuals, those with fewer years of education, racial/ethnic minorities, and rural populations. Residents of rural areas suffer significant health inequities and encounter barriers to CRC screening which are often overlooked in healthcare research. This project seeks to address these disparities with a health literacy, shared decision making strategy coupled with tailored ‘stepped care’ automated telephone outreach (recorded by the patient’s primary care provider) that promotes long-term adherence to CRC screening in resource-limited, rural health centers via colonoscopy or annual fecal immunochemical test (FIT).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing epidemic of stimulant use among sexual minority men (SMM), including those living with HIV, could interfere with achievement of the U.S. Ending the HIV Epidemic goals, with improved HIV virologic suppression among SMM who use stimulants needed. This project will first examine multi-level determinants of HIV virologic suppression including stimulant use in a digitally recruited cohort of SMM. We will then perform a randomized controlled trial of reSTART, a multi-component HIV antiretroviral therapy adherence intervention that integrates a point-of-care urine test for HIV adherence self-monitoring and an evidence-based positive affect intervention for SMM living with HIV who use stimulants, to examine reSTART’s impact on virologic suppression, adherence, stimulant use, positive affect/emotions of participants, and cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Rational combinatorial approaches are urgently needed to enhance immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy in patients with liver metastases. We have discovered that liver metastases siphon and delete tumor-specific T cells to cause systemic immunotherapy resistance, and moreover that ablative liver-directed radiotherapy can restore immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy. Herein we propose to evaluate mechanisms of immunotherapy resistance in melanoma patients and preclinical melanoma models with liver metastases as well as mechanistically define how liver SBRT overcomes immunotherapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: The proposed program “Training in Advanced Data Analytics and Computational Sciences to End Drug-Related Harms” (TADA) will prepare a diverse cadre of 21st century social and behavioral science (SBS) researchers to develop transformative approaches to end the substance use disorder (SUD) crisis. Supported by 45 faculty mentors from 11 departments, TADA will prepare trainees to ethically, critically, and seamlessly integrate advanced data science methods into the SBS research lifecycle for SUD. Trainees will learn to: (1) Conduct theoretically-informed studies of distributions and ecologies of SUD-related harms using advanced data science methods; (2) Conduct theoretically-informed studies motivating and assessing policies and programmatic interventions that may affect SUD-related harms and services; (3) Disseminate findings to multiple stakeholder communities to strengthen efforts to end SUD-related harms; (4) Critically apply principles of the ethical and responsible conduct of research.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Advanced Data Analytics to End Drug-Related Harms (TADA)

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I) is a genetic disorder which causes serious and progressive symptoms beginning in early childhood, especially the central nervous system with loss of neurodevelopmental milestones, deterioration of neurons, and loss of white matter; and the joints with stiffness, decline in mobility, and painful degeneration. Hematopoietic stem cell transplant, a treatment for MPS I, must be done as early as possible to prevent neurodegeneration, but is risky and does not completely take care of these difficult symptoms, leaving children with intellectual disability and severe deficits performing activities of daily living. The proposed studies will evaluate a multimodal gene therapy approach in the canine model of MPS I to simultaneously remedy multiple refractory aspects of the disease, paving the way towards future therapy for people with MPS I that is less risky, while comprehensively addressing symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is a medical technique that creates images of biochemical processes occurring in vivo, where radioactive molecules (also known as PET ligands) are injected and the distributions of those molecules are measured using a PET scanner. As the burden of psychiatric illnesses in the United States and worldwide is high, there is a critical need to develop novel PET ligands to image vasopressin-related neuropsychiatric disorders, including autism spectrum disorder. This work will develop key tools designed to advance the scientific understanding of arginine vasopressin receptor 1A in the central nervous system and facilitate the discovery of neurotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative: In prior work, we have established the latent variable “δ” (for dementia) as a dementia-specific cognitive phenotype. δ can improve dementia-related clinical trials. This project pilots several methodological advances: 1. The use of telephone assessment to minimize recruitment and assessment costs (and protect participants from potential SARS-cov-2 exposure). 2. The use of a latent dementia severity metric (dECog) to equate study groups on baseline dementia severity. 3. The use of a novel “Line of Identity (LOI)” algorithm to select cases most likely to benefit from intervention (an example of precision medicine). 4. The use of a latent dementia severity metric (dTEL) as a comprehensive dementia-specific outcome. 5. The use of a latent biomarker construct as a mediator, potentially establishing a novel mechanism to explain acetylcholine esterase inhibitor (AChEI) effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scope of quality improvement programs that focus on improving the utilization of first-line evidence-based medical therapies in patients with heart failure is limited by mechanisms to identify those who are eligible for specific treatments. The current proposal aims to design automated tools to identify patients eligible for heart failure therapies using various data components already captured in the electronic health record in hospitalized patients. The proposal will then pilot test strategies of improving treatment utilization with electronic alerts delivered to clinicians based on these tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-1-infected individuals who are under long-term anti-retroviral therapy, can effectively suppress plasma viremia, but remain predisposed to co-morbidities that are often attributed to hyperactivated and suboptimal immune functions. Recent indications that a sub-group of virus-infected cells called “active reservoirs” continue to generate viral RNAs and/or proteins during the treatment period could potentially contribute to the co- morbidities as well as relapse of viremia upon treatment interruption. We will extensively characterize the active viral persistence in lung alveolar macrophages to determine the roles of these reservoirs in viral rebound and immunological dysfunctions in therapy-suppressed individuals in order to identify molecular targets for their elimination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Progress toward elimination of pediatric HIV infection has stalled in recent years, primarily due to gaps in care for pregnant and lactating people with HIV and their infants. We propose to use a validated computer simulation model of mothers and infants to estimate and compare the clinical and economic impacts of alternative maternal interventions (HIV testing, pre-exposure prophylaxis, and antiretroviral therapy) and infant interventions (postnatal prophylaxis and testing), incorporating critical interactions between maternal treatment and infant prophylaxis and diagnosis. We will then develop, test, and apply simulation optimization methods and translate these results into online decision tools, to identify the packages of maternal and infant interventions that maximize clinical benefit and cost-effectiveness in a range of settings that reflect global variation in HIV epidemiology, healthcare delivery, and healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The establishment of left-right (LR) asymmetry is a critical event required for the correct positioning of internal organs. Defects in human LR axis formation cause birth defects of the heart, vasculature, lungs, and intestinal tract. Our research aims to discover the central mechanism that links Hedgehog (Hh) signaling pathway and transforming growth factor-b (TGF-b) signaling pathway to the establishment of left-right asymmetry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Widely-adopted targets such as “95-95-95” have fueled tremendous progress in access and effective use of HIV treatment, but no analogous targets exist for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). This study will estimate the relationship between plasma concentrations of PrEP drugs and their effects on reducing HIV acquisition risk, the relationship between PrEP program participation and non-pharmaceutical HIV risk reduction, and implications for how different combinations of PrEP coverage and adherence across population segments could lead to achievement of HIV epidemic goals. The evidence produced by this study could not only inform the development of PrEP targets, but also enable measurement of progress toward these targets using a Population-Based HIV Impact Assessment (PHIA) for PrEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of the oral microbiome among children at the stage of primary dentition is an important predictor of their future health and well-being. Understanding the changes in the oral microbiome from ages 3-5 years among HIV-exposed uninfected children will inform precise microbiota-targeted interventions. This research provides evidence-based information for integrating HIV care and dental care in resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (STATEMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) People with HIV are at increased risk of developing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which is the third leading cause of death worldwide, but we do not fully understand why. To address this knowledge gap, we will study associations between the oral microbiome, systemic inflammation, and COPD among people with HIV in Botswana. This information will improve our understanding of how COPD develops in people with HIV and may lead to the development of new ways to treat COPD using the microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE Viruses contribute to at least 21 different human cancers, representing approximately 15% of all human cancers. Understanding the biology of these human tumor viruses and how they cause cancer will provide new approaches for preventing and treating the associated cancers. In this program project grant a highly interactive group of seven investigators and their laboratory members engage in collaborative research focused on two objectives: to elucidate the life cycles of and transformation by human tumor viruses and to translate this understanding into the identification of targets for specific anti-viral, anti-tumor therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 − PROJECT NARRATIVE High-risk human papillomaviruses are the most common sexually transmitted virus and cause 5% of all human cancers. These cancers arise as a result of persistent infections that our bodies fail to eliminate. In this project, we explore ways to activate our own immune system to eradicate the persistent infections that give rise to these cancers and to improve clinical approaches to treating the cancer that do arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 – PROJECT NARRATIVE Latent Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection is an important cause of human tumors, especially lymphomas and nasopharyngeal carcinomas, in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressed hosts. Lytic EBV infection (in which infectious viral particles are produced) causes lesions on the tongue (oral hairy leukoplakia), particularly in HIV-infected patients. In this proposal, we will define how the EBV-encoded latent membrane protein 1 (LMP1) promotes epithelial cancers by inducing proliferation and inhibiting differentiation through effects on the tumor suppressor Hippo pathway. We will also determine the mechanism(s) by which epithelial cell differentiation promotes lytic EBV infection in normal epithelial cells. Finally, we will ask whether FDA- approved drugs which alter Hippo pathway signaling can be used to treat human diseases caused by latent and/or lytic EBV infection in epithelial cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 4 − PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common form of aggressive lymphoma, is actually a collection of multiple cancers (subtypes) that have similar clinical presentations but require different therapy. Overall, 5- 10% of DLBCLs are EBV infected, but we do not know the which DLBCL genetic subtypes are EBV-associated. In this project, we will determine these subtypes, how EBV promotes their development, and identify the subtype- specific therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE A – PROJECT NARRATIVE In this multi-investigator Program Project Grant (PPG), seven science laboratories at the University of Wisconsin pursue research to understand how viruses cause human cancer and to discover ways to prevent and treat these cancers. The Administrative Core provides two important services to the PPG. First, it provides oversight, as well as administrative and financial support to ensure that the science proposed can be carried out. Second, it provides expertise in statistics and bioinformatics to ensure that conclusions drawn are valid and to discover new insights based upon the analysis of high-dimensional genomics data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuronal metabolism and energy deficits have been implicated in many neurodegenerative and neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's diseases, epilepsy and schizophrenia. However, our current understanding of the molecular mechanisms of metabolic dysfunction leading to diseases is cursory at best. This proposal aims to identify fast spiking neuron specific energy generation pathways in the brain to determine how metabolism adapts to changes in neuronal activity and drives higher-order cognitive processes, such as long-term memory and sensory processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research Supplement to Promote Diversity in Health-Related Research The rocaglates and aglains are classes of natural products isolated from various Aglaia plant species which have shown a variety of favorable biological activities including anticancer, anti-inflammatory, and antiviral activities. As outlined in the Diversity Supplement application, development of catalytic, asymmetric synthesis approaches to these natural product scaffolds and targeted derivatives will be undertaken using novel photocatalyst systems. Successful development of the methodology will enable detailed exploration of the translational potential of these novel scaffolds. The planned studies are relevant to public health in that they will enable preclinical development of novel classes of anticancer and antiviral agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will produce a culturally sensitive technology-based HIV prevention intervention for Black women in SUD treatment that is aligned with modern prevention efforts, is informed by intersectionality, and circumvents SUD treatment-related barriers. Results of the current study will be impactful in addressing HIV risk among Black substance using women by 1) providing information about social determinants that are associated with HIV risk behaviors, 2) deepening the understanding of HIV risk behavior and current gaps in HIV treatment and 3) supporting the development of a technology-based HIV prevention intervention that is culturally sensitive and can be integrated into SUD treatment settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep disorders such as obstructive sleep apnea and insufficient sleep are extremely common in people with HIV and are associated with a greater risk of developing heart disease. Sleep disorders can cause monocyte activation in people without HIV, and this effect may be even greater in people with HIV who are already predisposed to monocyte dysfunction. This proposal will test whether sleep disorders alter monocytes in people living with HIV and provide crucial training for the applicant to become an independent scientist focused on understanding how sleep affects immune function and inflammation in people living with HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Fungal drug resistance is an emerging threat to public health and especially immunocompromised individuals. The proposed research will examine fungal species and their genes driving resistance in the oral environment of HIV patients with a long-term goal of improved diagnostics to optimize treatment. The project is relevant to the NIH mission in its combination of fundamental biological research on molecular mechanisms of drug resistance with application to enhance human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Defects in intracellular transport processes, including mutations in kinesin and dynein motor proteins, are known to contribute to neurodegenerative diseases, cancer, and ciliopathies. This work will utilize biophysical and cell biological approaches to reveal basic information about how kinesin motor proteins function within the complex cellular environment. This work will advance our understanding of intracellular trafficking processes and impact our ability to treat human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This dissertation proposal focuses on the unique needs of cisgender Black women in the United States, a vulnerable population facing disproportionately high rates of HIV and sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Current research is scarce on the complex interplay between sexual reproductive health (SRH) disparities and structural and social determinants of health among this population at risk for HIV in Maryland, particularly in understanding how to effectively integrate HIV prevention into existing SRH services despite these services being a primary and optimal mode for navigating the HIV prevention care continuum. Utilizing a mixed-method approach, this study investigates the availability, accessibility, and acceptability of SRH services, as well as personal experiences and perspectives, to inform the development of contextually appropriate and culturally sensitive HIV prevention strategies that address the root causes of these disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infects >300 million people worldwide, is the leading cause of liver-related death, is worsened by HIV, and is very difficult to cure. We have evidence that HBV-infected people who are receiving treatment show diminished expression of HBV genes, which is an unexpected observation. We propose using new techniques to uncover how diminished expression happens and comparing this process in people with only HBV to those with HIV and HBV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative This proposal represents a Supplement to Promote Diversity for a Hispanic graduate student to conduct research related to the parent RM1 (GM142002), expanding the scope of our existing aims. Mr. Max Balderas is a student in Joseph Ready’s research group, and he will develop chemical degraders of the enzyme 15- PGDH.
