IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The pentameric ligand-gated ion channels (pLGIC) mediate fast synaptic transmission in the central and peripheral nervous systems, and thereby critically govern numerous cellular processes such as pain perception, motor coordination, and gastrointestinal functions. Dysfunctions in pLGIC are associated with several psychiatric, neurological, and gastrointestinal disorders, and therefore these channels are important drug targets. The goal of the proposed studies is to elucidate fundamental mechanisms governing channel function and modulation at a molecular level. Findings from this work will lead to a better understanding of the role of pLGIC in various physiological and pathophysiological processes, and hence aid strategies for development of new and safer therapeutics.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The presence of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) in the cells of the infected people limits the development of an effective cure to this infection. These cells or organs where the virus persists are called “HIV reservoirs” and scientists are still working to keep discovering new HIV reservoirs that may need study. We propose experiments to investigate a cell type that is in the blood vessels of the lungs as potential cells acting as viral reservoirs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to plan the first-in-human Phase I/II clinical trial of a phage-based clinical intervention, ProphaLytic-VcTM (PVC), to prevent the community spread of cholera in Dhaka, Bangladesh. With the successful completion of prior small business grants, PhagePro has demonstrated that PVC is highly effective in preventing Vibrio cholerae colonization of the small intestine in mice and rabbits, thus protecting against cholera. We have established robust small-scale phage manufacturing parameters, optimized critical quality control assays, constructed an avirulent V. cholerae manufacturing strain, and completed Investigational New Drug (IND)- enabling studies aligned with the FDA’s expectations for phage products. With Serán Bioscience, we have optimized small-scale processes for solid dosage formulation of each PVC phage. With this R34 clinical trial planning proposal, we aim to collaborate with cholera physicians and researchers at the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Diseases Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b) to develop documentation to support successful implementation of the Phase I/II trial for safety and efficacy of PVC in household contacts of cholera patients. In addition, we will develop a regulatory plan in alignment with Bangladeshi authorities and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. If successful, the clinical trial will demonstrate proof-of-clinical efficacy for PVC and the potential for PVC to be a transformative tool in controlling cholera outbreaks around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental Health Sciences (EHS) encompasses many fields of study that seek to understand how chemicals in the environment impact human health. We plan to improve the interoperability, machine accessibility, and understandability of EHS data by identifying EHS community needs, expanding existing data standards, and developing testable workflows. Our overall objective is to develop standards and tools that allow the integration of data from all EHS fields to support public health and safety assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We think that aging causes cells in the bone marrow to stop secreting proteins that support normal development of immune cells, the cells in the body that heal wounds. This causes abnormal immune cells to travel to the arteries and cause disease. In this project, we will reverse aging in the bone marrow and see if it can prevent disease in the arteries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer (OCa) is the deadliest of all gynecologic cancers, and new therapeutic strategies are desperately needed to improve OCa patient survival. We identified a small chemical molecule ERX-208, that promote endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress in OCa cells but not in normal cells and has potent anti-proliferative activity. Proposed studies will enable both a better molecular understanding of how ERX-208 induces ER stress in OCa cells and enable rational design of more potent versions of ERX-208 either alone in combination with current chemotherapies. We believe that this project will generate a novel therapeutic agent and the preclinical rationale for further clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Proper coordination of gastric reflexes is dependent on vagal afferent responses to mechanical and chemical stimuli, including the orexigenic gut peptide ghrelin. The goal of the current project is to examine whether ghrelin-mediated inhibition of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels is dysregulated in gastric-projecting vagal afferent neurons following experimental spinal cord injury (SCI). The results of this study will offer insight into mechanisms underlying gastrointestinal dysfunction following SCI and could improve therapeutic targets of gastric motility disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The purpose of this project is to understand the relation between language and higher-order cognition (i.e., planning, problem solving, and executive function) in young children with developmental language disorder (DLD), who have problems with both skills. One possibility is that children’s impaired language leads to impaired self-directed speech (i.e., nonsocial speech directed toward oneself to regulate thoughts and behavior), which is positively related to higher-order cognition in children with typical language. Documenting the development of self-directed speech in children with DLD and establishing how the use of self-directed speech affects planning performance among these children is important for our understanding of the nature of deficits in DLD and for informing possible treatment approaches for improving cognitive performance in this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants born to mothers with HIV are more vulnerable to disease, have stunted growth, and have altered immunity, even when they are not infected with HIV themselves, which may be due to altered gut microbiome. Here, we propose to conduct a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial in infants exposed to HIV to test whether Bifidobacterium infantis EVC001 supplementation during the first month of life improves gut health, systemic inflammation and immunity longitudinally. This study may provide important preliminary evidence of a readily available intervention to improve gut health and subsequent immunity in infants exposed to HIV, a growing and vulnerable pediatric population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Influenza is a major public health threat worldwide, however, vaccine effectiveness is suboptimal and our current vaccine is strain specific, limiting effective control across multiple strains. This U01 addresses the critical need to improve understanding of how the human B and T cell response is established after initial influenza virus infection or vaccination in infants and children and to identify correlates of protection from disease. To this end, our consortium of world-renowned investigators is applying state-of-the-art immunological methods in the context of unique and established cohort studies in infants and children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This T32 program is designed to train post-doctoral trainees in palliative care research concerning patients with heart, lung, or blood diseases. The program stresses the conduct of clinically-relevant, patient-oriented research in an ethical and scientifically rigorous manner and has an on-going commitment to attract and train individuals from under-represented minorities. In this renewal application, we propose to build on our successful program with innovative strategies to maximize the impact and sustainability of palliative care research and to help address compelling questions identified in the 2016 NHLBI Strategic Vision.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Chemotherapy treatment often includes platinum based therapies such as oxaliplatin that produce peripheral nerve pain. Chemotherapy-induced pain is a burden imposed on patients (58-89%) causing sensitivity to touching cold items, discomfort swallowing cold items, throat discomfort, and muscle cramps. Symptoms are twice as severe in second and sequential treatment rounds with 79% of patients reporting moderate to severe pain scores. These symptoms can be permanent and disabling in > 40% of cancer survivors, substantially affecting quality of life. We have designed and engineered small antibody biologics referred to as scFvs. The scFvs target a nervous system receptor, called P2X4, that increases in pathological states such as chronic pain and anxiety conditions. In the proposed studies we (1) humanize the P2X4 scFv toward human use without initiating an immune response, (2) determine how effective the humanized version of the scFv is in reversing pain-like behaviors, and (3) test the lead scFv in human cells in culture dishes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Neurotrauma, such as traumatic brain injury (TBI) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), can cause persistent and profound sleep disruption, including abnormally increased muscle tone during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, or REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD). While RBD has been associated with early synucleinopathy and parkinsonism, the specific predictors and neural pathways by which neurotrauma leads to RBD and synucleinopathy are unknown. We aim to address these gaps using our mouse model of neurotrauma that shows REM sleep abnormalities, in combination with a transgenic mouse model of Parkinson's Disease, as well as test the ability of the botanical curcumin to mitigate synucleinopathy. Results from these studies will provide valuable mechanistic information about the pathophysiology underlying neurotrauma's effects on REM sleep and synucleinopathy. With this critical knowledge, we will take important steps forward in better predicting and mitigating potential neurodegeneration among Veterans with TBI/PTSD.

PHR: Project Narrative Cure rates for pediatric cancer have improved significantly over the past 30 years due to the enrollment of nearly all affected children in the United States on Children's Oncology Group (COG) clinical trials, and the research completed using biospecimens banked from these studies. The COG Biospecimen Bank aims to support additional pediatric and adolescent cancer research by collecting, processing, and distributing high quality biospecimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project seeks to enhance the value of the AphasiaBank database and tools for the study of spoken language and communication as used by people with aphasia. We will do this through the introduction of innovative methods for automatic speech recognition, discourse analysis, gesture analysis, corpus analysis, and a new system called collaborative commentary. We will apply these new methods to the analysis of the current database, as well as many new corpora. We will configure these new methods for widespread use by both researchers and clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Colorado Cancer Center (UCCC) is an NCI-designated matrix center that brings together 263 cancer researchers from two universities and four clinical entities to drive cancer discovery and innovation. UCCC addresses the cancer needs of its catchment, the State of Colorado, guided by its vision to prevent and conquer cancer. Together. UCCC's mission is to unite its community to overcome cancer through innovation, discovery, prevention, early detection, multidisciplinary care, and education. Exemplary research and adroit leadership, propelled by significant institutional investment has led to impactful innovations in cancer biology that translated into preventative, diagnostic and therapeutic strategies proven in clinical trials, approved by the FDA, and then disseminated to improve the standard of care. UCCC seeks to address the needs of underserved populations by providing targeted, culturally appropriate behavioral interventions, colorectal cancer screenings, and by shaping state tobacco control legislation. CCSG renewal and continuation of institutional commitments of funds and space will allow a continued upward trajectory and enhance the fight against cancer in Colorado.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Monoclonal antibody (mAb) therapies can drive potent anti-tumor immune responses and have thus become part of the standard of care in the treatment of many cancers, but their efficacy is impeded by diverse cancer resistance mechanisms. This proposal aims to characterize a novel mechanism that enables cancer cells to evade macrophage phagocytosis, which is a major pathway of cancer killing driven by mAbs. Establishment of this novel mechanism using a combination of in vitro and in vivo approaches will advance our understanding of cancer- macrophage interactions and will lay the foundation for therapeutic strategies aimed at counteracting cancer resistance to mAbs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knowledge generated from the proposed research will provide an evidence base for addressing disparities in the diagnosis of primary immune deficiency (PID) among racial and ethnic minorities. Because early diagnosis and treatment of PID are crucial for the prevention of permanent organ damage and death, addressing disparities in PID diagnosis will have a significant public health impact and is relevant to NIMHD’s mission to improve minority health and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to perform a randomized comparative effectiveness trial to assess the impact of a multidisciplinary telehealth intervention aimed at improving outpatient blood pressure control and decreasing disparities in blood pressure control in a racially and ethnically diverse cohort of ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke survivors by incorporating a social determinants of health approach into the care model. Hospitalized stroke survivors will be enrolled in the study prior to hospital discharge. Post-stroke care for stroke survivors enrolled in the intervention will include remote BP monitoring, video visits, and an integrated approach to care by a multidisciplinary team that includes a social worker, pharmacist, and stroke clinical provider.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Latinos in the U.S. experience significant disparities in access to mental health services due to lack of health  insurance, language barriers, low availability of bilingual providers, mental health stigma, and fear of  deportation. There is an urgent need to identify low-cost, culturally appropriate interventions to reduce mental  health disparities among this population. This project will address that need by implementing and testing  CRISOL Mente, a multi-level, culturally-congruent intervention to improve the mental health of the Latino  population in Philadelphia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer screening among Latinx populations lags far behind that of non-Latinx White populations. We will test a program that pairs video-texting with neighborhood navigation services to improve colorectal cancer screening for adults who are new to screening or have never been screened. Our program could serve as a model for sharing accurate health information and promoting healthy behavior for a variety of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: This proposal aims to employ artificial intelligence (AI) and natural language processing (NLP) technologies and conduct a randomized clinical trial to examine how a voice-assisted, remote patient symptom monitoring system (VARSMS) can reduce ethnoracial disparities after gastrointestinal (GI) cancer surgery. Black and Hispanic patients experience more difficult social and medical conditions while recovering at home than white patients, which makes a home-based “smart” intervention potentially transformative. Further, our system would replace less flexible and adaptable telephone-based systems currently in use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The uptake of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine is suboptimal among low-income children and adolescents in Texas. This project will utilize state-of-the-art data mining techniques to determine area-level HPV vaccination rates, will implement geospatial approaches to identify hotspots of poor HPV vaccination rates, and will disseminate evidence-based resources for improving HPV vaccination rates. The long-term goal of this project is to increase the HPV vaccination rates among low-income children and adolescents to reduce HPV-associated cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The HIV-infected population is surviving into old age, thanks to medicine regimens that are successful in lowering deadly viral loads, such that 47% (454,684) of Americans living with HIV/AIDS are aged 50 years and older. Despite the efficiency of antiretroviral therapy in reducing viral burden, those with HIV/AIDS remain especially open to accelerated neurocognitive declines of aging, added neural burden from heavy alcohol consumption, substance use, and organ system injury, and vulnerable to neurodegenerative disorders with older age such as Parkinson's disease (PD). Using the NIMH's Research Domain Criteria (RDoC), this research will contribute to public health utilizing brain imaging methods to discover neuroimaging biomarkers for emerging parkinsonism and accelerated cognitive decline beyond that of normal ageing and potentially modifiable factors such as sleep and daytime physical activity, which together can lead to advances in preventative therapy to be applied during midlife to counteract progression and reduce future disease burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This innovative proposal will address financial wellbeing, an often overlooked but important factor impacting reentry for justice-involved people with mental health challenges, who are disproportionately Black and Latinx. The project will change community level determinants by integrating financial capability support (one-on-one coaching and access to financial tools and services) into existing services and training bank and credit union staff to reduce discrimination. It will also support collaborative community efforts working towards upstream policy and legal reforms to reduce the incidence of those financial challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Heart problems are the number one cause of pregnancy-related death in the United States and most profoundly affect poor and non-White women. Social health programming can help people lead healthier lives by teaching them about stress management and healthy diets, which can help prevent heart disease later in life. Our research project studies how social health programming for teenagers can empower communities across the United States to overcome barriers to health and reduce the long-term burden of adult heart disease during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative African American adults have two times the risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease compared to other ethnic groups. Regular physical activity is promising for reducing risk of Alzheimer’s Disease, but there is very little data on this question in African Americans. The current study (called “RAATE-MCI”) will determine if regular physical activity conducted over a year will reduce risk factors for developing Alzheimer’s Disease in older African American adults with mild cognitive impairment. We will assess participant’s brain functioning, brain structure, memory, chromosomes, and the contribution of plaques in the brain on outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Exposure to household air pollution from primitive energy sources (such as charcoal and wood-burning stoves and kerosene lamps) is a top-ten risk factor for morbidity and mortality worldwide. This research will investigate whether a whole-house energy intervention can produce meaningful health benefits for women, men, and children in rural Rwandan homes. Outputs from this work will increase the clinical knowledge-base on the health effects on household air pollution and will generate policy-relevant information on scalable solutions to achieving cleaner, healthier forms of household energy.

PHR: Project Narrative Our training program in “Diseases of Public Health Importance” aims to provide interdisciplinary training in basic sciences related to the etiology, pathogenesis, prevention, and cure of diseases with significant global impact. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative.  Mutations in the photoreceptor-specific TULP1 gene cause an early-onset and severe form of retinitis pigmentosa, an inherited form of blindness. The first goal of this research project is to identify the function of Tulp1 and determine the complement of proteins comprising the Tulp1 complex and how these interactions combine to assemble the machinery required to transport photoreceptor proteins. The second goal is to define the pathological mechanism causing photoreceptor degeneration due to TULP1 mutations thereby identifying pathways as specific targets for therapeutic intervention aimed at slowing this blinding condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study focuses on cellular networks in the Alzheimer’s disease brain. Our studies take a GeroScience approach and are guided by our prior studies of the biology of the aging brain. We test whether delayed aging and neuroprotection by caloric restriction can ameliorate pathology advance in Alzheimer’s disease mice, focusing on the metabolic microenvironment and communication among neuronal and vascular networks.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project—the FFG3 study—will collect data on the 3rd generation of the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study (FF). We will collect information on perinatal health, parenthood experiences, and characteristics of households and families into which the 3rd-generation children are born, as well as biological samples from the 3rd-generation children and their parents who are not already part of the FF study. The data will facilitate novel and important analyses of intergenerational transmission of health, intergenerational relationships within families, and gene*environment effects on health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Mg2+ is essential for wide range of cellular processes including the imposition of membrane shape and stability, neutralization and stabilization of nucleic acids and nucleotides, channel modulation, enzyme secretion from acinar cells, and serves as a cofactor for cytosolic and mitochondrial metabolic enzymes. Although cellular Mg2+ dynamics is accomplished via numerous Mg2+ transport machineries, the molecular identity of these Mg2+ flux mechanisms have not been fully elucidated. In the MIRA program, we will identify ligands and channels and elucidate Mg2+-dependent metabolic signals that would establish the Mg2+ flux compendium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spatial navigation is fundamental to survival, and entorhinal cortex (EC) function is fundamental to remembering cognitive maps of environments, and perhaps in mapping relationships between knowledge more generally. EC dysfunction is one of the earliest effects of Alzheimer’s disease, yet how EC contributes to the cognitive mapping abilities that are impacted in aging and Alzeheimer’s-related dementia is remarkably poorly understood. We will utilize cutting-edge neuroimaging and virtual reality techniques to test specific predictions about how EC supports the cognitive map in young adults, and apply this foundational knowledge in an aged cohort to test a deep, mechanistic perspective of age-related declines in goal-directed navigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) Protein synthesis on the ribosome and intracellular motility and cell division, based on the molecular motors are crucial for development and maintenance of all of the organs in the body. The specific cellular machines to be studied here, the ribosome, myosins, and cytoplasmic filaments, are required for appropriate neuronal development, sensorineural function in hearing and eyesight, the immune response and cell division. Thus errors of expression or function lead to severe developmental neurological, cardiovascular, immunological deficits, and play roles in cancer cell division and metastasis, muscular dystrophy, cystic fibrosis and many other diseases. The studies proposed here will give fundamental information on how gene expression, cellular development, and transport motors function and may eventually lead to therapeutic targets in these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite strong consensus that early, specialized intervention for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) can have a dramatic impact on outcomes, the public health system’s capacity to provide such services is severely challenged by the rapid rise in ASD prevalence. The goal of this research is to increase timely and equitable access to ASD-specialized early intervention during the critical first three years of life by capitalizing on the existing infrastructure of the Part C Early Intervention (EI) system, which is publicly funded and available in all U.S. States. This project will train EI providers to use an evidence-based, inexpensive, parent-mediated intervention that can improve child and family outcomes as well as mitigate the substantial economic costs associated with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Glaucoma is a leading cause of incurable vision loss, and increased pressure inside the eye is a major risk factor. There is strong evidence that the biomechanical properties of the eye contribute to the well-known interindividual differences in susceptibility to increases in eye pressure. The proposed research will uniquely define protective biomechanical properties which may serve as new and more effective therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Animals and plants are composed of somatic cells that form the body, and germ cells that transmit genetic material to the next generation via the union of egg and sperm. This international conference will cover the latest research in germline biology in a range of organisms and experimental systems. By focusing on emerging topics in germline specification, the development of germ cells, gamete formation, fertilization and egg to embryo transition, the meeting will provide unique opportunities for sharing results and for fostering collaborations. The knowledge presented should positively impact the study of gene transmission and reproduction as relevant for human health and breeding of animals and plants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The opioid crisis has resulted in an alarming number of infants with a history of prenatal opioid exposure. Opioids are known to impair immune responses, thus uncovering how prenatal opioid exposure contributes to immune dysfunction is of great interest. This proposal postulates that immune dysfunction following prenatal opioid exposure may be the result of modulation of gut microbiota and epigenetic reprogramming of intestinal macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 diabetes is difficult to manage during exercise, and few validated tools exist to recommend treatment options to avoid dangerous complications resulting from low blood glucose. This proposal combines physiological modelling and deep learning to develop a novel artificial intelligence decision support system to help multiple daily injection users maintain safe blood glucose levels during and after exercise. We will build and validate this system in three parts: 1) we will tune a decision support system to correctly identify issues in patient glycemic control and recommend appropriate treatment modifications; 2) we will develop a new hypoglycemia prediction tool that reflects the longitudinal dynamics of glucose uptake during and after exercise; and 3) we will explore the performance of this decision support system and hypoglycemia prediction tool in a clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Stroke is a leading cause of long-term disability among American adults, and so promoting recovery from devastating stroke conditions such as aphasia (an acquired language disorder) is a public health priority. Aphasia recovery is often greatest in the first few months after stroke (the subacute phase), yet recovery extent varies widely between stroke survivors and cannot currently be predicted for individual patients. This research aims to address this problem by identifying currently unknown relationships between subacute phase brain function patterns and language recovery in people with aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Anton, Eva S. Project Narrative The emergence of progenitor diversity and the resultant neuronal organization and connectivity lay the foundation for an appropriately wired cerebral cortex. We plan to deconstruct the molecular logic of progenitor diversity and neuronal connectivity necessary for the formation of the cerebral cortex using models of neurodevelopmental disorders. Consequently, this work will provide a framework to establish how changes in progenitor balance or neuronal connectivity can lead to neurodevelopmental disorders and brain malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Postmenopausal women are disproportionately affected by recurrent urinary tract infection (rUTI), a disease that can persist for years and greatly lower quality of life. High rates of antimicrobial resistance and allergy have rendered many front-line antibiotics ineffective against rUTI and new therapies are urgently needed. The recently characterized microbiome of the urinary tract has been identified as a promising source of new rUTI therapies; therefore, the goal of this project is to gain the foundational knowledge necessary for the rational design of effective probiotic therapies for rUTI, using state-of-the-art techniques and human cohorts to determine the function of the urinary microbiome and how it, along with the chemical environment of urine, are altered during rUTI in postmenopausal women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  People over age 65 typically suffer from visceral adiposity, which accelerates aging by promoting insulin resistance, cardiovascular dysfunction, and many other chronic health conditions, significantly shortening healthspan and lifespan. We recently discovered that the generation of new fat cells is the major contributor of age-associated adiposity, and we propose to study when, where, and why does the making of new fat cells take place during aging. Successful completion of the proposed research will provide new therapeutic avenues for the prevention and treatment of age-associated adiposity and its related chronic diseases, ultimately promoting longevity and healthy aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Radiation cystitis is a debilitating condition caused by pelvic tumor irradiation that is associated with inflammation, neurogenic detrusor overactivity, hemorrhagic cystitis and chronic fibrosis that may require a cystectomy and where current therapies, which are often ineffective, focusing only on controlling hemorrhaging. Accordingly, our goals are to better characterize the pathophysiology of radiation cystitis in order to implement novel agents, to be used singly or in combination, to enhance its treatment: 1) mitochondrially targeted free radical scavenger, XJB-5-131; 2) p75 neurotrophin receptor (p75NTR) modulator, LM11A-31; 3) soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) activator, cinaciguat; and 4) intravesical infrared dye or contrast media mixture, gadobutrol/ferumoxytol, to selectively irradiate the bladder within the abdomen, or enhance non-invasive magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of bladder wall fibrosis, respectively. As LM11A-31 and cinaciguat have passed clinical safety trials for non-urological pathologies, the proposal has considerable clinical relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The virulence of SARS-CoV-2 and its toll on human health is staggering, and the need for a safe and effective vaccine remains dire. This proposal aims to develop and optimize a better adjuvant for a SARS-CoV-2 vaccine based on a proven strategy developed for influenza virus vaccination by using a combination adjuvant strategy to activate an array of innate receptor pathways which more closely recapitulates natural viral infection. We anticipate that these studies will lead to a translatable adjuvant compatible with different vaccine platforms and will accelerate and improve the protective efficacy of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines, while promoting the types of responses which avoid vaccine related enhancement of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are the most abundant cell type in the mammalian nervous system and actively contribute to neural circuit formation by influencing the neurons around them. The precise timing by which neural stem cells transition from generating neurons to astrocytes is an important variable in the formation of proper neural circuits and has been implicated in various neurodevelopmental disorders. This proposal uses genomic and stem cell-based approaches to identify the cellular origins of human astrocytes and the molecular pathways that drive gliogenesis. Together, this knowledge will help reveal new avenues for studying the pathogenesis and therapeutic strategies of neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The mitochondrial ATP synthase is a multi-subunit complex that generates most ATP in mammalian cells and has also been suggested to function as the mitochondrial permeability transition pore. Using two independent mouse models that we engineered to be deficient in the ATP synthase complex in cardiomyocytes, we investigate these functions in isolated cardiac mitochondria, cardiomyocytes, and hearts in vivo. Loss of the mitochondrial ATP synthase in cardiomyocytes results in lethal heart failure which is mediated by novel mechanisms that we define. Additionally, our data do not support a role for the mitochondrial ATP synthase as the mitochondrial permeability transition pore and suggest that it functions as a negative regulator. Finally, we explore the role of deficient ATP synthase function in human heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Circadian clocks are time-tracking systems that allow organisms to adapt to the time of day, and drive many cellular functions; their alteration can lead to a variety of diseases and physiological conditions. We propose the development of a chemical biology toolkit that will enable the concurrent tracking of multiple circadian signals at different levels, and utilize chemical entities to selectively target and alter the behavior of core clock proteins. These platforms will facilitate an array of further studies to understand the roles and functioning of the molecular clock that are currently not feasible.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Chronic musculoskeletal conditions, such as low back pain, have substantial costs and burden on society. A better understanding of the underlying reason for developing chronic low back pain is needed. This award will allow the PI to expand his mentoring of trainees in musculoskeletal pain phenotypes and leverage the rich clinical research environment at Duke University to advance his current clinic research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Catheters we place in patients for life-sustaining therapies such as dialysis can become infected causing significant medical and economic harm. Current management of these infections frequently includes removal and replacement of the catheter which can be difficult due to their life-sustaining function and risks associated with the procedure. In this study, we will develop a strategy to treat these infections in place using a combination of heat, antibiotics, and fluid flow and thus obviate the need for risky catheter replacement procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROPOSAL NARRATIVE SS peptides are among the most promising therapeutic compounds for the treatment of mitochondrial dysfunction associated with primary heritable diseases, chronic pathologies, and aging-related declines in health. Understanding the mode of action of these compounds coupled with the identification of variants with greater activity will mark a significant advance in the quest to treat mitochondrial disorders. The objective of the proposed research plan is to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which SS peptides operate at the membrane, mitochondria, and cellular levels, particularly with respect to aging-related diseases, and to evaluate a library of SS peptide variants that will inform the design of next-generation compounds with greater bioavailability and efficacy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rheumatologic diseases are a diverse group of conditions that together result in a large burden of disease in the United States and can lead to considerable morbidity, disability, lost work and premature death. The causes of these diseases remain poorly understood and there is a need for better therapies. This application will support the UCSF rheumatology research training of physician-scientists that for over 40 years has trained a cadre of the nation's leading researchers to address pressing questions that advance our understanding and treatment of rheumatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop tools to promote genetic research of aging, behavioral, and social phenotypes in diverse populations. Existing comparable tools require that researchers omit some data when those data come from diverse populations, whereas our proposed tools account for population differences in a way that allows researchers to use much more data in more diverse samples. Using these tools, we will be able to make scientific discoveries that are more representative of the global population, which will reduce the potential for unequal benefits from genetic research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section   The prevalence of schizophrenia and other mental disorders is high, and they cause severe socioeconomic stress on patients, families, and the society. Despite the identification of many genetic factors in human genetics studies, effective therapeutics are limited due to a lack of understanding of the pathophysiology of mental disorders. This proposal aims at understanding the function of SETD1A, which has been shown to be strongly associated with schizophrenia, and results derived from this study potentially will potentially help in devising novel therapeutics for mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The goal of this MIRA grant application is to continue developing a research program aiming to understand the biogenesis of mitochondrial membranes, with a focus on (1) oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) individual enzymes and supercomplexes, and (2) mitoribosomes and the mitochondrial translation machinery, as they occur in yeast and human cells. Disorders arising from impaired mitochondrial OXPHOS function or mitochondrial gene expression, including protein synthesis, result in a variety of pathologies, including encephalomyopathies and cardiomyopathies. Identifying and characterizing factors required for OXPHOS enzyme assembly, mitoribosome biogenesis and translation, and the pathways in which they act is a prerequisite towards understanding the molecular basis of these disorders.

PHR: NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) and COVID-19 are the leading causes of mortality from infectious diseases globally. The slow rollout of COVID-19 vaccines in low- and middle-income countries means that cases of co-infection with Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) and latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection will continue to take place. This proposal will identify how SARS-CoV-2 impacts reactivation of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection or immunity to Mtb antigens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. Project Narrative  The SKyRoCKeT Study (Surface-Knit and Reformulate CADENCE-Kids for Translation) will recruit a sex- and age-balanced sample of 360 young people 6-20 years of age to develop an integrative, physiologically-coherent age-cadence-log(MET) surface-based model, reformulate the prior R21 CADENCE- Kids study by providing individualized, more precise, age-specific and coherent cadence-intensity thresholds, investigate additional differences by anthropometric factors, and translate cadence-intensity thresholds to over- ground walking. The SKyRoCKeT Study is an innovative critical step to provide a coherent, interpretable, objectively monitored step-based intensity metric to inform (inter)national physical activity (PA) guidelines by transforming currently vague guidelines of PA intensity into quantifiable PA recommendations that can be of widespread use, which clinicians, young people, parents, and researchers can integrate into preventive care management and action plans for personalized care. The SKyRoCKeT Study will allow for a user-friendly, interpretable metric to more accurately inform public health/behavioral interventions, assessments, analyses, school-based health and physical education curricula and programs, and public health messages for young people and their caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid overdoses and suicides continue to be major public health problems that often converge in the emergency department (ED). The proposed study aims to establish the safety of administering ketamine to individuals with opioid use disorder who are endorsing suicidal ideation in the ED, and evaluate the preliminary efficacy on opioid- and suicide-related outcomes. Results from this study will help lay the foundation for an adequately powered efficacy trial of ketamine as a treatment option in the ED to improve opioid- and suicide-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Glucose is a key nutrient for supporting embryo development and decidualization of the endometrium. Our preliminary data indicate that the endometrium stores two distinct glycogen pools that may be important in regulating glucose availability to the embryo and decidua. This project will use a novel Cre/Lox mouse to separately investigate the role of epithelium and decidual glycogen and determine how obesity affects endometrial glycogen metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Growth factors are biochemical signals that regulate diverse cellular functions including proliferation, differentia- tion, or metabolic activity. This proposal seeks to develop new reagents and methods to selectively activate or suppress the activity of these signals with spatial and temporal control by tailoring their interactions at the sur- faces of cells. Once established, the tools will enable new biological discoveries and cell-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Nearly one in five children are obese, and disparities in overweight and obesity between children from low- and middle-to-high-income households persist despite a multitude of school-based interventions. The structured days hypothesis posits that structure within a school day plays a protective role for children against obesogenic behaviors, and, ultimately, prevents the occurrence of excessive weight gain. Based on demand-side financing, which has a long history addressing large scale public health problems in the United States through federal, state, and local programs like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program and the 21st Century Learning Centers Program, this study will provide access to healthy structured programming via vouchers to afterschool programs and summer day camps during two “windows of vulnerability” (ie afterschool and summer) for low-income children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital lung diseases are a significant source of pediatric morbidity and mortality for which no definitive treatments exist, although next generation in utero gene therapy may be applied to these disorders to correct pathogenic mutations prior to birth. While animal studies of viral vector delivery of in utero gene therapies are encouraging, identification of alternative, potentially safer delivery approaches will significantly advance the field toward clinical translation. In this proposal, we investigate the potential of ionizable lipid nanoparticles for this application by generating novel mouse fetal lung optimized ionizable lipid nanoparticles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) are clonal blood disorders characterized by overproduction of normal blood cells and an increased risk for progression to bone marrow scarring (fibrosis) or leukemia. Importantly, fibrosis or leukemia in MPN patients is highly lethal. I propose to focus on a key regulator, the High Mobility Group A1 (HMGA1) protein, because our preliminary data strongly suggest that HMGA1 is required for disease progression; my long-term goal is to identify pathways that could be blocked in therapy to treat, or even prevent, progression in patients with MPN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Inflammation-induced injury to the vital organs is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality following severe trauma; however, the precise mechanisms that control the host immune response are poorly understood. This program will examine key contributions of the vascular endothelium to direct and indirect immunomodulation after traumatic injury. Our goals are to 1) increase our basic understanding of how endothelial cells regulate inflammation; 2) define mechanisms occurring during endothelial dysfunction that drive organ injury; and 3) identify novel therapeutic tools that limit post-injury organ damage and improve trauma patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT) Dysfunction in lymphatic vessels is associated with development of many diseases, including obesity and metabolic disease, chronic wound and cancer, aging and Alzheimer’s disease, inflammation and cardiovascular diseases; however, therapeutic lymphangiogenesis for preventing and treating these diseases has not been widely explored partly due to the unavailability of a clinically-relevant cell source and controllable matrix environment. This research program focuses on strategies to utilize clinically-relevant stem cells and synthetic materials for controlling lymphatic networks formation. The expected outcomes from this research program has the potential to advance our basic understanding of lymphatic vasculatures in health and disease, as well as innovative therapeutics for a myriad of diseases that will benefit from therapeutic lymphangiogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Iron-dependent enzyme-mediated oxygen activation is a life-sustaining process that drives the metabolism of aerobic organisms. However, dissecting the contribution of ligand sets to oxygen activation is challenging due to the complexity of catalytic centers. By simplifying the ligand sets to solely nitrogen-donor ligands, we aim to address the scientific challenge by comparative investigation of heme and non-heme iron-dependent oxygenases of biomedical significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative O-GlcNAc is the only known intracellular glycosylation signaling pathway in mammals, and is implicated in nearly every basic biological process from signal transduction and gene expression to cell division and differentiation. Despite its widespread reach, we lack a foundational understanding of this post-translational modification, largely due to the lack of tools to unambiguously identify O-GlcNAcylated proteins or to perturb the essential O-GlcNAc transferase gene (Ogt). Here, we propose to apply new groundbreaking tools we have recently developed to uncover the principles of O-GlcNAc signaling, including its dynamics, how its propagated, and its role in transcriptional control of stem cell differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement We propose to develop a suite of machine learning methods to identify disease-relevant cell subpopulations from single-cell assays. Those methods will incorporate internal and external clinical phenotype information into single-cell data analysis to dissect biologically and clinically significant subsets from heterogeneous cell populations. Applying those approaches to distinguish phenotype-associated cell subpopulations from single- cell sequencing data will help identify the cell subsets driving the phenotypes, thus facilitating the discovery of cellular targets to treat human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinal detachment is an ocular emergency that can lead to permanent blindness due to photoreceptor cell death. Detachment of the retina can occur in all ages, from newborns to adults, and is characterized by active infiltration and activation of local microglia and peripheral monocyte/macrophages. Through the successful execution of this proposal, we will gain new mechanistic insights to effectively target these populations and develop novel neuroprotective strategies to prevent vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses three key limitations in the field of dementia family caregiving research, by focusing on caregiver cognitive health outcomes, quantifying two daily health behaviors of sleep and activities, considering caregivers' assistance to engage individuals with dementia in daily activities and the dyadic context of caregiving, and a chronic stress biomarker when examining the hypothesized associations. The project will generate critical information on how caregiver cognitive health is associated with daily sleep and activities within the dyadic context, elucidating the social context and biological mechanisms that relate to varying caregiver outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic, low-grade inflammation is a contributing factor to most diseases associated with aging. However, the molecular and cellular mechanisms that regulate chronic inflammation are still being deciphered. We will determine how specific regulatory microRNAs function to control age-dependent inflammatory status through their regulation of T cell metabolism, recruitment of inflammatory myeloid cells, and control of senescence-associated secretory phenotypes, and our work will identify novel therapeutic targets to treat this harmful condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TDP-43 proteinopathy is pathologic hallmark of frontal temporal dementia (FTD) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), and also occurs broadly in Alzheimer's Disease (AD). TDP-43 is an RNA-binding protein with multiple functions in mRNA processing, and also implicated in regulating retrotransposon activation. We will decipher the molecular mechanism how TDP-43 regulates the retrotransposon LINE1 RNA accumulation and how the LINE1 RNA elevation perturbs the gene expression landscape, which could contribute to neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chiral N-heterocycles are imperative scaffolds found in pharmaceuticals and biological processes. Our research program focuses on the development of novel methods for the economical and selective synthesis of such axially chiral N-heterocyclic compounds using small amounts of deliberately designed catalyst. Therefore, it is expected that the proposed research will have a significant impact on synthetic methodology and human healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute lung injury in the intensive care unit has a high mortality and is worsened by acute kidney injury. The mechanisms behind the kidney-lung interaction are not well understood and have potential as therapeutic targets to improve patient outcomes. The proposed project studies how activation of the intracellular innate immune receptor NOD2 contributes to acute lung injury following acute kidney injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  To fundamentally uncover the regulatory mechanisms between animal genomes and TEs in neurodegenerative disorders, we are deploying genetics, genomics, biochemical and small RNA analytical approaches on the RNAi pathway in the Drosophila model system to complement the translational objective of characterizing the TE RNA regulation process in human cells and brain samples. TE activation during aging is an intriguing hypothesis behind neurodegeneration because all animal genomes harbor a major reservoir of active TEs that are latent when animals are young but are activated during aging. This study leverages our lab’s previously established investigations of TE regulation during Drosophila aging, and we will bring new insight into how human TE RNAs are also processed into small RNAs during human aging and how these TE small RNA levels are affected in diseased states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  As a group, autoimmune diseases impose a major health burden. While specific autoimmune diseases are infrequent in the population, in the aggregate they affect 5-8% of Americans and can be life-threatening. Current treatments are only moderately effective, and carry a heavy risk of adverse effects. We have identified a monoclonal antibody specific for B cells that shows efficacy in animal models of rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and type 1 diabetes. This antibody therapy is safer than competing approaches because it does not induce B cell depletion and its effects can be reversed by cessation of treatment, enabling restoration of immune function. With further molecular improvements and clinical development, this antibody will greatly expand the therapeutic options for SLE and other autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative RNA expression from retrotransposable elements (RTEs) is enhanced in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The proposed research aims to better understand the functional roles of RTE-derived RNA and the regulatory mechanisms that lead to their aberrant expression in AD. This work will provide mechanistic basis for how and which RTEs may contribute to AD, potentially informing development of novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal analyzes the cellular and molecular mechanisms that regulate hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplant and hematopoietic regeneration following myelosuppression. Improving our understanding of how HSC transplant and regeneration occur at the molecular level is highly relevant to the treatment of patients with immune disorders, bone marrow failure syndromes, and leukemias. Furthermore, the identification and analysis of regenerative factors that promote hematopoietic recovery following injury is also necessary to support hematopoietic recovery in patients that experience accidental radiation exposure.

PHR: Relevance This study builds on new research into the functional significance of neuronal cell types in the mammalian cochlear nucleus, the first station for auditory processing. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In response to a wound, some cells fuse with several of their neighbors to become giant cells, which move faster and close wounds faster than regular cells. Similar giant cells are observed in many types of cancers, where they are malignant and resistant to therapy. We will investigate how these giant cells form in response to wounds, how they function in wound repair, and how they are eliminated after a wound is closed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently discovered that the enzyme Glutamate Carboxypeptidase II (GCPII) is highly upregulated in activated macrophages infiltrating muscle during aging, and that inhibiting the elevated GCPII activity dramatically delays neuromuscular junction (NMJ) denervation, muscle function and muscle volume loss in aged mice. Unfortunately, there are no clinically available GCPII inhibitors as current inhibitors are polar and charged at physiological pH resulting in poor oral bioavailability and limited tissue penetration. Given its significant clinical potential, we propose to utilize a hydroxyl-dendrimer delivery system to provide sustained and targeted delivery of GCPII inhibitors to activated muscle macrophage; successful execution will result in an oral dendrimer-GCPII inhibitor conjugate ready for clinical translation to combat age-related sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Prions cause epidemics in animals and humans and, like viruses, evolve to produce novel strains with unpredictable properties. Prions are misfolded versions of a host-encoded protein which contain the necessary and sufficient information for infectious propagation within their conformation, thus obviating requirements for agent-encoded genomic material. This proposal addresses important emerging issues relating to novel animal prion strains, their potential to wreak significant ecological and economic havoc, and the increasingly uncertain prospect that they might cause disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV infects cells by entering the nucleus and integrating its reverse transcribed DNA into host genome. Currently, key steps of infection, including disassembly of the protective capsid shell surrounding the viral DNA and subsequent events leading to integration, are not well understood. We will employ a panel of biochemistry, virology, and single virus imaging techniques to delineate the controversial capsid disassembly process and characterize the role of new nuclear host factors required for infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Different contexts require different strategies for incorporating time-related information into value-based decisions. The goal of this project is to improve the precision with which we can measure human brain processes that support context-appropriate calibration of valuation and decision processes. The results will advance our understanding of the basis of miscalibrated decision behavior in mental health conditions— including both failures to persist toward long-run goals and unwarranted persistence toward non-beneficial outcomes—and will lead to new computational tools for studying the relevant brain systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The greatest unmet need in multiple sclerosis (MS) is to develop novel treatments targeting cells and processes within the central nervous system (CNS) to confer neuroprotection and repair disabilities, in not only relapsing remitting MS, but also in secondary progressive MS. A “one size fits all” neuroprotective treatment approach in MS will not work, since 1) MS patients are heterogenous regarding which disabilities are predominant, 2) being female versus male impacts rates of disability progression, and 3) aging corresponds with disability progression. This R35 will use a cell-specific, region-specific, and sex-specific approach to discover neurodegenerative targets optimized for each disability in MS models in females and males during young adulthood and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The healthy corneal surface is an effective barrier to bacteria, yet the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is able to infect the eye during contact lens wear. We discovered that corneal epithelial cells normally undergo pyroptosis, an inflammatory and lytic programmed cell death, in response to bacterial invasion; however, P. aeruginosa inhibits this host response with one of its toxins, Exotoxin S. We will investigate the importance of pyroptosis in resolving microbial encounters at the ocular surface, and also identify how P. aeruginosa is able to subvert this host defense mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Targeted manipulation of the gut microbiota to increase health-associated features and functions is a sought- after therapeutic strategy for many human conditions and diseases. This proposed research seeks to identify mechanisms by which cell surface polysaccharides from human gut bacterial strains shape microbiota composition and function through utilization as a nutrient source by microbiota members and by modulating the immune system. The knowledge generated from this study will improve our understanding of the nutritional landscape within the gut, and identify specific carbohydrate structures useful for targeted microbiota interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Overall Narrative Our objective is to understand fundamental mechanisms underlying communication between cancer cell genomic instability and the immune system. To achieve our goals, we have assembled three Projects that will work closely with three Cores to address critical questions on detection of genome instability in tumors by the immune response. Integration of these multidisciplinary projects with Mammalian Artificial Chromosome and Chemical Biology Cores will transform understanding of the molecular basis for immune detection of genome instability in cancer and define approaches to enhance immune therapy mediated responses in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project proposal seeks to understand fundamental mechanisms of genome integrity control and their relationships to immune responses to cancer. We have demonstrated the importance of cell cycle checkpoints in mediating communication between DNA damage and innate immune responses, and now approach this central issue in cancer biology by utilizing unique systems to investigate DNA damage dependent (1) RNA pattern recognition, (2) signaling mechanisms that augment MDA5 and RIG-I activation and their impact on in vivo immune responses, and (3) communication between these mechanisms and NLRP9 dependent inflammasome activity in directing the tumor immune microenvironment. These pursuits will be performed in collaboration with other team members to define specific strategies that target the DNA damage response to elicit effective immune responses to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Project 2 Solid tumors evolve genetically, which for therapy makes them a diverse and moving target, and we hypothesize that extrinsic mechanical factors – particularly 3D tissue/tumor architecture and its rigidity – contribute in key ways to chromosome instability and to the immune-sculpted evolution of aneuploidy. Several new and diverse molecular tools will be used in solid tumor type microenvironments (rather than 2D) to clarify mechanisms by which adhesion pathways affect mitotic fidelity including DNA damage processes that extend to signaling pathways and innate immune responses. Pan-cancer patient data further indicates that high levels of aneuploidy skews macrophages and somehow impedes Tcell checkpoint blockade (in melanoma), but with new approaches and tools we have focused on macrophage checkpoint disruption that preliminary data shows (in challenging B16 melanoma models) can produce durable cures, which now requires understanding the contributions of aneuploidy and microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: For reasons that are not fully understood, sensory hair cells in the inner ear die off with age likely contributing to loss of balance function which is one of the most pervasive and costly public health concerns for older adults. Preliminary evidence herein suggest that the pro- survival gene, Pou4f3, which is highly expressed in inner ear hair cells, is downregulated with age in a fashion that precedes hair cell death and dysfunction. We therefore propose experiments to better understand the regulation of Pou4f3 expression with age, to directly test whether targeted genetic disruption of Pou4f3 causes hair cell death and balance dysfunction, and to determine whether overexpression of Pou4f3 can prevent age-related declines in balance function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is influenced by the immune system, which is itself regulated by intestinal microbial metabolites. These metabolic signaling pathways present an opportunity for therapeutic immune remodeling to improve CRC outcomes ranging from prevention to enhancing chemotherapy and immunotherapy. The objectives of this study are to delineate pathways by which microbial metabolites regulate immune cells, engineer a probiotic microbial strain to locally deliver therapeutic metabolites, and test the impact on CRC of using microbial metabolites for immunoregulation – united by a common focus on RORgt+ Tregs, a critical anti- inflammatory immune cell population in the intestine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NIAID Clinical Data and Safety Management Center (CDSMC) is a consolidated clinical support service center conceived to manage NIAID’s portfolio of clinical research in allergic diseases, asthma, autoimmune disorders, and immune-mediated complications of transplant, continuing programs supported by Rho under prior awards. Our vision is to advance NIAID’s history of successful clinical research by continuing our successful collaboration in data management, safety, and specimen tracking with a focus on continuity while embracing innovation. Over the last two decades, innovation has dramatically changed clinical trial operations, with the technology revolution advancing trial data systems and advances in biology enabling research to halt disease processes, and the Rho team seeks to continue our support of NIAID’s work to deliver on this promise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents’ involvement in medical decision making related to a chronic illness may lay the groundwork for effective and independent illness management as youth mature. The primary goal of this proposal is to develop a self-report questionnaire to assess youths’ involvement in decision making during outpatient visits for pediatric chronic illness (specifically, type 1 diabetes, sickle cell disease, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, and inflammatory bowel disease). Data from this project will lead to more nuanced clinical approaches to enhance youth participation in medical encounters, promote independent interactions with the health care system, and improve health behaviors and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: There is a dire need in cancer biology to advance the understanding of the downstream consequences of DNA damage, the causes and consequences of chromosome missegreation at cell division, and the mechanisms that drive these processes in tumors. The mammalian artificial chromosome (MAC) core will serve as a foundry for the advanced genetic tools that are uniquely suited for studies of these processes. The MACs will serve as critical tools for developing new understanding that has the promise to impact immune modulating approaches that improve patient response, inform new strategies to overcome therapeutic resistance, and develop predictive biomarkers of patient response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To treat disorders such as autism, schizophrenia, and epilepsy we must understand the mechanisms that govern how neural circuits are built during development. Neurons differentiate into several unique subtypes which must interact to assemble healthy cortical circuits. Here, we will knock out the disease-risk gene Satb2 from excitatory pyramidal cells to determine how this impacts their differentiation into distinct neuronal types, and in turn the development of the neural circuits of the hippocampus.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will improve our understanding of a ‘one health’ approach to physical activity interventions for adolescents with developmental disabilities through the multi-site evaluation of a novel, imitation-based, intervention with the family dog. This intervention is designed to increase daily physical activity, quality of life and social wellbeing in adolescents with developmental disabilities, even after the program has been completed. This research will improve public health by evaluating new areas of animal assisted intervention aimed at improved developmental trajectories for adolescents with developmental disabilities, directly addressing the research goals of the One Health initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria is an impediment to the entry of antibiotics into the cell, which is especially problematic given the increasing threat of antibiotic resistance in gram-negative bacteria to public health. Our project investigates a novel link we have discovered between loss of the DNA mismatch repair pathway (MMR) and alteration of OM permeability causing broad antibiotic resistance. Completion of our Aims will elucidate the connections between MMR and OM permeability, greatly expanding our understanding of the links between DNA repair and antibiotic resistance and identifying potential targets for antimicrobial discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative: This grant proposes to elucidate how aging affects NAD+ metabolism in normal and progeroid fibroblasts as well as in mice, and if NAD+ replenishment can mitigate progeroid or senescence phenotypes. A second aspect of work characterizes the effect and metabolic pathway of a novel NAD+ precursor called dihydronicotinamide riboside (NRH) in fibroblasts and mice. Finally, pre-clinical translational studies characterize effects of NRH in eliciting mitochondrial biogenesis in aged mice and test its effects in the treatment of a mouse model of metabolic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV are at a greater risk for obesity and metabolic diseases like diabetes and heart disease because of the effects of the antiviral medicine they have to take to control the HIV virus. Women represent a growing proportion of people living with HIV and are at even greater risk for treatment-related disease when they undergo menopause and loss of estrogen that helps prevent metabolic disease. This project will use a monkey model of postmenopausal women living with HIV to determine if estrogen replacement therapy will prevent the adverse effects of menopause on HIV treatment-caused metabolic disease and the ability of HIV treatment to control virus levels.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The proposed mixed-methods sequential explanatory study project addresses a highly relevant public health question: what is the implementation landscape for evidence-based transdiagnostic approaches to treat mental disorders in primary healthcare. Mental health disorders are among leading contributors to Ukraine’s poor health profile, with high morbidity, mortality, and disability rates. The information gained through this study can contribute to closing the mental health treatment gap in Ukraine, LMIC, and other low-resources settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than one in five hundred people have genetically based cardiomyopathies that are a leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young people. We will determine the mechanisms by which mutations in the motor that powers cardiac contraction lead to cardiomyopathies, allowing for the design of therapies for preventing or alleviating the disease symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The success of vaccination requires the generation of a strong immune response to the inoculated antigens to provide long-term protective immunity against infectious diseases. To accomplish this goal often requires the addition of vaccine adjuvants, substances that do not induce immune response against themselves, but significantly enhance the immunogenicity of co-administered antigens. The goal of this grant application involves exploration of carbohydrate saponin molecules as novel vaccine adjuvants for utilization in humans to combat a wide range of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic elements known as transposable elements and inflammatory molecules known as inflammasomes are thought to be involved in Alzheimer's disease (AD) but causal links have not been established. We will determine whether a class of transposable elements known as SINE RNAs activate specific inflammasomes and whether blocking this activation is beneficial in models relevant to AD. These studies will provide a deeper understanding of the role of these inflammatory transposable elements in AD and can serve as a foundation for future development of targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 2R01DK095112-05A1 Anemia is a common health issue affecting all age groups. While varying in their underlying causes, all forms of anemia require adaptation of iron metabolism. This proposal will identify and characterize signaling mechanisms by which iron metabolism and red blood cell production are interrelated, and will test approaches to modify this signaling in the treatment of the blood disorder beta thalassemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the most effective therapy for adults with major depression; however, some patients fail to respond despite an adequate trial, and ECT can produce negative cognitive effects. In this revised four site, prospective study we propose the first investigation of ECT outcome integrating multiple types of data including clinical and cognitive measures, whole-brain neuroimaging, EEG, and E-field modeling to establish the mechanisms underlying ECT-induced antidepressant response (response biomarkers) and negative cognitive effects (safety biomarkers). Using this approach in patients with major depressive disorder (n = 230), we will confirm the “sweet spot” of ECT dosing in order to maximize antidepressant benefit and cognitive safety.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will use an integrated data approach to explore racial differences in the effectiveness of supplemental reading interventions that provide intensive, targeted support to students with or at-risk for reading disability (RD). To date, the paucity of studies that disaggregate findings by student race make it impossible to know whether reading interventions deemed evidence-based are generalizable and valid for Black students. This project will advance our understanding of the persistent disparities in reading achievement between Black and White students and potential sources of individual difference for these groups.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Circadian disruptions, such as shift work, impair fertility in humans and other animals, and this may be due in part to food consumption at the wrong time – at odds with the normal biological rhythm. In mice, we found that mis-timed food reduces reproductive success. In this application, we will build on this by determining how light cycles, food cycles, and biological clocks in the hypothalamus interact in the control of reproduction.
