IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common viral infection to complicate heart transplantation and is a well-established risk factor for rejection, a significant barrier to allograft function and longevity. The goal of this project is to create a high dimensional cartography at single-cell resolution of the cardiac allograft tissue microenvironment during cellular rejection with CMV infection to identify mechanisms of viral rejection and immune cell signatures that track with tissue disease state in the blood. Successful completion of these proposed studies will nominate novel, non-invasive biomarkers to predict CMV-related outcomes in heart transplant recipients and guide the development of rejection treatment strategies that selectively mitigate viral immune dysregulation. .

PHR: Project Narrative  The University of Mississippi proposes to establish the Glycoscience Center of Research Excellence (GlyCORE), a new University-wide center to study how carbohydrates and carbohydrate-containing molecules affect human health. GlyCORE will support investigators in glycoscience through direct funding of selected research projects, establish mentors for early career investigators, support the recruitment of new faculty in glycoscience, and develop local and regional meetings for investigators to discuss their work. GlyCORE will also support the establishment of three central research cores to support these investigators with cutting-edge biomedical research tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Multiple myeloma is currently considered incurable due to the development of drug resistance disease that ultimately causes patient’s death. This study is expected to define a new mechanism and a factor for drug resistance in myeloma. It will also develop assays to analyze individual patients’ drug response as well as reagents to reduce drug resistance. Such assays may be used to determine which patients might harbor the specific resistance factor and therefore to select patients who might most benefit from a future therapy targeting the causative factor identified here.

PHR: Alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) is responsible for telomere maintenance in some cancers and can be activated in other cancers by anti-telomerase treatments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE We submit that thrombus formation in response to normal, physiological bleeding produced by puncture wounds or biopsies or other causes is fundamental to human health and is still poorly understood. We do not yet have the penetrating ultrastructural analysis of a forming clot that is required to build conceptual paradigms based on a structural characterization of the actual clot that forms. The studies proposed test a novel clotting paradigm, Cap and Build, and should greatly increase the predictive value of that paradigm. In brief, the research should yield through signaling tests and adhesive mutant studies a sensitive, validated ultrastructural paradigm in which to assess bleeding effects and drug consequences that should be extensible with time and effort to many other systems including arterial bleeding, thrombosis, embolism, and DVT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the most effective therapy for adults with major depression; however, some patients fail to respond despite an adequate trial, and ECT can produce negative cognitive effects. In this revised four site, prospective study we propose the first investigation of ECT outcome integrating multiple types of data including clinical and cognitive measures, whole-brain neuroimaging, EEG, and E-field modeling to establish the mechanisms underlying ECT-induced antidepressant response (response biomarkers) and negative cognitive effects (safety biomarkers). Using this approach in patients with major depressive disorder (n = 230), we will confirm the “sweet spot” of ECT dosing in order to maximize antidepressant benefit and cognitive safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early recognition and treatment of mania spectrum symptoms is vital for a favorable prognosis. Psychomotor activation - increased activity or energy - is a central feature of the mania spectrum that can be quantified through objective measurement of locomotor activity. In a comprehensive laboratory assessment and naturalistic follow- up study, we propose to uncover the biobehavioral (circadian, reward) mechanisms driving locomotor activation and mania spectrum risk. Findings will improve early detection of mania symptoms, help identify those most vulnerable to worsening mania symptoms over time, and provide novel targets for interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Osseointegrated prostheses are a novel alternative to a socket prosthesis that directly mount the prosthesis to the residual limb femur via a bone anchored implant, which allows the amputated limb to be loaded in a more normative fashion. Early evidence is highly promising regarding the improvement in function and quality of life after osseointegration; however mechanical failure due to implant loosening or periprosthetic fracture caused by pathologic loading at the bone-implant interface exists in a small subset of this population, yet the mechanistic understanding as to why remains poorly understood. The findings of this proposal will be fundamental in the understanding of bone-implant loading mechanics and failure mechanisms, which can be used to improve the efficacy of targeted post-surgical rehabilitation by normalizing loading following prosthesis osseointegration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Copper is an essential nutrient that is vital for oxygen metabolism. Although low tissue concentrations of oxygen are a common physiological stress, the adaptive mechanisms of copper homeostasis are unknown. The proposed research will elucidate the mechanisms by which oxygen regulates copper homeostasis and test the therapeutic potential of oxygen depletion as a novel treatment for a genetic copper overload disorder.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The proposed program will establish the first blended Masters and Postgraduate Diploma training in bioethics in Kenya at 2 local universities. The program will also build capacity of both Kenya and Pakistan-based faculty to support these graduate-level training programs by offering focused trainings in bioethics pedagogy, mentoring, and scientific writing including grantsmanship and manuscript development. Rapid capacity building initiatives will involve training stakeholders from both countries in basic and emerging issues in research and public health ethics through workshops and certificate courses, with a focus on enhancing human subject protection, especially in resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repeated opioid use is a significant factor driving overdose deaths in the continued opioid epidemic plaguing the U.S. healthcare system. This research evaluates how repeated fentanyl use, such as opioid use disorder remodels, the control of breathing. We examine the role for and mechanisms related to behavioral-based remodeling after repeated opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research project is relevant to human health because antibiotic resistance is a growing problem threatening long-term global health outcomes and enormous associated costs. Bacteriophage are rising as an attractive supplemental or alternative therapy to combat bacterial infections, and an understanding of how phage structures mediate entry into bacterial hosts through the use of specialized receptor proteins is expected to give rise to new or improved uses of therapeutic phages. Therefore, this proposal is directly relevant to the NIGMS mission of supporting basic research to increase our general understanding of key biological processes that ultimately will lay a foundation for disease treatment.

PHR: Project Narrative: Our broader vision is to uncover the code for translating a range of protein surface structural characteristics into protein surface interaction and functional properties. The Han lab will pursue such translation using molecular biological and biochemical tools, as well as state-of-the-art characterization tools that capture surface structural properties with higher information content, greater level of details and resolution, including the properties of the protein surface water layer, protein dynamics, and protein conformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Providence/Boston CFAR (Prov/Bos CFAR) is a collaboration between Lifespan/Brown University and Boston University/Boston University Medical Center leveraging our complementary and synergistic strengths to build a multidisciplinary HIV research portfolio. Our CFAR is particularly focused on marginalized populations including men who have sex with men (MSM), people who use substances, justice-involved persons, women, gender minorities, and at-risk youth both domestically and globally. The resources of the CFAR have resulted in an increase in our HIV funding, increased hiring of new faculty engaged in HIV research, and support for early stage investigators to develop a career in HIV research.

PHR: Narrative: The long-term goal of this R01 is to further advance our knowledge of the AIDS-defining malignancies caused by Kaposi’s Sarcoma-Associated Herpesvirus (KSHV). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Biophysics is an interdisciplinary field of the biomedical sciences that aims to understand the mechanisms of human health and disease on a molecular scale using the tools of the physical and quantitative sciences. The Molecular and Cellular Biophysics Program (MCBP) at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is an established and successful training program in biophysics that seeks funding to train a diverse cohort of students for this rapidly advancing and critical field. Program graduates will be equipped to pursue innovative career trajectories that drive biomedical research and education through the training and leadership skills they developed and honed in the MCBP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative: Following the great success of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART), older individuals (>50 years of age) account for approximately 30–50% of HIV-1 seropositive individuals in high-resource countries; a prevalence that is expected to reach approximately 73% by 2030. Neurological complications of HIV infection are the big- gest challenge facing HIV researchers and there is a critical need to develop treatment approaches for HIV-1- associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND). We are in a unique position to critically test the efficacy of a regenerative “dendritic spine-targeted” therapeutic approach to alter the longitudinal trajectory of HAND (i.e., delay progression of neurocognitive impairment) by restoring synaptodendritic integrity via the NogoA- NgR3/PirB-RhoA signaling pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kentucky (KY) is a high priority Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) jurisdiction due to heavy rural HIV burden and exceptionally high rates of new HIV diagnoses driven by injection drug use. A central pillar of EHE is the prevention of new HIV infections through scale up of PrEP in key populations, including people who inject drugs (PWID), who are notably impacted by structural challenges to PrEP uptake. This R34 application proposes to develop, integrate and test a low threshold peer-facilitated telehealth (TelePrEP) intervention for Appalachian KY PWID in syringe service programs (SSPs), filling a critical need to implement innovative approaches to mitigate geographic disparities in PrEP access and improve the care cascade among PWID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We are proposing comprehensive, mechanistically focused, and highly synergistic studies that will determine the factors promoting in vivo the development and maintenance of terminally-differentiated natural killer (NK) cells with enhanced antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. Furthermore, we will investigate how those factors can be synergistically harnessed with IL-21 and bNAbs treatments to enhance viral control of simian immunodeficiency virus in the absence of antiretroviral therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amidst the ongoing opioid epidemic, injection drug use has increased in the rural areas of the Deep South, and persons who inject drugs (PWID) are at higher risk of contracting HIV and Hepatitis C Virus (HCV). Given the lack of access to HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and HCV care and medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD), PWID living in the rural areas of the Deep South are at elevated risk of contracting HIV and HCV, yet few tailored, innovative, trauma-informed approaches are available for this at-risk population. The proposed plan for career development and research focuses on this critical gap by assessing barriers to and facilitators of PrEP, HCV care and MOUD for PWID in the rural areas of the Deep South and then using these findings to develop and pilot-test a tailored, multi-component, trauma-informed, and resilience-based telehealth intervention that aims to increase awareness of and willingness to use PrEP and HCV care and MOUD in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Of the many examples of cellular trans-differentiation and reprogramming in the research literature, very few if any efficiently generate new cells that exhibit terminal differentiation suitable for cellular therapeutics and disease modeling. In the past funding periods of my two grants that converge into this R35 application, our laboratory has found that genes residing in particular varieties of chromosomal condensation, known as H3K9me3-heterochromatin, are refractory to activation during trans-differentiation and reprogramming. The present application uses a research environment for diversity, equity, and inclusion to bring together diverse technologies and cellular systems to understand how gene regulatory proteins overcome the heterochromatin barrier and to apply the information to create more differentiated cells for therapeutics and disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE If successful in building MI skills among HIV counseling support staff, iMI4HIV has the potential to shift how MI training is provided to these critical providers of HIV care services. Furthermore, the program can be housed at FSU for use by AETCs throughout the country to provide additional MI training to their client agencies, used to train HIV treatment counselors in research studies, and provide training opportunities for other community-based agencies working to End the HIV Epidemic. Lastly, it can provide a training model that can be adapted to training providers working with other patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) is one of the most significant factors fueling the global HIV epidemic and coinfection is associated with higher HIV plasma viral loads and increased rates of HIV transmission. The goal of this application is to identify the mechanisms by defining the transcriptional responses to HSV-2 in HIV-infected individuals using primary cells and genital skin biopsies obtained during HSV-2 recurrences and to determine how these responses promote HIV replication. The results obtained will have broad implications and accelerate the development of strategies for HIV eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ultimate solution for HIV infected people on lifelong therapy is to find a cure. This study will use lymph node and guts from a cohort of ART suppressed individuals, some of whom interrupted therapy following a bNAB intervention. The study will seek to identify barriers to HIV eradication in tissues and perform in vitro testing of therapeuitic strategies for eliminating HIV in tissues for a cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a strong correlation between chronic drug use and increase susceptibility to HIV infection. Chronic drug users accounts for approximately a third of all cases of AIDS in the USA and the progression to HAND is markedly accelerated in opiate drug abusers; currently most HIV patients are on ART however, the long term consequence on neurocognition has not been delineated. This proposal postulates that alteration in the GUT microbiome results in the secretion of Bacterial extracellular vesicles that are able to cross barriers and travel long distances to modulates microglial cells thus contributing to neurocognitive deficits that are persistence in people living with HIV that are substance users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proper assembly of membrane proteins is of critical importance to cellular physiology, yet we do not have a fundamental understanding of the physical reasons why membrane proteins form stable assemblies in the hydrophobic membrane. In this project, we will study the equilibrium dimerization reaction of the CLC-ec1 Cl- /H+ antiporter as a model system to dissect the thermodynamic driving forces underlying membrane protein association in lipid bilayers. The results from this study will identify the molecular mechanisms for how protein sequence, lipid composition and general anesthetics modulate stability, and thereby lay down a physical foundation for the development of new strategies aimed at correcting stability defects in membrane protein folding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV and gestational diabetes both increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes postpartum, but it is not known whether HIV adds to the risks brought on by gestational diabetes. I propose a longitudinal cohort study following pregnant women with gestational diabetes with and without HIV over 2 years postpartum to 1) determine how HIV affects the development of type 2 diabetes or its precursor, pre-diabetes and 2) characterize the longitudinal effect of HIV on beta cell function, which is a major contributor to the pathophysiology of type 2 diabetes. The results of this study will be used to develop lifestyle or pharmacologic interventions to prevent diabetes in South Asian women with and without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This study will identify new aptamers that differentiate among HIV-1 capsid assembly states and develop an aptamer-mediated, capsid assembly state-specific affinity purification method paired with crosslinking mass spectrometry to identify novel capsid-associated host factors. This work will generate new tools and methods to support future studies that improve our understanding of HIV-1 capsid structure-function relationships, the role of capsid assembly forms in diverse HIV-1 replication steps, and capsid-host factor interactions, leading to a better understanding of the role of capsid in HIV-1 biology. Future work beyond this proposal could significantly impact the discovery of anti-HIV drugs that target novel aptamer-binding sites on capsid protein, define the role(s) of specific capsid assembly forms in HIV biology, and be extended to the capsids of other viruses of public health importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to investigate the effects of methamphetamine (METH) abuse and HIV-1 infection on the brain, specifically on the cells responsible for creating new neural cells, called neural progenitor cells (NPCs). This application is focused on how the migration of NPCs and interactions with brain pericytes may be affected by METH and HIV-1. Our goal is to better understand these impacts and find new ways to treat neurological issues in people living with HIV-1 who abuse METH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 associated neurocognitive diseases (HAND) affect up to 50% of people with HIV-1 (PWH), including those receiving antiretroviral therapies (ART), and there are currently no effective treatments available. This project aims to investigate the role of the endocannabinoid system (ECS) in the development of HAND. By gaining a deeper understanding of the mechanisms by which selective cannabinoid receptor agonists modulate neuroinflammation, we may be able to develop new therapeutic approaches to treat HAND and improve the quality of life for PWH.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) affects millions of women annually, leading to increased vaginal inflammation, elevated susceptibility to STIs, adverse birth outcomes, and a reduction in quality of life. However, our understanding of the factors influencing transitions to BV, as well as the mechanisms underlying its persistence and recurrence, are incomplete. This project utilizes integrative metagenomics to characterize the interplay between vaginal viral and bacterial communities, how they are shaped by contraceptive use, and how these dynamics may alter HIV acquisition risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is devoted to novel ion chemistries and instrumentation for mass measurement and structural characterization of intact bio-polymers and their complexes. Emphasis is placed on the gas- phase attachment of multiply-charged ions of selected mass and charge to oppositely-charged ions derived from complex bio-polymer mixtures, including heterogeneous complexes, such as molecular machines and viruses. This effort addresses key limitations in the current state-of-the-art in top-down proteomics and native mass spectrometry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic/Latino sexual minority men are disproportionately impacted by methamphetamine use and HIV, yet represent an understudied population. This study is designed to test a social-ecological model that examines the effects of intersecting drug use stigma and sexual minority stigma on drug use and HIV vulnerability among Hispanic/Latino sexual minority men. This project aims to advance HIV prevention research and inform multilevel stigma reduction interventions to reduce the burden of HIV in this critical population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The blood vessels in the lungs are severely affected in the presence of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), the virus that causes AIDS. This leads to serious illnesses in the lungs and in the heart and we still do not know how HIV causes or contributes to these severe pulmonary vascular diseases. Here we are proposing experiments to understand how HIV molecules change the way that lung molecules interact so that we can propose novel therapies to prevent lung diseases in people with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We developed a novel therapeutic tuberculosis (TB) vaccine that potentiates the efficacy of the traditional, prolonged TB treatment. With the mechanistic studies described in this proposal, we will dissect the multifaceted immune response to TB, offering shorter treatment and alternative options to standard TB treatment when adverse drug reactions, resistance, recurrence, or treatment failure complicate clinical management, especially in high-risk populations, including patients living with HIV. Understanding how our TB therapeutic vaccine works can serve as proof-of-concept for targeting other key TB-related enzymes and treating other chronic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trichomonas vaginalis (TV) is the most prevalent non-viral sexually transmitted infection globally, is associated with a number of adverse health outcomes, and has received comparatively little public health attention. We propose to examine the natural history of TV across the lifespan by characterizing the epidemiology, assessing risk factors associated with TV susceptibility, and profiling the local and systemic (immune/microbiota) effects of TV infection by life stage and HIV status. This work will shed light on the reasons for the curious bimodal age distribution in TV prevalence, the mechanisms by which the parasite induces disease and, ultimately, contribute to understanding the disproportionate adverse health outcomes in women of African descent and in the Southern United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Health Relevance While current anti-HIV therapeutic agents contribute to the effective suppression of HIV-1 in patients, actual choices for long-term treatment are rather limited due to viral escape, cross-resistance, and toxicity, demanding discovery of newer and safer classes of anti-HIV agents. This application focuses on developing a new class of safe and potent anti-HIV agents that specifically target HIV-1 integration and maturation, which can contribute to more effective long-term suppression of HIV-1 and ultimately HIV-1 cure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: With the ongoing scale up of Dolutegravir (DTG), an integrase strand transfer inhibitor antiretroviral treatment, in Sub-Saharan Africa, weight gain has been noted in postpartum women living with HIV. How maternal DTG impacts the physiology of maternal and infant body weight regulation has not been studied. In a cohort of maternal-infant dyads from Uganda, we propose to study how DTG-based regimens affects energy intake and expenditure along with biological measures of appetite and metabolic pathways relevant in weight regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Immunity to enveloped, RNA viruses that utilize a trimeric-protein-spike, Class I membrane-fusion cellular invasion mechanism maps to host antibodies targeting the apex of the influenza and SARS-CoV-2 viral spike. In this exploratory project, we will investigate whether equivalent antibody-targeted epitopes at the apex of the HIV/SIV viral spike can mediate a similar level of protection from viral challenge, a level which has been elusive for HIV vaccine candidates for nearly 40 years. This hypothesis will be tested by engineering a vaccine containing only the two key spike-apical, antibody-targeted epitopes and testing it in a non-human primate model of HIV/SIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Despite the advent of antiretroviral therapy, HIV positive patients continue to have changes in the white matter of the brain, especially in myelin, the lipid membrane formed by oligodendrocytes. Myelin is necessary for the propagation of nervous impulses and the protection of the nerves. Our studies address the effects of HIV infection and the antiretroviral drugs used to treat HIV on the development and function of the oligodendrocytes and the myelin sheath.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microglia mediate chronic neuroinflammation during HIV that contributes to the development of neurologic dysfunction in up to 50% of people living with the virus, which is a major public health issue. We propose to leverage the anti-inflammatory potential of the endocannabinoid system, through pharmacologic agonists and the phytocannabinoid cannabidiol, to suppress this deleterious response in HIV-infected and uninfected microglia. Coupled with my mentorship and training goals, successful completion of these activities will propel me forward in accomplishing my long-term goal of becoming a public health research scientist working at the intersection of HIV and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The leading infectious cause of death for people living with HIV is tuberculosis (TB), and unfortunately even when HIV is controlled and TB is cured, people with both HIV and TB have a four times higher death rate than people with HIV who never had TB. We think this may be because TB changes how immune cells in the body are infected with HIV, so this research will study how many and what kind of immune cells are infected with HIV when people also have TB. This may help us to understand how to cure HIV when people have both HIV and TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This research project proposes to study the intersection of how a post-translational modification, ADP- ribosylation, which is vital for processes related to transcription, chromatin activity, and the cellular stress response, may be altered during HIV-1 reactivation. The project is of great interest to the HIV-1 community as it may reveal novel targets for latency reversing agents in eradicating latent HIV-1 in CD4+ T-cell populations. This project is directly related to NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge in understanding and treating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Molecular effects of cannabinoids on the Blood Brain Barrier in HIV-infected brain  The HIV infection causes significant disease morbidity in the brain, largely associated to blood-brain barrier (BBB) disruption, inflammation, and persistence of HIV-infected CNS target cells such as long-living microglia, in spite of antiretroviral therapies (ART). We found that cannabis use modulate the expression of BBB integrity markers in a context-dependent manner, increasing signs of BBB disruption in non-HIV subjects, but paradoxically improving BBB integrity in PWH. This observation motivated an in-depth examination of how cannabinoids impact BBB integrity, with consequences to inflammatory cell transmigration and protections against HIV-infection in the brain, by modeling the human BBB in vitro and in vivo systematically testing critical determinants, cellular interactions and targets, which can be used to inform mechanisms and new approaches aimed at optimizing BBB integrity in the context of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scalable behavioral interventions that improve depressive and anxiety disorders and PrEP uptake are urgently needed for gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (GBMSM), who are disproportionately affected by common mental illnesses and HIV globally. The proposed K01 supports the candidate's transition to an independent investigator focusing on adapting and evaluating scalable interventions that integrate mental health and HIV services in community clinic settings for GBMSM in low- and middle-income countries. The knowledge and skills gained from training, in addition to findings from the proposed research, will inform future intervention strategies to reduce the global burden of common mental illnesses and HIV for sexual minority men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: II. PROJECT NARRATIVE With HIV outcomes improving, the incidence of AIDS declining, and the life expectancy gap between people with and without HIV decreasing, the focus of HIV research and treatment should shift away from AIDS and mortality towards non-AIDS comorbidities and quality of life. This work assesses the cost-effectiveness of HIV care in two large single-payer systems while focusing on non-AIDS comorbidities and quality of life. We develop a machine learning application to aid researchers in measuring quality-adjusted life-years in the absence of quality of life survey data, develop a novel model of HIV progression to aid clinicians in predicting and preventing high risk non-AIDS comorbidities, and inform Department of Defense and Veterans Health Administration policy makers whether it is more cost-effective to retain PWH in the DoD or transfer them to the VA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRATIVE Although medications that inhibit the spread of HIV are effective, many people who take these drugs for a long time experience problems with memory and other brain functions. We have recently developed a new way to study how the activated parts of the animal brain are connected into networks. We now plan to use this approach to investigate which brain regions in mice infected or not infected by HIV1 are affected by the anti-HIV drugs and how these regions are connected. By studying the changes in the brain networks of animals treated with these medications, we hope to gain a better understanding of the cognitive side effects of these drugs. This research could help us find ways to reduce or prevent these side effects in people which take these drugs as prophylaxis or in people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite 40 years of active research, the biochemical and biophysical processes that underlie the nuclear import of HIV genomic material remain obfuscated. This project aims to characterize the binding between the HIV capsid protein and the critical cellular factor CPSF6, which licenses the capsid for nuclear import. These studies will provide new understanding of HIV biology and potentially a new interface of the HIV capsid that could be targeted for rational drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative HIV infection induces lung inflammation and bacterial dysbiosis, which leads to the increased risks of chronic lung diseases in people living with HIV (PLWH). Our knowledge about interplay between HIV-associated immune dysregulation and the lung microbiota is limited. This proposed study will use an advanced humanized mouse model to better understand HIV-driven lung inflammation and microbial changes and promote mechanical studies to develop better procedures for screening, preventing, and treating lung diseases in PLWH.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT The Bahamas has responded to its formerly high rates of HIV infections with a broad and aggressive HIV/AIDS prevention program including children in the school system. We have worked with them to develop and test the effectiveness of one such HIV prevention program (FOYC+CImPACT) among grade six students. The grade six program was shown to be very effective through a study that followed the students for three years after they had received the training. Therefore, the Ministry of Education (MOE) of The Bahamas decided to mandate the use of FOYC+CImPACT throughout all government grade six classes in The Bahamas. Over the past decade, the research team partnered with the Bahamian Ministries of Education and Health to utilize two national implementation programs to study teachers’ fidelity of implementation and theory-driven implementation strategies to increase teachers’ continued implementation of evidence-based interventions. Our decade-long nationwide implementation research provides a unique opportunity to investigate the trajectories and determinants of sustainability for HIV behavioral interventions. This study will provide valuable information to all countries and communities struggling to prevent their youth from becoming infected with HIV and doing so in a manner the country/community can afford to sustain. This information will also answer questions about maintaining the effectiveness over time of other prevention programs that are incorporated into school curricula.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative HIV and malaria continue to place a tremendous burden in sub-Saharan Africa. The current treatment landscape for both diseases is changing with the near universal transition to dolutegravir for HIV, and the emergence of artemisinin resistance. Through the establishment of four hree longitudinal cohorts in Uganda, we will assess the impacts of dolutegravir on weight gain and metabolic derangements, the magnitude and impact of drug-drug interactions between dolutegravir and leading antimalarial regimens, and finally assess the pharmacologic predictors of resistance selection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The female reproductive tract (FRT) microbiome consists of the bacterial microbiome, which can protect against pre-term birth, bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted infections including HIV, and the viral microbiome, which includes bacteriophages who, as natural predators of bacteria, may serve to regulate bacterial populations. Our prior work showed the FRT bacteriophages form communities which corresponded with FRT diseases; however, the mechanisms behind bacteriophage contribution to regulating FRT bacterial populations is largely undetermined. Using a unique longitudinal cohort comprised of US women living with HIV and AIDS compared to healthy controls, we will investigate the FRT bacteriophage communities over time, the impact of AIDS and antiretroviral therapy on FRT bacteriophages and bacteria, and identify bacteriophage species and genes that predict shifts to pathogenic FRT bacterial microbiomes, which may lead to novel preventative strategies and phage-based therapeutics for FRT diseases, thereby improving women’s reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Criminal justice-involved women, who are predominantly African American, are among the highest risk women in the U.S. to acquire HIV with few having access to effective HIV prevention medications called HIV pre- exposure prophylaxis or PrEP. Formerly incarcerated community health workers can link criminal justice involved women to community medical care by addressing re-entry barriers to care such as housing, unemployment, and lack of transportation. This study aims to improve the feasibility of an innovative criminal justice woman focused PrEP care linkage program utilizing the formerly incarcerated community health workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a cancer-associated pathogen that often drives tumor formation in persons living with HIV-1/AIDS. Herein we seek to decipher critical sites of vulnerability on the virally encoded gH/gL glycoprotein complex and leverage this information to develop vaccines that prevent EBV infection and/or tumor development. This work could lead to the development of a vaccine that eliminates the burden of EBV- driven lymphomas that prevail where HIV-1 is endemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: This project aims to investigate how alcohol potentiates HIV-associated neuroinflammation involving the inflammatory mediator, the inflammasome NLRP6, that is primarily expressed in the brain astrocytes, in the context of both HIV and the comorbidity of alcohol use. The mechanism(s) underlying this interaction remains poorly understood. Findings from this project could set the stage for the future development of targeted adjuvant therapeutics aimed at mitigating neuroinflammation in people living with HIV with alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative A vaccine that will be effective in preventing HIV infection and also control virus replication once the virus has taken hold, will require a dual barrier. The first one at the mucosal portal of entry for the virus to prevent or at least minimize the ability of the virus to create a beachhead and two at the systemic level where generalized immune responses are able to control virus that has succeeded in overcoming the first barrier. Our vaccine strategy targets renewable colorectal epidermal stem cells as a permanent source of antigen production which proliferate and elaborate the vaccine antigen along the phases of the reproductive cycle, providing repeated bouts of vaccine antigen presentation as the cells mature and cycle, leading to induction and maturation of humoral and cellular immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection and methamphetamine use are known to impact brain structure and function and that this may have implications for brain health and aging. This K01 application will use data science methods to calculate estimated brain age from structural and functional neuroimaging data in people stratified by HIV infection and methamphetamine use histories in association with inflammatory biomarkers. This project will have clinical relevance by determining whether HIV infection and methamphetamine use impact brain aging, and whether this is associated with inflammation, thereby having a profound impact on both current treatment applications and future brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Metabolic and cardiovascular complications of HIV and antiretroviral therapy are leading causes of premature aging associated with long-term HIV disease. This proposal will use advanced strategies for high-throughput screening and subsequent chemical optimization to identify and characterize novel highly selective chemical probes to a validated therapeutic target that has so far proven challenging, despite strong rationale. Altogether, this proposal aims to address the significant unmet clinical need for new and more effective therapies to ameliorate HIV- and ART-associated metabolic complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it can potentially address gaps in current prevention of maternal-to-child transmission programs in sub-Saharan Africa, where nearly 140,000 infants are perinatally infected with HIV each year. We hypothesize that the innovative strategy of training traditional healers to deliver HIV counseling and rapid HIV testing in their communities can increase testing among children who have not received the World Health Organization recommended HIV testing. We propose formative qualitative work to guide adaptation of an evidence-based HIV testing intervention that will meet the unique needs of children and their caregivers (Aim 1), and then to pilot test this intervention at five traditional healer practices among 200 children aged between 18 months to 5 years old (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative This proposal develops the next generation of an anti-PD-1 chimeric antigen receptor T cell approach which cleared germinal centers of signs of T follicular helper cells and associated viral replication in the non-human primate model of lentiviral infection, albeit increasing extrafollicular viral replication due to depletion of PD-1+ CD8+ memory T cells. While exciting, additional safety features need to be implemented in this approach to make it clinically useful and it is arguably easier to engineer greater safety than to develop other approaches. By integrating more sophisticated genetic circuits and programmable control mechanisms into the current anti- PD-1 CAR platform, targeted depletion of TFH cells is improved, thereby providing foundational knowledge to enable further studies towards the role of TFH cell depletion for an HIV cure in the nonhuman primate model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative People living with HIV (PLWH) are three-four times more likely to be depressed in their lifetime than HIV- people, yet there are few studies of the neuropathology of depression in PLWH. This proposal explores neural and inflammatory mechanisms of depression in PLWH by using task- based and resting state fMRI to measure the activation and functional connectivity of brain networks related to Negative Valence and emotion regulation. Neuroimaging measures are related to regulatory and peripheral measures of inflammation to identify individual differences associated with the underlying neuropathological mechanism of depression in PLWH compared to HIV- people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Increasing the coverage of HIV testing and access to HIV prevention such as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) among men at high risk for HIV remains crucial for improving men’s health outcomes and reducing HIV risk among their female partners. This study seeks to develop and pilot test integration of secondary distribution of HIV self-tests by female sex workers (FSW) to their male clients as an entry point to generate demand for PrEP, followed by an FSW-led intervention to address ongoing structural, interpersonal, and individual-level barriers to promote PrEP initiation, adherence, and persistence among male clients of FSW.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will define polydrug overdose mortality rates for four key target populations of patients either engaged in health care, privately or publicly insured, or recently released from prison; will define clinical predictors of polydrug overdose mortality risk; will identify prescription opioid pain management trajectories associated with polydrug overdose in longitudinal cohorts of pain patients; and identify pathways to polydrug use and overdose.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-22-011: Risk and Protective factors of Polydrug Overdose in North Carolina

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the recurrent exposure of wildland firefighters to elevated levels of wildland fire smoke, knowledge about the respiratory effect of such exposure and respiratory protection to reduce the exposure are lacking. Therefore, the proposed study will investigate: 1) the long-term respiratory effects of recurrent occupational exposure to wildland fire smoke, and 2) assess the effectiveness of the situational use of an air purifying respirator (APR) during peak wildland fire smoke concentration at reducing exposure. These objectives will be determined respectively by investigating: 1) changes in subclinical markers of respiratory disease development across the wildland fire season, and 2) reduction in the cross-shift increases in biomarkers of exposure and wildland fire smoke associated effects in the respiratory airways and blood corresponding to the situational use of the APR during work at prescribed burns.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Chronic Respiratory Effect and Control of Occupational Exposure of Wildland Firefighters to Smoke
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative By training predoctoral students to translate research findings into policy-relevant messages, this project will expand access to scientific information on demographic processes, social and behavioral aspects of reproductive health, and population health. Increased access to such information contributes to the development of better social and health programs that ensure that every person is born healthy and wanted, that women suffer no harmful effects from reproductive processes, and that all children have the chance to achieve their full potential for healthy and productive lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This program will investigate the means by which metalloenzymes and transition metal complexes interact with reactive, or, “fixed” nitrogen species. Key research directions include understanding how organisms use fixed nitrogen species as part of their primary cellular energy transduction metabolisms. Reactive nitrogen species such as nitric oxide play vital roles in human health, in particular in controlling vasodilation––understanding how these species are generated and interconverted may help develop new therapeutic strategies for cardiac- related pathologies and for combatting infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The Smidt Heart Institute at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles is renewing its Institutional Training Grant to support its Advanced Heart Disease Research Training Program. The objective of the program is to provide outstanding team-mentored training in basic biomedical, translational, and health services research to both PhDs and MD-scientists in order to provide them with the necessary skills to develop independent and productive academic careers in cardiovascular science. These future leaders of medicine will be well-equipped to develop new, more effective treatments for diseases of the heart and blood vessels such as heart attack, heart failure, high blood pressure, and sudden death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Our PO1 program has the ambition to position anti-glycan antibodies as a therapeutic alternative and/or complement to the current limited chemical arsenal of antibiotics. High affinity anti-glycan antibodies will be produced and characterized by a complementary expert group of chemists, bacteriologists, immunologists, and structural biologists with a focus on Staphylococcus aureus. Preliminary data, including in vivo studies, attest of the pertinence and feasibility of the project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: This PPG will develop a mechanistic understanding of how the TIGIT/CD155 and PD-1/PD-L1 coinhibitory pathways interact with each other to maintain tissue tolerance in the clinical context of autoimmune diseases and cancer. This new knowledge will further the development of novel strategies for manipulating coinhibitory pathways to stimulate or inhibit immune responses in specific diseases that can translate to novel human immunotherapies. Specifically, the translational goals are to develop novel strategies to treat autoimmunity and cancer, and to limit tissue inflammation associated with adverse autoimmune events observed with cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to accomplish a comprehensive analysis of the transcriptional and immune function of PADI4, which my data indicate is a key target gene for p53-mediated tumor suppression. I expect the proposed research to impact our understanding of PADI4 and histone citrullination in cancer, as histone citrullination is among the most understudied histone post-translational modifications. Understanding the role of PADI4 in tumor suppression and the p53 pathway will provide crucial insight into cancer risk and could point toward novel therapeutic targets in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has been proposed to interact with specialized niches within the bone marrow microenvironment as a means to resist chemotherapy. The goal of this work is to to determine the single-cell composition of human bone marrow, ascertain whether residual AML cells reside in a protective endosteal niche, and find if transcriptional changes incurred by AML cells over the course of therapy mediate their interaction with specific niche cell populations. Collectively, this work will improve our understanding of the microenvironmental contribution to AML chemoresistance, which will help nominate novel therapies that target sources of protection for AML within the bone marrow niche.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Arteriovenous fistulas (AVFs) are the preferred type of vascular access for hemodialysis, and surgical creation of AVFs is the current gold standard, yet many surgical AVFs fail to mature for use. Endovascular AVF creation, a novel percutaneous (non-surgical) method to create a vascular access, was recently approved by the FDA. The goal of the proposed research is to establish a solid foundation for the design and conduct of a randomized clinical trial to compare the clinical and economic impact of endovascular AVFs and surgical AVFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative It is well established that Ewing sarcoma is driven by a fusion oncogene, EWSR1-FLI1, however the biology of this oncogene is poorly understood. In our prior work we identified that EWSR1-FLI1 dysregulates a fundamental process, transcription, causing an increase in R-loops. While R-loops serve normal functions, high levels of R-loops are considered deleterious and are often associated with genome instability and a loss of cellular fitness. The mechanism of how Ewing sarcoma is able to maintain high levels of R-loops without genomic instability is not known. If we can determine this mechanism, then we should be able to specifically target it as an alternate therapy for the treatment of Ewing sarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have achieved, in nonhuman primates and initial clinical trials, induction of transient hematopoietic chimerism and long-term I.S. free renal allograft survival, following combined kidney and BM, MHC mismatched transplantation. The proposed research studies will evaluate novel conditioning modalities using Bcl-2 and Mcl-1 inhibitors in place of irradiation or chemotherapy. We anticipate this will provide safer and more effective recipient conditioning, which will make this tolerance strategy available to many more transplant recipients, including those receiving organs from deceased donors. Our NHP model has proved to provide strong correlations with subsequently observed outcomes in humans. Thus we anticipate the results of these studies will be directly applicable to clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) remains a leading cause of cancer death in the United States. The objective of the Rural Community Support for Colonoscopy project is to test the effectiveness and study the implementation of a patient navigation program for increasing colonoscopy completion in rural populations with a positive fecal immunochemical test (FIT) result. The findings from this study will advance our knowledge of the effectiveness of patient navigation in this patient population and will guide future implementation and dissemination of the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative VCPIP1, an anti-tumor target and a deubiquitinase in the DUB OTU family, is abundant in many cancers and can be characterized using structural biology methods. Using structure-based drug discovery (SBDD) methods, I propose to utilize the unknown structure of VCPIP1 in complex with VCP to help optimize inhibitor activity within the drug discovery process. I expect this to make a profound impact in therapeutics and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Uncontrolled hypertension has been associated with numerous effects on health resulting in a poor quality of life or even a fatal heart attack or stroke, $131 billions of dollars in national healthcare expenditures and worse outcomes that are most severe among the poor, disadvantaged, and racial and ethnic minorities such as refugees and immigrants. Since nothing is known about how refugees with hypertension manage their condition at home, we will look into barriers to that and feasibility of interventions to self-manage their hypertension as a critical step to the adaptation, implementation, and evaluation of evidence-based interventions that empower refugees to engage in self-managing their cardiovascular disease risk. In addition, the proposed project will allow the candidate to master a complex set of research skills in the development of novel hypertension interventions, and develop topical expertise required to fully characterize hypertension management challenges and intervene to reduce cardiovascular disease risk by researching special patient populations that are understudied and suffer disproportionately from hypertension, generating knowledge that can be applied to many other patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Co-occurring and mutually exclusive patterns of cancer-promoting mutations reveal context-dependent effects of driver alterations in tumorigenesis. This project seeks to investigate the paradoxical effects of the frequently inactivated gene SETD2 in KRAS- and EGFR-driven lung adenocarcinoma. Understanding the mechanism of SETD2's relationship with each oncogene will identify targetable therapeutic vulnerabilities in human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aphasia is a common and debilitating communication disorder caused by damage to the language regions of the brain, most often from stroke. Although impairments in the production of naturalistic language, such as conversational speech, are ubiquitous in aphasia and of high priority for rehabilitation, there remains a lack of understanding about which brain regions are associated with impairment and how performance improves over time. The proposed project will address these limitations in the current literature by leveraging a novel measure and applying it to a large and ongoing longitudinal study, with the goal of building an explanatory brain- behavior framework that advances our understanding of naturalistic language production in aphasia and meaningfully informs clinical management practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Multiple modifiable barriers cause race- and location-based disparities in accessing and receiving evidence-based, guideline-concordant care among patients with foregut cancers. This proposal uses a mixed methods approach to identify these barriers from the perspectives of patients, caregivers, and medical stakeholders, as well as from electronic health records. This information will be used to develop a clinic-based screening tool to identify patients at risk for for non- receipt of guideline concordant therapy, thereby enabling the effective allocation of resources and interventions to improve care for patients at greatest risk for disparities in care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) is a deadly pediatric brain tumor for which no curative treatment option currently exists. This proposal will explore developing splice-modulating antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) to skip the exon that contains the H3.3 K27M mutation found in 70-80% of DIPG patients, leading to disrupted translation of the disease-defining mutant protein with the potential to reduce tumor burden and prolong survival. Knowledge gained from this proposal will advance our understanding of molecular targets in DIPG, potentially offer a new therapeutic option for further clinical drug development, and provide justification for use of antisense oligonucleotides in the treatment of genetic disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance In this renewal application we propose the continued development of the Drug Dependence Epidemiology Training (DDET), a program to support pre- and post-doctoral training in substance use and substance use disorders. Our goal is to increase the number and quality of health professionals who apply expertise in epidemiology, biostatistics, prevention science, and services research to substance use research use research. We have a demonstrated commitment to enhancing diversity within the drug research community, as well as special emphasis in training on: HIV and Hepatitis C, epidemiological and statistical methods, social and structural factors, psychiatric disorders, and emerging issues, such as overdose prevention and SARS-CoV-2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: A major contributor to altered gene expression and chromatin reorganization in endocrine-related cancers is nuclear receptor signaling. Hormone therapies are currently the cornerstone of treatment for most patients, however, a deeper understanding of nuclear receptor regulation of epigenetics will help combat tumor recurrence and therapeutic resistance. The proposed work will not only add depth to our current understanding of nuclear receptor biology, but also advance our ability to effectively treat hormone-dependent cancers with therapies that target nuclear receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of the short term research training program is to increase the number of optometrists who will do rigorous basic, clinical and translational research on normal vision and vision disorders. The program provides the initial step toward this goal by providing optometry students with an intensive exposure to research for twelve weeks early in their professional training. We aim to motivate talented optometry students to continue reseach training at the MS or PhD level, to include research in their careers, and to contribute to improvements in vision care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This is a training grant proposal for interdisciplinary training of predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows in skin biology. The goal is to train future skin biologists who will use multidisciplinary approaches to tackle diseases of the skin, a high priority for NIAMS. The training has implications for skin diseases with barrier dysfunction, wound healing, vascular lesions, and pigment cell diseases such as vitiligo, melasma, nevi and melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a global public health crisis that specifically impacts the health of synapses, the nodes at which neurons connect to one another to form networks in the brain. Early traumatic brain injury (TBI) is the best-established environmental risk factor for AD, but the structural and mechanistic connections between TBI and AD are largely unknown. This study seeks to characterize synaptic neurodegeneration resulting from TBI and determine its connection to AD, which may help identify new targets for treating neurodegeneration and for preventing acute brain injuries from progressing to dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) is the leading infectious disease killer worldwide and a leading cause of death among people with HIV. While it is well established that in areas with rifampin-resistant or multidrug-resistant TB (RR/MDR-TB) HIV increases the number of RR/MDR-TB cases, it remains unclear if HIV impacts the transmission and evolution of RR/MDR-TB. This research project will integrate epidemiologic, clinical and genomic data to characterize HIV- mediated transmission and evolution of RR/MDR-TB in the Western Cape Province, South Africa.

PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulation of histone methylation has emerged as a major cause of neurodevelopmental disorders including intellectual disabilities and autism spectrum disorders. While histone methylation plays important roles in any cell types, the proposed study is designed to identify methyl-histone regulations that are unique to neuronal cells. The obtained knowledge may be used to form the basis upon which abnormal methyl-histone regulations can be selectively targeted in the brain without affecting other organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Smoke-free public housing policies have been mandated by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). However, our work suggests these policies are considered to be so unfair by residents that compliance is severely undermined, with potentially negative unintended consequences. Our goal is to verify how these policies can be harmful and propose adaptations to increase their effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections require long and onerous treatment: antibiotic regimens that could clear infections more quickly would improve patient outcomes. This proposal seeks to determine how Mtb battens down the hatches of its cell wall during stress, thus increasing antibiotic tolerance. This work will characterize some of the molecular mechanisms responsible for treatment recalcitrance in Mtb, and will lay the foundation for future screens for anti-tolerance drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Exposures to deprivation (e.g., hunger) and threat (violence) during mid-to-late adolescence impact the mental and physical health of youth; however, we need more information on how potentially modifiable factors affect the impact of such exposures. The CAMINANDO-MH study examines the impact of exposures to threat and food deprivation on the mental health of 400 Latin American teens who migrated to the US as unaccompanied adolescents. We will follow them over 18 months to assess how psychological, cognitive, and social factors (e.g., daily stressors, supports) affect their mental health trajectories to clarify how to improve their outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Antibiotic resistance is an increasing problem especially in gram-negative bacteria where the permeability barrier created by the outer membrane (OM) excludes many antibiotics; yet, although a barrier, the pathways responsible for synthesizing and transporting OM components are potential targets for the development of antimicrobials that can weaken the OM. Our proposed study will investigate the biogenesis of a conserved component of the cell envelope of Enterobacterales, enterobacterial common antigen (ECA), which has functions in maintenance of the OM permeability barrier. The knowledge of ECA biogenesis gained through our work will facilitate functional studies of ECA and identify potential targets for antimicrobial small molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Paternal mitochondrial elimination and radiation-induced bystander effects are two vitally important, distinct, and dynamic biological processes essential for stress response, normal cell functions and organismal development. Defects in these two processes can cause multiple human diseases, such as inherited human mitochondrial diseases. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms that regulate and execute these two fundamental biological events and identify new genes and pathways important for these two processes, leading to identification of new therapeutic targets or ideas to treat human diseases caused by abnormalities in paternal mitochondrial elimination and improve disease treatment by reducing side effects caused by radiotherapy and other therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Proper regulation of cell division during the process of making a sperm or egg (termed meiosis) ensures that these crucial cells inherit the correct genetic material. Errors in this process lead to genetic abnormalities, pregnancy loss, and developmental defects. The overall goal of this proposal is to understand the regulation of meiotic cell division, with a focus on mechanisms underlying preferential inheritance of certain chromosomes over others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Summary Research on human health has fundamentally changed in the last 20 years. Modern genomics and proteomics technologies have carefully characterized health-related events, which has opened the door to asking more complex questions about normal and disease states. Correspondingly, to confront complex research challenges, the career opportunities to Ph.D. scientists have diversified, including multiple non-academic positions (e.g., industry, biotechnology, government, publishing). Along with this research progress and changing career landscape, the biomedical culture has placed greater emphasis on quantitative data analysis, rigor and reproducibility, and transparency to ensure quality and accuracy of research findings and safety to minimize risk to scientists and the environment. To take advantage of this unprecedented opportunity to thoroughly dissect biological systems with high standards of rigor and many career perspectives, a biomedical work force capable of multi-disciplinary, team-driven, and problem-focused thinking is needed. In total, this modern world of biomedical research requires a rethinking of the Ph.D. training experience. To address the changing needs in biomedical work force training, we have created a Chemistry Biology Interface (CBI) training program at Wayne State University (WSU). WSU has the ideal campus environment for a scientifically rigorous and culturally rich training experience. CBI faculty among six departments and three colleges offer a wealth and diversity of research expertise for graduate training. WSU has in place a series of professional development activities to augment career preparation. The diverse undergraduate population at WSU also synergizes and supports an equally diverse graduate community. Building upon these strengths, the CBI program will augment the graduate training within core disciplines by promoting multi-disciplinary research knowledge and collaboration facilitated by cross-campus mentoring and peer-to-peer advising. These outcomes will be achieved through a series of CBI activities that center around an individualized “My Ph.D.” theme. The foundational activity is an annual "My Ph.D." workshop focused on career skills surveying, assessment, and planning, which will be led by CBI student peers and faculty for multi-level mentoring. Complementing the individualized skills evaluation, multi-disciplinary research, scientific rigor, communication skills, and peer cohort building/networking will be accomplished through annual CBI symposia, biweekly seminar activities, a team- taught and literature-based CBI course, a co-mentoring Ph.D. committee structure, early and sustained academic advising, internal and external research experiences (ATTRACT), and community outreach events (ACT OUT). Through these meaningful activities, WSU Ph.D. graduates will form a strong scientific identity with discipline-specific skills and informed multi-disciplinary perspectives. The combination of research breadth, skills depth, and enhanced mentoring facilitates the confident, solution-oriented, and collaborative thinking needed to address complex biological questions and migrate through a diverse career backdrop.
PI_NAMEs: CHOW, CHRISTINE S;PFLUM, MARY KAY H (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: Biology;Chemistry;Training Programs;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: Chemistry Biology Interface Training Program at Wayne State University
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - B[TWD-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the most commonly diagnosed and deadliest cancer in the world, accounting for over nearly one-fifth of all cancer deaths in 2018 and the 5-year survival rate for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is only 18.1%. The current proposal will focus on the link between cancer redox metabolism and DNA damage repair/signaling as a means to provide a mechanistic understanding of metabolic vulnerabilities of tumors with the goal of enhancing tumor cell responses to radio-chemotherapies. Overall, I believe that this F99/K00 award will provide the means for me to utilize my skills as a redox biologist in order to establish a research career focused on cancer cell redox metabolism and DNA damage repair/signaling in tumor cell responses to radio- chemotherapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Academic researchers with a focus on infectious diseases have contributed to the elimination, prevention and control of diverse infections that cause substantial morbidity and mortality in children, including smallpox, polio, meningitis, measles, malaria, diarrhea, and AIDS. Despite substantial progress, both long-standing (e.g., diarrheal illnesses) and emerging infectious diseases (e.g., SARS-CoV-2) continue as leading causes of death and disability to children in the US and globally, especially among children under 5 years of age. The goal of this proposal is to train committed individuals to perform needed and groundbreaking research on the prevention and treatment of infections that afflict children, and to enable these researchers to focus their careers on improving the health of children everywhere.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Increases in computational power and data availability have facilitated development of advanced statistical methods and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, powerful tools for knowledge discovery and facilitating clinical decision making, but have also made evident the existence of biases and blind spots, both implicit and explicit, in both data and models. As such, fairness, interpretability, and reproducibility are among several emerging areas in need of research both in computer science and biomedical informatics. This project will focus on developing a novel fairness metric and new machine learning techniques for real-time clinical decision support in the critical care and ICU settings to address issues of health diversity, equity, and inclusion through the use of fair machine learning algorithms to appropriately handle missingness and bias in clinical data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein synthesis is a major pathway targeted by antibiotics, and the rise of multi-drug resistant bacteria calls for further understanding of the translational machinery to improve current antimicrobial treatment. Our work will provide insights into adaptation of such bacterial pathogens during stress conditions and facilitate development of novel antimicrobial strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will characterize genome-scale patterns of DNA methylation and gene expression in blood samples from African American participants in the Detroit Neighborhood Health Study, a population-based study of mental disorders among adult Detroit residents. Analyses will target brain-related epigenetic variation, measured in blood, and will test the effects of social context, both positive and negative, on DNA methylation and gene expression levels, and their relation to risk for post-traumatic stress disorder. Results from this study will provide a deeper characterization of how social exposures, both positive and negative, influence brain-related epigenomic processes to impact stress-related psychopathology among Africa Americans, an under-studied U.S. minority group with substantial health disparities in traumatic-stress related psychopathology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Depression causes serious difficulties with everyday functioning. For the 20 to 50% of depressed patients who fail to respond adequately to medications and psychotherapy, repetitive pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is an important treatment alternative. RTMS benefit depends on placing the TMS coil in the correct place on the head to reach critical brain regions below. Several researchers, including our lab, showed that for a third of patients, the standard clinical practice used to determine coil placement location did not position it above the correct brain region, and patients failed to respond. We propose to test the accuracy of a different method of locating the coil placement on the head, called Beam F3. We will use functional MRI to identify brain regions predicted to improve functional outcomes in depressed Veterans (at Palo Alto VA) and also test whether accurate stimulation leads to better functional outcomes in patients undergoing rTMS therapy (at Providence VA). If successful, results will support improved patient outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will enhance both the effectiveness and uniformity of the National Molluscan Shellfish Safety Program by improving the flow of information between federal and state regulatory agencies, industry, and consumers. The project will strengthen state activities by providing assistance in such areas as procedural and policy guidance, technical training, research, consumer education, and conformity with requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program (NSSP) Model Ordinance. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The inability of antiretroviral therapy (ART) to clear HIV infection and the observation that a sterilizing cure and/or stable remission can be achieved by a subset of ART-treated persons has galvanized interest to advance clinical strategies towards a cure and/or stable remission. Including scientists from 12 institutions and 9 industry partners, the BEAT-HIV Delaney Collaboratory will seek to develop and test innovative combined immunotherapy strategies to permanently suppress and/or eradicate HIV in the absence of ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal disease affects more than half of people aged 18 and over, and nearly three out of four aged 65 and over. There remains a disconnect between the needs of mechanistic researchers and clinicians who treat musculoskeletal trauma, disease and associated sequelae in the patients of today. We propose that a training program designed for co-mentoring of predoctoral students in an environment and culture providing strong transdisciplinary support for clinical and mechanistic research in musculoskeletal health will result in a new generation of researchers who can develop and implement novel strategies to describe and combat diseases of the musculoskeletal system in the near and far term.
