IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Blood flow is critical to the function of every organ yet the fundamental mechanisms regulating blood flow remain unclear. We have mapped the arterial system of the mouse and identified specific expression of the ion channel TRPV1 in the vascular smooth muscle that encircles the small arterioles of the heart, skeletal muscle, and adipose tissue. We will test the hypotheses that TRPV1 regulates rapid changes in arterial caliber, that the underlying mechanism involves a temperature and phospholipase C dependent pathway, and that adaptations to TRPV1 in arteries enable the persistent activation required for tone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by formation of fibrotic lesions in the lung, eventually resulting in scarring and progressive loss of lung function, and despite some newer treatments patients still have a median survival rate of only 3-5 years once diagnosed. Inhalation of exosomes derived from stem cells offers a promising therapeutic strategy by promoting endogenous repair and mitigating pulmonary fibrosis. Here in this proposed study, we plan to establish the therapeutic role of lung stem cell-derived exosomes in treating pulmonary fibrosis and determine the active principal microRNA contents in the exosomes that responsible for the regenerative activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Typhoid fever is an infectious disease caused by Salmonella Typhi (S. Typhi), a bacterium that causes as many as 20 million new infections and 600,000 deaths annually. Asymptomatic chronic carriers of S. Typhi play a major role in the transmission of typhoid fever, as they intermittently shed the bacteria and can unknowingly infect surrounding individuals. This study aims to characterize novel compounds that target biofilm formation, a process utilized by S. Typhi to establish and maintain chronic carriage in the gallbladder, so that they may be eventually used to prevent and/or cure chronic infections more efficiently than ineffective single antibiotics.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will equip me with the necessary skills to examine the underuse of genetic services among African American women at high risk for breast cancer and to identify tools that may increase diffusion of knowledge of genetic counseling among high-risk populations. This project is relevant to NCI's goal of ensuring that a diverse pool of highly trained scientists is available in appropriate scientific disciplines to address biomedical, behavioral, social and clinical research needs in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The fact that therapies based on the Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 (GLP-1) pathway and that genetic variation in the GLP-1 receptor lower both fasting and postprandial glucose concentrations has been relatively overlooked. In addition, there is increasing evidence that GLP-1 is synthesized in the endocrine pancreas and supports islet function. We propose a novel series of experiments to understand how endogenous fasting GLP-1 secretion could influence subsequent responses to hyperglycemia in the presence and absence of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative ADPKD, caused primarily due to PKD1 mutations, is a common genetic disorder. We will test if improving the translation of mRNAs produced by the non-mutated PKD1 copy is a new therapeutic opportunity for ADPKD. Our studies will also provide a scientific roadmap to develop PKD1-boosting drugs for ADPKD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Levothyroxine is widely prescribed to treat hypothyroidism, though no clinical trials have been performed to assess treatment goals in older people. The proposed clinical trial will examine the clinical consequences of allowing greater flexibility in levothyroxine dosing in older people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The visual system has a remarkable ability to adapt to altered environments, not only sudden changes in light intensity but also the long-term changes in seasonal light periods. Such adaption is supported by structural plasticity of photoreceptors that involves two important cellular stress pathways, the Unfolded Protein Response and autophagy, with both of them linked to numerous diseases ranging from neurodegeneration to cancer. This proposal combines biochemical and genetic approaches to define the role of a candidate regulatory kinase that potentially reveals a novel layer of regulation in the maintenance of visual processing in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pneumonia remains the leading infectious cause of death. Presently doctors do not know which patients can benefit from steroids, when to give steroids, or how much steroid to give. In this application, we propose an approach to steroid use in pneumonia that considers an individual’s unique features, seeking to give the right dose of steroid to the right patient and at the right time.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is the number one infectious disease killer in the world. Altering mitochondrial homeostasis has been repeatedly associated with susceptibility to Mtb and exacerbation of Mtb pathogenesis. By understanding how crosstalk between Mtb virulence factors and mitochondria influences immune outcomes, we might one day be able to therapeutically target mitochondria as part of tuberculosis patient treatment plans.

PHR: Dysfunctions of decision making are core characteristics of various mental illnesses such as addiction, major depression and eating disorder. Here, we seek to develop and apply novel technologies in spatial single-cell omics and in vivo tracing and imaging to determine the neural basis of decision making. These studies will uncover fundamental insights into the brain mechanisms underlying the debilitating cognitive impairments associated with mental disorders and provide translational inroad for the intervention and treatment of these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My career goal is to become a cancer researcher leading a program focused on the translation of evidence- based genetics applications such as family cancer history (FCH) collection to improve risk-stratified cancer prevention and early-detection in low-resource settings. In the F99 phase, I will complete my dissertation research focused on identifying factors influencing collection of FCH, while gaining skills in social network data analysis. During the K00 phase, I will extend this research and training by: 1) building knowledge of human centered design to incorporate F99 findings about determinants of FCH collection into an updated FCH tool, 2) becoming an expert in implementation science through the deployment and evaluation of a FCH intervention in community health settings, and 3) enhancing skills to prepare for an academic research position.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cyclic nucleotide-gated (CNG) channels are essential for vision and olfaction. Numerous genetic mutations in these channels cause debilitating visual disorders such as retinitis pigmentosa and achromatopsia. Obtaining high-resolution structures of wild-type and mutant CNG channels in different states and carrying out structure- guided functional studies is crucial for understanding how these channels are controlled by cyclic nucleotides and how disease-associated mutations disrupt channel function, and for developing appropriate treatments for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is the most widespread tick-borne viral disease in humans with case- fatality rates of 10–40%. Here we propose to employ structure-based vaccine design principles to engineer immunogens that induce cross-reactive protective antibodies. Our studies will provide insight into the structures and antigenicity of CCHFV glycoproteins and will deliver a bona fide vaccine candidate against a NIAID Category A pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Large segments of current US middle-aged adults are suffering and doing more poorly than earlier-born cohorts and these trends are distinct to the US, compared to other Asian and European nations. Despite known differences between the US and other nations, little research has examined the mechanisms underlying diversity in midlife development and individual-level characteristics that either magnify or mitigate differences. Our objective is to use the HRS family of studies to identify the intergenerational, financial, and health behavior mechanisms driving diversity in midlife development of health, well-being, and cognition and shed light on individual-level characteristics that can promote resilient outcomes and inform future prevention, policy, and intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: With ~560,000 Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients and >4 million residents >65 years old, Florida is, and will continue to be, an epicenter of the AD epidemic in the United States. Notably, impressive gains in our understanding of AD pathogenesis have not yet translated into disease-modifying therapies that benefit patients; thus there is huge unmet medical need. The 1Florida ADRC’s global mission is to work with other ADRCs and stakeholders in the AD field to help change the understanding of AD and related dementias (ADRDs) to a new reality in which ADRDs are more facilely and accurately diagnosed, more effectively treated and ultimately preventable or curable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The innate immune system restricts the growth of invading bacteria by limiting access to essential nutrient metal ions (nutritional immunity) and by production of antimicrobial peptides and enzymes that attack the cell envelope. Using Bacillus subtilis as a model system, we characterize the bacterial stress responses elicited by metal ion limitation and excess, and by antibiotics that interfere with integrity of the cell envelope. The resulting insights are relevant for understanding the mechanisms that allow bacterial cells (both beneficial and harmful) to adapt to the host environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because up to sixty percent of arteriovenous fistulas created in hemodialysis patients in the United States fail to mature for successful dialysis use. This project aims to improve the understanding of the mechanisms of arteriovenous fistula maturation failure and develop nanomedicine to treat this important clinical problem. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge to help reduce morbidity and mortality for patients on hemodialysis requiring a vascular access.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposed study, we will use longitudinal data from rural Malawi to examine the effect of marriage on mental and physical health and test whether differences exist by sex and age, i.e., across the life course. We will account for selection into (re)marriage and dissolution by controlling for unobserved characteristics that likely affect both marital status and health and will also consider how marriage patterns, customs, and norms in this context affect this relationship. Ultimately, we will create the first population-based longitudinal dataset on marriage and health in sub-Saharan Africa, which will be the first to include complete marriage histories, detailed measures of health, information for spouses, migration history, HIV/AIDS infection, gender attitudes, and women’s autonomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project utilizes synthetic chemistry, microbiology, genetics, and proteomic methods to develop novel compounds to combat bacteria. This research will develop narrow-spectrum and antivirulence tool compounds as potential therapeutic agents that either inhibit growth or biofilm processes within pathogenic bacteria. The compounds are derived from natural product scaffolds isolated from regions rich in chemical diversity and bioactivity, which will undoubtedly shed light on the chemical underpinnings of these complex microbial communities.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post-COVID-19 syndrome is frequent in COVID-19 survivors regardless of acute disease severity. Cognitive impairment, a severely disabling manifestation of post-COVID-19 syndrome, poses particularly difficult challenges for our aging veteran population. Identifying markers of risk for cognitive decline after COVID-19 is crucial for developing effective prevention and treatment strategies. This project will characterize changes in cognition and brain imaging over time and will confirm the association between a platelet biomarker and future risk of cognitive dysfunction after recovering from COVID-19, resulting in better medical care, improved quality of life and decreased financial burden for the VA.

PHR: Narrative: Etv4 and Etv5 are required for normal limb, testis, kidney and motor neuron development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment of opioid use disorder with the medication buprenorphine reduces risk of opioid overdose mortality, but poor retention in care limits this medication’s protective effect. This proposal will use large observational data to examine the relationship between buprenorphine dosage strategies and retention by: 1) describing current buprenorphine dosage practices in terms of dosage trajectories, 2) comparing the effect of two distinct buprenorphine dosage strategies on retention, and 3) estimating the impact of improved buprenorphine dosage practices on retention and overdose for the state of Massachusetts. This proposal has the potential to identify improved buprenorphine dosage strategies that increase retention in care, a key pillar in reversing the opioid overdose epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromogranin A (CgA), the most ubiquitously distributed protein in the hormone-producing cells in our body, is overexpressed in patients with neuroendocrine and non-neuroendocrine malignancies, heart failure, renal failure, liver dysfunction, hypertension, and numerous autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease as well as in the brains of Alzheimer’s disease patients, implicating that excess CgA is toxic to many cellular activities. We found that lack of CgA in a mouse model caused marked improvements in the age-associated increase in blood pressure and diabetes with consequent increase in healthy lifespan. This proposal will use a transdisciplinary approach to uncover if CgA is a risk factor for aging by analyzing the lifespan of CgA knockout mice and whether removing CgA from adult animals will help ameliorate aging associated development of inflammatory disorders like diabetes and hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narratives  The liver transplant (LT) program for acute alcoholic hepatitis (AH) at Johns Hopkins provided a unique opportunity for us to create a clinical resource that now serves the alcohol research community and facilitates access to otherwise unavailable specimens. We propose to continue meeting investigators’ current and increasing needs and liberally provide our resource to the entire alcohol research community. Hopefully, given the enhanced efficiency of collaboration, a nationwide team can make progress towards better care and therapeutics for this difficult patient population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social isolation and loneliness have risen at alarming rates among young adults, placing this cohort at heightened risk for poor physical and mental health, especially in populations that already face higher burdens of disease. We propose basic experimental research on social connectedness to discover whether, how, where, and for whom health communication, optimized for social media, can ameliorate social isolation in these at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pressure Sensitive Adhesives For Use in Thoracic Surgery PROJECT NARRATIVE A pleural fistula, or opening between the pleural cavity and lung parenchyma or airway, originates from injury or locally invasive cancer. Closure of alveolar- and broncho- pleural fistulae remains a serious surgical challenge with high morbidity or death, and one where new biomaterial-based adhesives are needed. The performance and evaluation of novel biodegradable, biocompatible pressure sensitive adhesives, with tunable adhesion strength, is described for in vivo closure of pleural fistulae despite an inherent pressure gradient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Retinal degenerations are a major cause of blindness in developed countries, producing signiﬁcant disability and burden to public health; developing therapies is a key goal for the National Eye Institute. The most promising (and still experimental) therapies, aimed at replacing the lost photoreceptors by either stimulating regeneration of the retina or by cellular transplantation, are still unsuccessful and have exposed gaps in our knowledge about the mechanisms that control the normal integration of photoreceptors into functional retinal circuits. This proposal aims to discover and study such mechanisms, with the aspiration to apply this knowledge to the development of therapies for retinal degenerations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysregulation in the activity of mitochondrial inner membrane proteases are implicated in the pathologic mitochondrial dysfunction associated with multiple diseases including many neurodegenerative disorders. However, the molecular mechanisms responsible for the regulation and activity of these proteases remain poorly defined. Here, we employ a combined structural and functional genomic approach to determine how inner membrane proteases perform the diverse biological functions involved in regulating mitochondria to reveal new insights into the pathologic and potentially therapeutic implications of altered protease activity in the context of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While bacteria are single-celled organisms, biofilm communities exhibit multicellular behaviors that allow individual bacteria to resist antibiotics and survive in harsh environments. The goal of this MIRA proposal is to uncover how emergent metabolic coordination and cell-to-cell signaling give rise to these collective behaviors in biofilms. This proposed work is relevant to the NIH because it will reveal new ways to target the unique properties that make biofilms resilient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic minority children who live in socio-economically disadvantaged communities are disproportionately impacted by pandemic and climate-induced disasters. Although effective interventions have been designed to treat mental health related symptoms in post-disaster settings, accessible, empirically supported prevention interventions are needed to prevent the onset of mental and behavioral health issues among these children. Building on our preliminary findings, the proposed study examines the efficacy and implementation of a COVID-19 adapted disaster focused prevention intervention, Journey of Hope-C19, in preventing behavioral health and interpersonal problems among racial and ethnic minority children who live in low-resource high poverty communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified a class of microbial metabolites, present within the intestine, that potently represses functions of Salmonella required for this pathogen to colonize and cause disease. We aim to identify the bacterial sources of these signals within the gut microbiome and to characterize their global effects on Salmonella virulence functions. This work is innovative and impactful as it investigates a novel means to reduce the public health threat of salmonellosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative This project will use individual-level administrative Medicare data to estimate the short- and long-run effects of natural disasters such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and floods on health, health care use, and health-related expenditures among the elderly and people with long-term disabilities. The project will also assess several mechanisms that could moderate or exacerbate post-disaster mortality and disease impacts, including disruptions in continuity-of-care and characteristics in areas to which victims relocate following a disaster.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE_OVERALL Pneumonia is the most common cause of death from an infectious disease worldwide and disproportionately affects the elderly. Most elderly patients survive pneumonia, but they have an increased chance of developing ongoing lung inflammation, skeletal muscle dysfunction and cognitive decline. We show that metabolic interventions that restore proteostasis in older animals can accelerate recovery after pneumonia with implications for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity in childhood is highly prevalent and associated with increased risk of cardiovascular disease, asthma, diabetes, certain cancers, and poorer quality of life. Despite much national attention and research, the prevalence of obesity continues to rise, and disparities persist, suggesting a large gap between research and practice. We will evaluate the dissemination and implementation of a proven-effective intervention for childhood obesity to accelerate the intervention’s adoption in different settings serving populations disproportionately affected by obesity and improve population-level outcomes in obesity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that there are very few proven treatments for unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss, uncovering genetic mechanisms is crucial for identifying individuals at risk and initiating targeted, patient-centered treatments. The proposed work will provide unprecedented machine learning analysis to define the spectrum of genomic and clinical indicators for recurrent pregnancy loss, unparalleled molecular phenotyping through metabolomics and single cell RNA sequencing, and development of a publicly-available “intolerome” database which will provide the foundation for a future prenatal OMIM.

PHR: The long-term goal of this project is to deepen our understanding of the role of  peripheral monocytes and microglia in Parkinson’s Disease (PD) and to identify  myeloid-related targets for treatment of the disease. If successful, discoveries from this  study will provide a foundation for more ambitious plans to identify potential mechanisms and  modulating factors for the increased risk of PD. Our proposed work may explain the causes of PD and  have the potential to lead to new therapeutic targets for PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA), which affects more than 3 million Americans and totals billions of dollars in socioeconomic costs, is typically initiated following an injury to the knee, followed by joint instability, which then progresses to a state of excruciating pain and limited mobility. Despite the huge impact of osteoarthritis on American society, there have not been significant breakthroughs in the treatment of this disease. Our aim is to provide an injectable solution for the treatment of PTOA, through the fabrication of super-lubricious microspheres loaded with a concentration of bioactive molecules, namely platelet-rich plasma, capable of modifying the local inflammatory response, stopping the degeneration and initiating regeneration of articular cartilage, ultimately restoring joint homeostasis and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed study in Ugandan children aims to understand how some children with severe malaria experience an abrupt loss of kidney function while sick and do not recover normal kidney function. Poor kidney health places children at higher risk of repeated kidney injury and poor health, leading to repeated hospitalizations. This study may identify medicines that can help kidneys recover from injury and lead to improved long-term recovery and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Ebola virus disease (EVD) is one of the world’s most feared infectious diseases and represents a growing public health threat with increasing frequency and size of outbreaks. Despite the growing number of survivors (>17,000 at present) with increased size of outbreaks and the provision of better care, little is known about the durability of the immune protection against repeat infection or what drives the clinical complications that threaten their functional capacity. We seek to better understand the protective and pathogenic effects of the EVD survivor immune system to inform approaches to the clinical management of post-EVD complications and provide insight into the immunity of EVD survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal will determine the previously biophysical signals that control histone-modifying complexes during the normal immune response and how somatic mutations of histone-modifying enzymes reprograms B cells to undergo malignant transformation by disrupting these signals. Based on functional studies, he will identify and test the efficacy of epigenetic- targeted drugs that counteract the effect of these mutations on the epigenome and sensitize lymphomas to other targeted agents and immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a common gynecologic condition that may increase a woman’s risk for cardiovascular disease later in life. Using data from the Utah Population Database and the NICHD ENDO study, we propose the largest and longest study on this topic to investigate the association between endometriosis and risk of clinical and subclinical cardiovascular disease, taking into account sociodemographic characteristics and reproductive history. Understanding these associations will help improve the identification of women who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease, which may allow for early interventions and ultimately reduce morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phosphate impacts nearly every aspect of human biology, but how our body senses circulating phosphate levels is unknown. The recent finding that the kidney releases a molecule that regulates phosphate levels provides an important clue that phosphate sensing may occur in the kidney. This proposal will study how and why phosphate specifically activates this process in the kidney, with the goal to enhance our fundamental understanding of human physiology and to provide new treatment targets in kidney, bone, and vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment, a clinical symptom of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) is common among adults living with CKD; however, this condition is understudied compared with other clinical endpoints associated with CKD. Prior work has shown that urine biomarkers of kidney tubule injury and dysfunction are associated with worse cognitive function independent of eGFR and ACR, however, the relationship is likely more complex than what can be identified through a few targeted biomarkers. The objectives of this proposal are to use large-scale proteomics to 1) identify protein clusters and biological pathways that associate with CI among adults with CKD in the Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC), 2) identify a parsimonious panel of proteins that predict CI by testing penalized variable selection methods in adults with CKD in CRIC, and 3) identify whether aims 1 and 2 externally validate using the Cardiovascular Health Study with the ultimate long- term goal of detecting potential drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The parasympathetic and sympathetic arms of the autonomic nervous system play critical roles in regulating energy storage and expenditure. This proposed project aims to understand the mechanisms by which the adipose hormone leptin regulates plasticity in the autonomic innervation of organs involved in energy balance; specifically, in adipose tissue and the pancreas, by building on our recent discovery that leptin regulates sympathetic innervation plasticity in fat. Understanding these mechanisms will enable the identification of targets that can directly modulate innervation and hence the energy regulating function of these organs, forming a foundation for new therapies to treat obesity and diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Longitudinal lung function in asthmatics is a critical risk factor for future exacerbations, chronic airway obstruction, morbidity and mortality. MicroRNA sequencing, metabolome-wide profiling, full exome sequencing, and genome-wide genotyping provide ideal data to increase our understanding of lung function decline from DNA variant to transcriptomic regulation to metabolic alterations to disease pathophysiology. Capitalizing on the rich resources available via the Mass General Brigham Biobank, we will create a cohort of asthmatics with multi-omic data to identify and validate integrative-omic blood biomarkers of lung function trajectory that inform on the fundamental underlying biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The combined prevalence of overweight and obesity in youth with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is now greater than the prevalence of combined overweight and obesity in youth of the general population, and increased weight in youth with T1DM increases risk factors for cardiovascular health problems. This K23 project will adapt an established behavioral weight management intervention for adolescents with overweight/obesity for a T1DM population. Study results and the Candidate’s training plan will inform a larger efficacy trial evaluating this novel evidence-based behavioral weight management intervention for adolescents with T1DM and overweight/obesity and will launch the Candidate’s career as an independent clinical investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Sphingolipids are a class of fatty molecules that have been thought to serve primarily as structural molecules in formation of cell membranes. Our work identified specific functions for individual sphingolipids, thus leading to their appreciation as `bioactive molecules', and in this proposal we focus on key enzymes of sphingolipid metabolism with important functions in cell stress responses. In the process of defining these pathways and mechanisms, we tackle some of the most recalcitrant problems in understanding these pathways, and we provide the foundations that allow many investigators to probe the health and therapeutic significance of the enzymes and pathways we are defining.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vaccines offer the greatest potential tool to provide protection against malaria and to maintain gains in malaria control and ultimately move to elimination. However, a lack of understanding of how immunity naturally develops in children living in high burden areas has severely limited our ability to develop an effective malaria vaccine. The central theme of this proposal will be to improve our understanding of factors driving the development of naturally acquired immunity in Ugandan children by studying infecting parasites and the host response in detail as immunity develops.

PHR: NARRATIVE Blinding diseases are some of the most devastating health concerns in the United States. This training program seeks to produce independent investigators capable of sustaining productive, innovative, independent research programs in the vision sciences. These new scientists are expected to generate discoveries in the underlying mechanisms of vision and associated pathologies, and to help develop treatments for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will elucidate the mechanisms by which gene expression, controlled by the nervous system through TFEB, confers protection against chemical and microbial inflammation. The proposed work has great potential to accelerate the development of innovative therapies that target the Brain/TFEB axis to treat infectious and inflammatory diseases. The proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Infectious Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) causes an exuberant inflammatory disease of the lung, with limited treatment options and an unacceptably high mortality. Our group has identified new therapies for ARDS, focusing on a specialized immune cell, the regulatory T cell (Treg) with the capacity to promote resolution of lung injury in preclinical models of disease. Collectively our preliminary data in mice, cells, and humans support a model that estrogen receptor beta (ER) agonists have therapeutic effects, via Tregs, in pneumonia-induced ARDS and can promote resolution of lung injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will investigate the role of small non‐coding RNAs, termed microRNAs, in the regulation of sodium (Na+) transport in the distal kidney nephron. We will investigate the hypothesis that the mineralocorticoid hormone, aldosterone up-regulates the expression of specific miR clusters in the distal kidney nephron which feedback to negatively alter Na+ transport. We will test this novel function of microRNAs in Na+ homeostasis using control mice and a nephron-specific microRNA knockout mouse model that will be subjected to aldosterone stimulation and changes to renal Na+ handling will confirm that these microRNAs are acting as a negative feedback regulators of aldosterone signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative  After intracerebral hemorrhage, clearance of the hematoma is essential for better restoration of brain function as this cleanup process is accomplished by brain microglia and blood-derived macrophages (M, phagocytes) and during clearance of the hematoma components, M produce massive quantities of bilirubin (BrB, a yellow pigment) by converting heme from the hematoma. BrB is an antioxidant, but due to its poor water- solubility, will form intracellular precipitates when it accumulates, which alters biological membranes and DNA, leading to M dysfunction; however, BrB activates the transcription factor (aryl hydrocarbon receptor [AhR]), to enhance production of proteins essential for preventing bilirubin precipitation, as well as other proteins that benefit M involved in hematoma resolution. Therefore, we will evaluate AhR as a new target for hemorrhage therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: TCR-T Cell therapy is a promising adoptive cellular therapy modality for solid tumors, but a main barrier is the disarmament and suppression of the engineered T cells by the fibrotic tumor stroma. In the current study, novel microphysiological tumor stroma niche models will be developed to investigate the interaction between TCR-T cells and the fibrotic stromal factors with and without the combination of anti-fibrosis therapies. The study results will help the designs of anti-fibrosis therapies and future fibrosis-targeting T cells and directly benefit the ongoing clinical study on T cell therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Acetaminophen (APAP) and analgesic products comprised of APAP and opioids are frequently abused and misused, a characteristic of the current prescription drug problem in the United States. Novel data from our laboratory has shown that APAP can alter expression of blood-brain barrier (BBB) tight junction proteins complexes and lead to paracellular “leak.” This grant proposal will study BBB changes in critical TJ proteins (i.e., claudin-5, occludin) expression and trafficking induced by APAP (both by itself and in in vivo models of acute/chronic pain), work that will directly impact public health in the United States by uncovering mechanisms of adverse drug events that can occur in individuals who abuse or misuse APAP and/or pharmaceutical products containing APAP.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The rete ovarii is a conserved epithelial structure that develops in parallel with the ovary during fetal life and remains closely associated with the adult ovary. This research will elucidate the precise nature and functions of the rete ovarii and its contribution to female reproductive longevity. This project will establish an integrated approach, all the way from 3D images to molecular signatures at the single cell level, which will enhance our understanding of the nature and importance of interactions between the ovary and extrinsic associated tissues, including the rete ovarii, for ovarian functions and fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE People with end-stage kidney disease may experience moderate to severe pain as a result of the inability of their kidneys to filter toxins that cause inflammation, and for many pain persists after restoration of kidney function following kidney transplantation. We all coexist with trillions of bacteria and other microbes, collectively known as the microbiome, that live in communities on and within the human body and make chemicals that reduce or exacerbate pain through the brain-gut-microbiome-axis. The goal of this study is to better understand how the communities of microbes, and the chemicals they produce that may affect pain, change after kidney transplantation, and how these changes affect pain over time in order to develop patient-centered treatments for pain by manipulating the microbiome through diet, stress reduction, and or supplementation with pre/probiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress urinary incontinence is an extremely prevalent condition that affects women throughout their life, resulting in tremendous negative impact on quality of life and incurring an enormous economic burden. There is an urgent need to identify the precise tissue- and cell-level events that lead to stress urinary incontinence that will inform the development of new therapeutics. Our deployment of a novel biomaterial-based strategy in an animal model of stress urinary incontinence is expected to shift the current paradigm of delayed and compensatory treatments towards more effective preventive and therapeutic measures, improving women's health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The major source of melanoma deaths is metastatic disease, largely due to the fact that while tumor removal  and therapies look promising for patients in the beginning, a large subset of patients will have tumor cells that  have left the primary tumor site and are in a state of ‘dormancy’ in other organs, which remain resistant to these  therapies and are unable to be detected by clinicians. We have uncovered a receptor called the MER tyrosine  kinase receptor that when expressed in dormant melanoma cells, results in their ‘reactivation’ and drives  aggressive tumor growth in the lung. We propose to study how these ‘reactivated’ melanoma cells secrete  soluble proteins into the lung to stop our immune system and other healthy cells such as fibroblasts from targeting  melanoma cells for destruction, and how this process can also lead to resistance against targeted and  immunotherapies, with the hope of finding pathways that can be targeted clinically for translational therapies  against dormant and reactivated metastatic melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Infection by emerging viruses, such as SARS-CoV-2, HIV, influenza, dengue and Zika viruses, poses a major challenge to global health. This study will delineate the molecular mechanisms of how infected cells detect RNA virus infection and initiate signal transduction to induce antiviral defense mechanisms. Furthermore, this study will give detailed insights into innate immune evasion by SARS-CoV-2 and other coronaviruses, which may ultimately contribute to the establishment of novel therapeutic approaches for virus-associated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precisely controlled formation of myelin on central nervous system axons is essential for motor and intellectual function. The long-term goal of this project is to understand how oligodendrocytes, which are glial cells of the central nervous system, form specific amounts of myelin on select axons during development. Completion of the project aims will substantially extend our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which myelin membrane is produced and modified by brain activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A precision approach to management of type 2 diabetes (T2D) involves using information about an individual’s genetic profile and underlying disease pathophysiology to match the right drug to the right patient. This project aims to identify the genetic predictors of response to glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1 RAs), a relatively new but increasingly common medication for T2D, through using a genome-wide association approach in several biobank-linked electronic health records and conducting a pharmacologic drug perturbation study. If successful, the proposal will generate evidence for genotype-guided therapeutic selection and improve the understanding of drug mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Perception of speech is remarkably robust even in the presence of competing background noise, yet this ability is compromised for the elderly and subjects with hearing loss. This study will explore how the auditory system is able to hear and recognize sounds in the presence of competing natural noises. This knowledge is critical to identify neural mechanisms that endow normal hearing abilities and to develop future interventions to diagnose and treat hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US opioid epidemic persists, with left-over pills prescribed for post-surgical pain being a major source of misuse and diversion. Building off promising pilot data, we now propose a large prospective cohort study of a novel opioid-dispensing system, comprised of a password-protected dispensing device, a smartphone app for clinical guidance, and a mail disposal procedure. This intervention is designed to reduce misuse and diversion of post-surgical opioids by promoting disposal of unused pills and reducing unnecessary consumption without compromising pain control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative At least 1.4 million adults in the United States have type 1 diabetes, and the incidence is increasing by 2-5% per year. Diabetic kidney disease is common in people with type 1 diabetes, can progress to kidney failure requiring dialysis or kidney transplantation, and markedly augments risks of cardiovascular disease and premature death. This project will determine the role of perturbed energetics and hypoxia in diabetic kidney disease in order to identify novel and specific targets for kidney disease prevention and treatment in type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospital visits are important opportunities to start treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD) with evidence-based medications, but this only improves outcomes if treatment is continued in the community. The present study proposes to develop and test strategies that improve transitions of care following hospitalizations for patients with OUD, which has the potential to impact public health by increasing the connection of patients to lifesaving care. The implementation mentorship, training, and research activities will inform future studies to improve both efficacy and of care for patients with OUD and set the stage for a larger-scale trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic minorities are more likely to experience high intensity, non-beneficial, burdensome and expensive care at end-of-life despite the fact that the majority of these patients prefer to die at home. The roles of perceived discrimination and lack of trust and how these factors affect communication and decision- making around the care one receives at the end of life are not understood. Understanding these associations will contribute important knowledge toward the development of interventions to improve communication, patient-reported outcomes, and goal-concordant care in patients who endorse experiencing perceived healthcare discrimination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Gender diverse youth have a gender identity that differs from their sex assigned at birth, and this at-risk population has improved health outcomes when they feel affirmed or supported by their parents. This study will survey a diverse cross-section of parents about the factors associated with being affirming and will develop an online intervention that connects them with other parents for mentored peer support. By assessing feasibility and acceptability of the new parent support intervention, this work will inform future research aimed at improving health outcomes for gender diverse youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The blood contains free-ﬂoating DNA from cells throughout the body, and when cancer is present, some of this free-ﬂoating DNA comes from cancer cells. This makes it possible to detect cancer from a routine blood draw, however, advanced statistical techniques are needed since this requires the detection of weak signals in large quantities of complex data. The purpose of this project is to develop statistical methods and software tools for this task, with the goal of enabling accurate and noninvasive early cancer screening.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE / PROJECT NARRATIVE End stage renal failure represents a massive health care problem for the United States, affecting 650,000 Americans every year, and having a mortality associated with dialysis of 65% within 5 years. $42 billion is spent annually for hemodialysis. Kidney transplantation dramatically reduces the cost of caring for such patients and improves their lifespan. Improving the outcomes of kidney transplantation and prolonging the survival of transplanted kidneys and patients is a major public health goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: In 2020, over 70,000 people died from opioid overdoses, and aversive conditions are a key contributor to opioid use and cravings. While the context that opioid use occurs in perpetuating use, the neural basis of contextual memory processing with opioids is poorly understood due to a lack of understanding of the underlying neurobiology. The goal of this proposal is to dissect the dynamics of two key molecules dopamine and norepinephrine in the dorsal hippocampus providing new insights to mechanisms that regulate opiate abuse disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The metabolism, storage and flux of lipids in the liver plays a central role in starvation, diet-induced obesity, diabetes and Nonalcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH) among others, however, the mechanisms governing the shift from normal metabolic physiology to pathophysiology are poorly understood, particularly with respect to the role of lipid metabolism. Our overall hypothesis is that cellular lipid catabolism represents not only a critical metabolic endpoint in the liver, but also serves as an important signaling node in nutrient sensing that is regulated at multiple steps during the oxidation of fatty acids. Defining this communication and better understanding hepatic lipid metabolism in general may lead to novel therapeutic interventions for obesity, diabetes and NASH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on understanding the size, stability and sex-based differences of the myeloid (monocyte and macrophage) reservoir in HIV. Ultimately, this proposal will help to determine if HIV establishes true latency in cells of myeloid origin, and whether this cellular reservoir has the potential to derail T cell focused cure-based efforts in HIV. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that is focused on research to find a cure for HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Resistance to treatment and lack of targeted treatment options for KRAS mutations are two major clinical challenges in lung cancer therapy. A common link to these two problems is the activation of Mcl-1, a major antiapoptotic protein that is overexpressed in human lung cancer. Studies in this project will develop a novel Mcl-1 inhibitor with the goal of overcoming treatment resistance and treating lung cancer with KRAS mutations, which will have substantial impact for a large subset of patients with lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Currently, there are no accurate nonanimal tests to identify consumer products and chemicals that require labeling to advise users to wear protective eyewear and avoid eye contact due to the threat of serious eye damage. The purpose of this application is to further develop and commercialize a new nonanimal test — the in vitro depth of injury eye irritation test (IVD EIT) — to identify this class of ocular irritants and thereby allow for adequate labeling that will advise and inform users about product safety as well as comply with new laws preventing or limiting the use of animals that have been historically used for this type of routine safety testing. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Universal Test-and-Treat (UTT) represents the world’s best chance to end the HIV epidemic; yet research on UTT impact in South Africa is limited. We constructed a National HIV Cohort from the complete laboratory records of South Africa’s HIV treatment program, covering over 4000 facilities. Integrating this cohort with treatment monitoring data, we will evaluate the national impact of UTT and identify where in the UTT care cascade patients are lost to follow-up, in order to guide the next phase of South Africa’s HIV response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The use and abuse of prescription opioids in females of reproductive age has dramatically increased over the past two decades. One consequence of this escalated use has been an upsurge in the number of babies born with opioids in their bloodstream, many of whom develop neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. The goals of the current set of studies are to address this public health issue using a preclinical model of oxycodone self-administration in female rats which will allow us to investigate neurodevelopmental modifications and adult outcomes associated with maternal opioid intake.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since the rapid drop in cost for genome sequencing, the field of genomics has experienced a bottleneck in computationally trained scientists capable of interpreting and transforming this data into actionable information to improve human health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Noroviruses are a leading cause of gastroenteritis worldwide, yet there are no approved therapies or vaccines available. This proposal seeks to understand how a class of antiviral restriction factors regulate the ability of noroviruses to infect specific cells, tissues, and species. This work will enhance our understanding of norovirus biology and pathogenesis and could reveal new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Public Health Impact Preventing high school dropout, juvenile justice involvement, and early parenthood for those youth most at risk within urban environments is challenging. Experimentally testing the impact of a long-term professional mentoring program in a randomized controlled trial on these three outcomes can inform us of the impacts of such programs. Should this approach demonstrate strong evidence related to these outcomes, mentoring programs such as Friends of the Children may play an important preventive role reducing health disparities among “high-risk” individuals and their communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Disorders of growth plate chondrocyte maturation impact the growth of the skeleton, resulting in a spectrum of diseases from skeletal dysplasia to extreme short stature. These diverse conditions underscore the importance of tight regulation to normal physiology, yet the genetic pathways involved are poorly understood. By identifying new functional genetic mediators of growth plate maturation, I hope to gain new insight into how these diseases develop and establish targets for the design of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  People with both vision and hearing loss have increased difficulties in daily functioning. Very little attention has been paid to the rehabilitation challenges faced by this large and increasing population. This project will investigate the impact of combined vision and hearing loss on the difficulties of this group in spatial localization, that is, in the ability to determine the direction of sounds and sights of objects in the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance The proposed work aims to expand and unify our lab’s projects surrounding a rapid evolution system called OrthoRep, pioneered by my group over the past several years. Using OrthoRep, we will address a range of important problems in biomedical research. These include the engineering of enzymes to cheaply synthesize drugs and commodity chemicals, the creation of better gene therapy tools and therapeutic proteins, and the design of new technologies for studying developmental processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority women (SMW) are at disproportionately high risk of both sexual assault and its resulting adverse mental health sequelae, but we know little about the upstream social determinants that contribute to this mental health disparity. Guided by an innovative, theoretically-grounded intersectional model, we propose to conduct the first direct test of the association of geospatial climates (e.g., municipal and state policy, SMW community presence) with SMW’s lived experiences of minority stress and mental health following sexual assault recovery. Results will inform clinical interventions and public policy advocacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The Somali American immigrant community has high risk for obesity, hypertension, metabolic syndrome and diabetes, all of which are frequent comorbidities of deficient sleep, including short sleep duration, obstructive sleep apnea, and insomnia. We plan to examine the likelihood, types and severity of disrupted sleep in Somali Americans, identify mechanisms that may be causing the sleep deficiency, and explore how the sleep problem may be leading to increases in daytime and night time blood pressure. These findings will address important knowledge gaps in understanding health and disease in Somali immigrants, and provide actionable insights to help in preventing any future epidemic of cardiovascular and metabolic disease in this relatively young population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legionella pneumophila is an infectious bacterium that causes Legionnaire’s disease and remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the immunocompromised such as the elderly. Caspase-11 is a component of a process (non-canonical inflammasome) which allows clearance of Legionella by phagocytic cells called macrophages. How caspase-11 regulates a cascade of events leading to bacterial clearance and the molecules involved in this cascade will be investigated in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increasing evidence suggests that early life and reproductive events, as well as exposures during pregnancy, may have long-term impacts cardiovascular and lung health of women and their children but most cohorts are not well equipped to support research addressing these questions. We propose to strengthen the shared infrastructure necessary to support research aimed at identifying intergenerational, reproductive and early life risk factors for CVD (CHD, stroke) and obstructive lung disease (COPD and asthma) in three cohorts – the Nurses’ Health Study II (NHS-II), the Growing Up Today Study (GUTS) and the Nurses’ Health Study 3 (NHS3) – by focusing in four areas: 1) the maximization of existing resources, 2) the collection of biological specimens and in-person measurements of blood pressure and anthropometric data, 3) the expansion of web-based mobile technology and “Big Data” capabilities for the cohorts, and 4) strengthening our capability for data sharing. The ability to combine biomarker data, state-of-the-art mobile high-resolution measures, and traditional epidemiologic risk factor data, collected across generations and throughout the life-course in three related cohorts will enable us and others to conduct powerful etiologic and translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE This study will contribute to public health knowledge of the effects of Medicaid MCO coverage and utilization management design on access to OUD treatment, and the effects of Medicaid enrollees’ OUD treatment receipt within MCOs on adverse outcomes, namely opioid-related emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and mortality. The study will provide tangible guidance to states and Medicaid MCO plans regarding how to best structure coverage and utilization management parameters to ensure appropriate and efficient access to opioid use disorder treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some of the most common oral diseases are typical examples of mucosal polymicrobial infections. This study will use oral bacteria as a model system to investigate how different species of the human flora can synergize to cause disease as well as identify potential mechanisms to inhibit this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This pilot study will support the feasibility and safety of conducting a large multi-center randomized controlled trial comparing patient-directed antimicrobial treatment duration to a fixed indication-specific duration using an oral 3rd generation cephalosporin for outpatient treatment of women with acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis (AUP). Patients will discontinue therapy upon symptom resolution, which may result in less antibiotic exposure, fewer adverse events, and decreased promotion of antimicrobial resistance. This project potentially will have a significant impact on not only patients being treated for AUP but on how infectious diseases are treated generally, reversing a decades' old approach to prescription of antimicrobial therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal aims to investigate the dynamics of burst-like β-frequency (15-29Hz) events in the human neural field potential in relation to both healthy and abnormal motor control. β-band activity is a key signature of both pathological and normal movement in humans, but recent high-impact work has shown that existing research mischaracterized the burst-like nature of this signal, casting doubt upon established relationships between β-activity and movement. This proposal aims to systematically investigate whether burst-like β-activity reflects specific inhibitory control functions in the human motor system, thereby motivating a novel, detailed, neurophysiologically grounded understanding of motor control in both health and disease.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Atherosclerosis, obesity and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) mediate increased risk for cardiovascular disease. This Program Project will probe the effects of caloric restriction, LXRα phosphorylation, Netrin1 and its receptor network and RAGE/DIAPH1 in these pathologies. The Program Project will discover mediating mechanisms and identify therapeutic targets for, ultimately, clinical trials in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study aims to develop a high-throughput screening method to map noncoding functional elements important for regulation of alternative splicing. Disruption of these splicing-regulatory elements has been implicated in an expanding list of human genetic diseases and modulation of splicing has arisen as disease modifying therapeutics. Results from this study may provide tools and resources to better understand disease mechanisms and develop potential therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Insight into gene regulatory mechanisms will be sought through studies of RNA polymerase pausing, transcription termination, translation control, and RNA binding proteins in Bacillus subtilis and Escherichia coli. Proper regulation of gene expression is of paramount importance for the function of cells in all organisms. As several human diseases arise in part through inappropriate gene expression, these studies will contribute to improving human health by providing a detailed mechanistic understanding of how genes are regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Traditionally viewed as a brain disorder, it has become clear that one of the most devastating outcomes of schizophrenia spectrum disorder is its high rates of medical morbidity and mortality due to mostly age-related medical conditions like cardiovascular diseases. In parallel, accelerated brain aging is also evident. The proposed study is to determine to what extent aberrant vascular biology in schizophrenia may contribute to the earlier onset and more severe brain-body aging burden, which will guide the prevention and early intervention efforts for people suffered from schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Zebrafish as an animal model have greatly advanced toxicology and environmental studies, however, the lack of standards to report toxicological exposure and phenotypic outcomes impedes comparative studies. Here, we propose the creation of a new zebrafish toxicophenotype atlas consisting of images annotated with a zebrafish phenotype ontology standard and the exposures represented with a new toxicopheno data model. This community-driven standards initiative will engage diverse stakeholders in toxicology and environmental health sciences to ensure the relevance of and consensus on the newly created standards and atlas and their long-term sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human microbiome, which plays an important role in many diseases, is generally characterized using high-throughput genome sequencing. However, high-throughput sequencing offers noisy measurements of microbial systems. We will develop rigorous statistical methods and software for analyzing microbiome data, with the goal of improving the specificity and reproducibility of discoveries about the microbiome's influence on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolism describes the processes required for life in biological systems. Understanding the specifies of metabolism is essential for progress in biomedical fields, for instance, facilitating rational drug design and understanding antibiotic resistance. Our work contributes new, fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems by defining a biochemical activity and metabolic role for conserved proteins of unknown function, one of which is a disease marker in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This R34 study has high Public Health significance, is complemented with rigor and scientific premise and uses a human-centered design, mixed methods and the ADAPT-ITT framework to address a critical gap in HIV/STI prevention-care. This study employs a 6-month pilot RCT to assess individual- and couple-level feasibility, acceptability and preliminary impact of a couples-based, digital health intervention (DHI) for improving HIV/STI prevention-care with a new population - Black heterosexual/opposite sex (BHOS) couples residing in New York State. It is expected that findings will reveal the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary impact of the adapted DHI on couples’ primary (and secondary) sexual health outcomes, as well as how best to apply these findings in a larger, adequately powered trial (R01).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are studying the role of molecular motors in organization of the cytoskeleton and its dynamics using a several systems, including mammalian cultured cells and Drosophila tissues (ovaries, neurons, and trachea) in vivo and in vitro. We will address the question of how microtubules and motors define distribution of other components of the cell, how they perform the bulk transport of the cytoplasm and how the motors and microtubules transport intermediate filaments in mammalian cells. These data can be used for analysis of transport of molecular components in neurons, trachea, and female reproductive tract, while also providing an excellent experimental system to study fundamental questions in cell biology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digestive diseases have a major impact on health in the United States. This training program takes advantage of considerable resources in epidemiology and outcomes research at the University of North Carolina. The goal is to provide comprehensive training for individuals who will improve our understanding of the magnitude, etiology, impact and treatment of digestive diseases, and who will assume leadership roles in GI epidemiology and outcomes research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lapses from HIV care are one of the most enduring challenges to HIV programs globally, and are associated with high rates of viremia and overall morbidity and mortality. The proposed research seeks to identify person- centered strategies using combinations of navigation and community-based medication delivery to both facilitate return to HIV care as well as sustain long-term reengagement post-return among individuals with treatment lapses in Zambia. This proposal advances a high priority research agenda to identify the most effective and efficient strategies for improving reengagement in care, and will help maximize not only the public health impact of HIV programs but will also advance strategies to improve care delivery for chronic diseases worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative GPCR-mediated signaling pathways play a key role in all physiological systems as well as pathophysiological conditions including cancer, immune disorders, cardiovascular diseases, metabolic disorders (e.g. obesity, diabetes), pain and addiction. Over 30% of all prescription drugs on the market act via these receptors. The structural biology study of the human GPCR family will result in developing a deeper and thorough understanding of molecular mechanisms of ligand recognition and receptor function, which should translate into development of more efficient therapeutics with diminished side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR HIV, VIRAL HEPATITIS, STD AND TB PREVENTION
PHR: Project Narrative Gaps between human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection evidence-based interventions and practice in the HIV neutral continuum of care, which are deepened in the US South, highlight the need for implementation research in this region in order to achieve US Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) goals. Thus, our overarching goal is to support and evaluate the implementation of a sustainable HIV health service model for rapid HIV testing and linkage to HIV treatment (ART) or prevention (PrEP) in Nashville, Tennessee (TN) and Memphis, Tennessee (TN), a southern US city which ranks 4th among all US Metropolitan Statistical Areas for HIV incidence. The results will inform future scaling of these models to additional HIV testing, care, and prevention sites across TN, a geographic area at the epicenter of important US HIV disparities as well as support the local Nashville and Memphis communities in reaching their established EHE goals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementation of Rapid HIV Testing and Linkage to HIV Treatment or Prevention Among Vulnerable Populations in Tennessee

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Almost 50% of cancer survivors will be 75 years or over by 2040, and the numbers of older survivors and caregivers are expected to grow with the aging of the population. Older cancer survivors experience physical and cognitive function impairments from curative-intent chemotherapy, yet no standard aging-sensitive intervention exists to improve outcomes. The overarching goal of this proposal is to evaluate whether a standardized Geriatric Evaluation and Management intervention (which surveils for the medical, physical, and psychological effects of chemotherapy to guide management recommendations including referrals to relevant disciplines) combined with a Survivorship Health Promotion program can improve outcomes of older survivors and their caregivers in the transition following curative-intent chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The MoTrPAC ancillary project is a large-scale trial designed to determine the molecular transducers that are involved in the exercise response, particularly in skeletal muscle, and ultimately contribute to improved health status. The experiments proposed will examine the ability of resistance or aerobic exercise training to “imprint” skeletal muscle cells in a manner which confers long-term changes in this tissue, which in-turn contribute to improved metabolic health and functional capacity through epigenetic regulation of novel exercise response genes. The proposed work will also provide primary human skeletal muscle cells to the MoTrPAC repository for future use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The microtubule network plays critical roles in organizing the environment within a cell. Although changes in microtubule function are associated with numerous human diseases, including neuropathies and cancer, we do not understand how molecular diversity at the level of the tubulin proteins that form microtubules gives rise to functional impacts at the cellular and tissue levels. This project uses a multi-system approach to define how the most molecularly diverse feature of tubulin proteins, the carboxy-terminal tail motifs, regulate microtubule function and tune network behavior.

PROJECT_TITLE: Beyond the tubulin code: Understanding how subunit diversity regulates the formation and function of microtubules

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D), a major risk factor for poor bone quality and fractures, is associated with the premature accumulation of senescent cells and advanced glycation endproducts (AGEs; activators of the receptor for AGE [RAGE] pathway) in multiple tissues. Intuitively, senescent cells and RAGE could act independently or interact via cross-talk to contribute substantially to skeletal fragility and dysfunction of other systems and physiological processes in T2D, yet this concept has not been rigorously tested. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that targeting senescent cells and RAGE signaling in mice can alleviate or partially reverse T2D and its complications, including skeletal fragility.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a significant problem for U.S. Hispanic children; rehabilitation after TBI decrease disability, but requires timely initiation, and long treatments in hospitals, community healthcare facilities and schools. While parents play a critical role in their child’s recovery, Hispanic parents face substantial barriers that can result in delayed initiation of treatments and higher disability. Our study evaluates the effect of a culturally and linguistically tailored TBI education and navigation intervention, aimed to improve parental caregiving self-efficacy, optimize access and adherence to rehabilitation and ultimately improve outcomes in an underserved and rapidly growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to bring to humans a novel radiotracer that measures the biochemistry of granzyme B, a serine protease that drives the pro-apoptotic effects of T cells. During the first phases of this project, the probe will be ushered into the clinic for a first in human study to determine safety, dosimetry, and pharmacokinetics. Subsequently, the accuracy of tracer detection of immunoresponsive tumors will be determined in a cohort of urothelial and renal cancer patients receiving standard of care immunomodulatory therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal is for a new training grant to support a well-established training program that integrates new approaches to make discoveries in lung disease, sleep and critical care. It will support the training of 6 postdoctoral fellows in various types of lung research from basic science to clinical trials. Using physiology as an integrator, individualized mentoring and team science are keys to building on our success at producing leaders in lung research with rich diversity and an ultimate goal of curing lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Integral Membrane Proteins (IMPs) include many biomedically-important gate keepers, receptors, transporters, homeostasis regulators, and potential drug discovery targets. We are developing a robust and reproducible platform for accurate, reliable, validated, and reproducible structure determination of IMPs, and applying this platform for structure determination of IMPs selected from the genomes of NIH priority pathogens. We also propose to develop novel and robust methods for quantifying distributions of conformational states of proteins, and to apply these technologies in structure-dynamic-function studies of key proteins from pathogenic bacteria, g-retroviruses, influenza viruses, and coronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synucleinopathies, including Parkinson's disease, are progressive neurodegenerative diseases that affect thousands of people each year. It is imperative to study the flexible regions of α-synuclein, the misfolded protein associated with these diseases, as research has demonstrated that they influence disease severity. My findings will provide insight on the molecular features that will help us understand harmful cellular interactions and toxicity in misfolded α-synuclein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ LAY SUMMARY Diabetic gastroparesis is a complication of diabetes that causes the stomach to not empty well and as a result of our previous work we know that increased oxidative stress, loss of interstitial cells of Cajal, and changes to specialized immune cells called macrophages are the most common cellular abnormalities. We now focus on the mechanism by which diabetes changes a blood cell type called a monocyte that enters the stomach and becomes an activated macrophage, which disrupts stomach function by damaging interstitial cells of Cajal. This new understanding will permit us to develop therapies for gastroparesis that target these cells.
