IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Harvard Catalyst K12 Program will be the premier educational opportunity at Harvard Medical School and its associated academic medical centers for early-stage investigators seeking to pursue a career in clinical and translational research. The program will build off the already successful KL2 program, which launched in 2008. It will also embrace many new initiatives, including enriched mentoring, training in translational science, a strong and directed effort to pursue diversity and inclusivity at every level, and a range of new educational opportunities and experiences to ensure that the highly promising physician scientists of today can become the leading medical innovators of tomorrow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL YALE ADRC  The Yale Alzheimer Disease Research Center seeks to advance our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease with the eventual goal of translating laboratory discoveries into novel effective clinical therapies. Seven Cores (Administrative, Clinical, Data, Biomarker, Neuropathology, Imaging and Outreach) and a Research Education Component will work together to achieve this goal. Our unifying theme is a focus on the cell biology of specific neurons, and its heterogenous disruption in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will investigate the role of LZK and DLK, a pair of MAP kinase kinase kinases, in the multicellular responses to spinal cord injury, which will provide novel insight on the neuron intrinsic and extrinsic regulation of axonal repair after spinal cord injury. If manipulating LZK and/or DLK is found to enhance tissue and axonal repair after spinal cord injury, this would pave the way to develop therapeutic intervention targeting LZK and/or DLK. The ultimate goal is to improve the quality of life for people with spinal cord injury or related neurological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective methods to regenerate hair follicles in adult humans are limited, largely because the events that lead to hair follicle formation are poorly mapped. In this grant, we leverage state-of-the art single-cell genomic methods, live imaging, and in vivo models to build a high-resolution roadmap of the key steps that lead to hair follicle induction. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop faithful methods to restore these events in adult skin in an effort to promote hair follicle regeneration, while also providing an experimental framework that can be used to study the formation of other skin appendages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Inward Rectifier K+ channels (KIR) play key roles in the operation of cells in neuromuscular and other tissue. We will provide the first comprehensive assessment of missense and topological mutations’ effects on KIR trafficking and function. Acquisition of these data is the required first step to build quantitative biophysical model of the sequence, structure, and function relationship in KIR, to understand the mechanistic basis for KIR mutation phenotypes in disease etiology, to identify new treatment strategies for KIR-linked disorders, and to rational engineering of KIR as chemogenetic reagents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microglia have been recently implicated in the development and maintenance of alcohol use disorder (AUD). Although research on this cell type has bloomed in recent years, little is understood about the role of microglia in the development of AUD following early life stress. The present study proposes to investigate the effects of early life stress and alcohol exposure on microglia function in a holistic and unbiased manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Evidence shows transgender women (TW) will only use biomedical HIV prevention strategies that have been rigorously assessed for safety, tolerability, and efficacy in this population, however, TW's participation in HIV vaccine trials is exceedingly low (<2% of trials participants), which will likely preclude their uptake of future vaccines. In response, the proposed R21 will develop and test a tailored digital health communication tool titled “VaxCom” to increase recruitment and enrollment of TW in Phase 1 vaccine trials by cuing discussions on TW's unique HIV vaccine questions/concerns, Phase 1 trials participation, and by presenting the associated information on these topics in a way that is targeted and meaningful to TW. Increasing TW's participation in Phase 1 HIV vaccine trials has the potential to generate meaningful TW-specific safety data, which can be leveraged to improve their participation in subsequent HIV vaccine trials phases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it comprehensively investigates nervous system mechanism of rotator cuff tears-induced pain, a common shoulder injury that affects approximately 4.5 million Americans every year. Understanding these mechanisms will identify targets for interventions and move us toward developing patient-specific treatments for individuals with rotator cuff tears. The proposed project is relevant to the NIAMS’ mission to investigate the cause, treatment, and prevention of musculoskeletal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Human cells can mount multi-pronged defensive responses to viral infection. The protein TRIM5 is positioned to initiate and organize these responses to retroviral infection and can directly interfere with the viral life cycle, transmit immune activating signals, and marshal cellular degradative pathways. The purpose of this project is to use cellular and proteomic approaches to determine how TRIM5 coordinates its myriad antiviral activities upon recognition of retroviral capsids with the long term goal of enabling our understanding and potential therapeutic manipulation of protective or pathogenic cellular responses to retroviruses including HIV-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current application seeks to identify and understand the role of DNA changes in blood cells in the development of new onset mild cognitive impairment, dementia and kidney disease progression. Strong epidemiologic evidence indicates that chronic kidney disease (CKD), an age-related clinical disorder is associated with accelerated cognitive function decline. Knowledge gained from this work may contribute to the discovery of new ways to reduce the burden of cognitive function decline and kidney disease progression associated with aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuropeptides and peptide hormones act as messengers to facilitate communication between cells in the central nervous system and endocrine system. Because many human diseases are caused by a dysregulation of normal cellular communication, it is critically important for human health to fully understand and selectively modulate these signaling pathways. This research develops chemical probes and approaches to interrogate the molecular mechanisms of peptide transmitters in disease, which will reveal new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of Graduate Training in Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology (GTMCP) at the University of Wisconsin- Madison is to train a diverse group of students in the discipline of Pharmacology to prepare them for careers that focus on the development of new therapeutics to treat disease. This application highlights a redesigned curriculum that strongly emphasizes the importance of rigor and reproducibility and mentor-mentee relationships, the necessity for professional development opportunities throughout graduate training to expose students to a wide variety of career options in the Pharmacological Sciences, and inclusive research training focused on the development of operational and technical skills in quantitative and systems Pharmacology to provide trainees with a mechanistic understanding of drug action, how it relates to normal human physiology, and how to exploit this knowledge to ameliorate pathophysiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Investigating the neural basis of social behavior such as mating and aggression provides a strong framework to reveal general principles of how the nervous system supports behavior. This proposal seeks to define the manner by which sensory input relating to social partners is processed and transmitted throughout the brain to guide appropriate behavior. The results of these experiments will determine broad principles of how the brain parses out and acts on social information—the comprehension of which will greatly inform our understanding of maladaptive social behaviors in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE While the prevalence of autism continues to rise (currently 1 in 44 children), the brain bases of the communication challenges observed in autistic individuals remain unclear. It is hypothesized that motor differences may underlie many of the speech, language, and communication difficulties observed in autistic individuals. This project will precisely characterize the motor regions in the brain related to speech production in autistic and neurotypical adults, thoroughly assess the speech, language, and motor profiles of these adults, and examine the relationship between the speech production motor brain activation and behavioral profiles of these individuals, with the goal of better understanding the role of the motor system in communication for autistic adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative BK channels are potassium channels involved in multiple physiological functions. Mutations in the BK channel underlie a group of human channelopathies characterized by neurodevelopmental delay, seizures, and movement disorders. Proximity of BK channels to calcium channels is crucial for their function; however, little is known about the mechanisms governing this channel-to-channel proximity. Our long-term goal is to identify the mechanisms controlling the spatial organization of BK channels and its co-clustering with calcium channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Regulatory T (Treg) cells play an essential role in controlling autoimmune diseases and chronic inflammation and understanding the mechanisms that control the function of Treg cells would be important in devising novel treatments of autoimmune and inflammatory disease. We have uncovered a key molecular pathway by which Treg cells lose their immune suppressive function due to their loss of a master protein called Foxp3 and identified novel approaches to re-establish the function of Treg cells under such conditions, relevant to chronic human inflammatory diseases such as asthma, autoimmune diseases and others in which Treg cells are unable to control the immune response. The proposed studies aim to understand how this pathway leads to inflammation and autoimmunity and may lead to novel therapies for inflammatory and autoimmune diseases by boosting Treg cell activity to promote immunological tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and steatohepatitis (NASH) have reached epidemic proportions, and remain without FDA-approved therapy. Numerous candidate therapies have been thwarted by inefficacy or side effects, underscoring the need to identify new therapeutic targets that coordinately prevent steatosis, without untoward side effects. We have uncovered here a novel mechanism, the inhibition of which provides uniquely coordinated protection from NAFLD and NASH, and we propose experiments to understand the process in molecular and physiological detail, in order to determine if targeting this pathway may have therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the Drugs of Abuse Training Program at Temple University is to provide comprehensive training for doctoral students and post-doctoral fellows in the areas of the neurobiology of addiction, pharmacology of drugs of abuse, and their intersection with HIV/AIDS. There is a need at the national level for well-trained innovative basic science researchers in areas related to substance abuse, in order to discover new treatment and prevention stategies to combat addictive diseases and their consequences including HIV/AIDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Physician-scientists have a critical role to play in the development, refinement, and application of novel strategies for the diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and cure of mental illness, but the number of highly trained physician-scientists entering psychiatry remains inadequate. The Integrated Mentored Patient-Oriented Research Training (IMPORT) Program has a 15-year history of supporting and accelerating the careers of physician-scientist trainees at psychiatry at Yale; our graduates have gone on to do important work across the country. Here we continue and enhance this program, keeping the core structure that has worked so well while enhancing focus on key areas required for success of the next generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Using novel microscopic imaging and microfluidic manipulation methods, a subpopulation of “unfit” cells is identified in the blood of sickle cell disease patients that may be responsible for vaso-occlusive crises. The proposal seeks to bring further innovations in imaging and microfluidic techniques that may allow us to better understand the mechanistic origins of these unfit cells and the consequences on their sickling propensity. The planned work will provide the foundation to explore how pharmaceutical interventions may affect this population of “unfit” cells and related patient outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Significant research efforts are currently underway to understand and prevent the pathogeneses of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, both of which are associated with memory loss and cognitive decline. The hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease pathogenesis is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-  peptide plaques and tau-containing neurofibrillary tangles in the brain, and the cause of this is not fully understood. This proposal will uncover the key route of brain-derived A or tau clearance that could contribute to the better understanding of the etiopathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will critically advance the understanding of early emotional predictors of later psychopathology in infants at familial risk for ASD, improving diagnostic precision and hastening access to empirically-validated preventative and early interventions in this vulnerable group. Consistent with the Research Domain Criteria research framework recommendations, the project (1) employs multiple levels of analysis, (2) investigates negative and positive valence systems as well as arousal systems, (3) examines a spectrum of ASD risk with long-term goals of improving diagnostic precision in ASD and enabling discovery of novel treatment targets and interventions both during prodromal and early syndromal stages of the disorder.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To combat the epidemics of obesity and metabolic disease, a growing number of pharmacological strategies have emerged that leverage key hormonal signaling pathways regulated by enteroendocrine cells (EECs), a rare secretory lineage of the intestinal epithelium essential for metabolic health. Despite these advancements, the molecular regulators of EEC homeostasis, especially in the contexts of diet-induced obesity and bariatric surgery, remain incompletely understood. This proposal aims to address this knowledge gap by examining the context- specific roles of an EEC lineage-enriched microRNA molecule (microRNA-375) in the regulation of EEC biology, which may ultimately reveal novel therapeutic targets for the treatment of obesity and its comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE As the most prevalent cause of dementia, Alzheimer's disease affects millions of Americans and imposes a major burden on our society, but the cause of Alzheimer's disease remains unclear and therapeutic avenues to stop Alzheimer's disease progression have not been identified. Recent progress described major risk genes for Alzheimer's disease that point to changes in lipid metabolism in neurons and in microglia and that suggest synaptic impairments as a cause of the disease, consistent with direct measurements on patient samples that also described synaptic impairments, microglial dysfunction, and changes in cholesterol metabolism as a common feature of the disease. Based on these findings, the present application aims to test in human neurons and in mouse brain whether genetic changes associated with Alzheimer's disease predispose to the disease by impairing synaptic function via a lipid-dependent mechanism, thereby providing insight into potential new pathogenetic pathways in Alzheimer's disease that may be amenable to future therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Our goal here is to elucidate the mechanistic regulation of neuro-glio-vascular (NGV) restoration underlying acute coma recovery and to test a targeted pharmacological therapy that promotes NGV restoration in our novel, recently developed rodent model of brainstem coma. We hope that the first glimpse of thalamic regulation of astrocyte function and pharmacological modulation of glutamate- astrocytic signaling will help refine the therapeutic paradigm to target astrocytes to promote acute coma recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative  Our proposed studies will test the hypotheses the chromatin loop extrusion and RAG scanning contributes to the different mechanistic strategies used by the Igh and Igk loci for long-range V(D)J recombination and that the loop extrusion mechanism can be harnessed for discovery of therapeutic antibodies. To carry out these studies we have developed a host of powerful new technologies. The proposed work should reveal new paradigms for understanding V(D)J recombination in vivo, illuminate the range of mechanisms employed for long-range V(D)J recombination in antigen receptor loci.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT More than 1.1 million people in the United States (US) are living with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection, and an estimated 30% of people living with HIV (PLWH) have evidence of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Compared to the general population, the rate of end-stage renal disease among PLWH is tenfold greater and mortality on dialysis is 19-fold higher. With the observed high rates of mortality on dialysis, the ability to risk stratify PLWH by risk for future development of CKD is critical for identifying those at highest risk who would benefit from early referral for nephrology care and transplant evaluation and lowest risk who could be eligible living kidney donors for PLWH in need of transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (FLC) is a rare cancer of children and adults that has no standard or effective treatment options. The overall goal of our project is to study a novel cancer treatment vaccine developed for FLC, in combination with other drugs that work on the human immune system. Using samples from the clinical trial and samples from other patients with this rare cancer, we will study mechanisms of response and resistance to immunotherapy in this cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The oncogenic EGFR variant, EGFRvIII, and the GTP-binding/protein crosslinking enzyme Transglutaminase-2, have been implicated in aggressive brain cancer. Recently, we have gained important new insights into how these signaling proteins are highly expressed in aggressive glioma stem cells and their functional consequences for the development of high-grade brain cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Autoimmune diseases cause a large social burden on both the patients afflicted with the disease and their support systems. The Accelerated Medicine Partnerships in Autoimmune and Immune-Mediated Diseases (AMP AIM) is a consortium of Governmental, University, Biotech, and Non-profit institutions that will work to assemble an unparalleled repository of samples and data from biopsy tissues using advanced technologies and analysis approaches of samples from four autoimmune diseases: System Lupus Erythematosus (or “Lupus”), Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA), Sjogren’s Syndrome (SjD), and Psoriatic Spectrum of Disease (Psoriasis, PsD). The Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation’s Tissue Research Core (OMRF TRC) proposes to provide the Network with 1) standard methods, 2) centralized sample storage/management, 3) centralized testing, 4) collection of tissue pathology data, and 5) data systems to organize all data through its existing staff and infrastructure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research proposal aims to develop an improved computational framework to discover non- coding functional variants in the human genome and evaluate their contribution to human diseases in a tissue- and cell-type-resolved manner. We will build machine-learning ensemble models to predict regulatory variants using existing and emerging epigenomic data and validate our prediction experimentally. The new method developed in this study will help us to uncover underlying genetic and molecular mechanisms of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: New World Arenaviruses (NWA) are single-stranded RNA viruses that cause viral hemorrhagic fevers in humans with high mortality and a better understanding of how host factors influence infection is important to our ability to prevent and treat infection. We recently discovered a new host factor, TRIM2 that in concert with SIRPA, a protein known to block phagocytosis, inhibits virus infection by restricting entry of viruses into cells. This proposal will build upon this finding and use mouse and cell culture models to determine how TRIM2 and SIRPA work to inhibit infection, with the ultimate goal of finding anti-viral therapies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT A major focus of the project is DNA replication, a fundamental event that is required in all life forms, and its disruption can lead to several forms of disease, including cancer. The central engine of the replication machinery is the hexameric MCM complex, which represents a logical, promising target for anti-cancer therapies. A second focus of the project is the human RNA helicase DDX3X, which is associated with several human diseases, including HIV, HCV, and the brain cancer medulloblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite long-standing racial disparities in lung cancer treatment and outcomes, the underlying reasons remain inadequately understood. We will comprehensively and simultaneously assess the contributions of affordability, accommodation, acceptability, accessibility, and availability barriers to lung cancer disparities in a nationally representative cohort of lung cancer patients. The results will advance our understanding of the potentially modifiable barriers to lung cancer care in African American patients, and thus will help inform multilevel intervention strategies to improve lung cancer care and reduce the burden of lung cancer in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and venous leg ulcers (VLUs) are common chronic wounds and are very serious diseases frequently complicated by infection. The focus of this project is to identify response mechanisms of patients’ skin regulated by the microbiome that are common for both types of ulcers, DFUs and VLUs. The results from this project will characterize mechanisms important for chronic wound healing, provide important new knowledge regarding chronic wound infection, and be used for the development of novel targeted therapeutics to fight wound infection and promote wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overdose of the commonly used analgesic drug acetaminophen is a leading cause of liver toxicity and liver failure, in part because there have been no major advances in specific treatments to prevent progression of hepatotoxicity to acute liver failure. Acute liver injury is associated with activation of a blood clot degrading enzyme called plasmin, and prior studies suggest plasmin promotes blood vessel damage in the liver that causes acute liver failure and its most severe consequences. The primary goal of this research program is to uncover how plasmin activity is controlled in the injured liver, such that new therapies can be designed to prevent morbidity and mortality in patients with liver toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: As there is continuing need to develop drugs to treat diseases, we are faced with training new scientists who understand the mechanism of these diseases, how to discover and characterize drug targets, how the drugs work and are processed by the body, and how to increase effectiveness and reduce adverse effects of the drugs. The collaboration of scientists from diverse backgrounds enhances creativity and innovation by bringing together a wide range of perspectives. Our program aims to 1) provide rigorous training that prepares PhD students to become leaders in the broad area of pharmacology and therapeutics; and 2) increase the diversity and quality of the national work force in this area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The only way to significantly increase the participation to large-scale genomic studies to further biomedical research and human health is to protect patient privacy. The ability to accomplish this is dependent upon developing computational techniques that quantifies the privacy risk and provides alternative ways to share the data while maximizing the utility. The proposed research combines novel statistical and molecular biology techniques to 1) quantify the amount of private information leakage in genomic summary results, and 2) develop tools to asses risk of privacy and means to share data while balancing usability and privacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project assembles leading cavernous angioma researchers with the aim of developing blood tests for the diagnosis and prediction of symptomatic brain hemorrhage, a critical clinical challenge in a disease affecting more than a million Americans. Our proposed study will investigate the regulation and function of ChREBPα as a protective factor in diet-induced NASH by preserving hepatic fatty acid oxidation and suppressing the activation of hepatic stellate cells and fibrosis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. Project Narrative As providing care comes at great physical and psychosocial cost for both persons with ADRD and their caregivers, reducing sources of caregiver burden is a clear health priority. Dysphagia (swallowing impairment) is a highly prevalent consequence of ADRD and strong contributor to morbidity and mortality; this proposed study seeks to address the clear gap in our current understanding of dysphagia’s contributions to burden among caregivers of persons with ADRD. The results of this study will directly inform the development of a new, evidence-based intervention for reducing aspects of caregiver burden related to dysphagia management in ADRD and thus offer a unique opportunity to proactively intervene with families earlier, ameliorating, and potentially even preventing, the development of aspects of burden over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) remains a major public health issue, as one-third of Americans are unscreened; this study aims to improve CRC screening uptake by developing and validating the Automated Colorectal Cancer Educational Support System (ACCESS) – an online, immersive, and interactive conjoint analysis-based decision aid that supports patients in selecting a CRC screening modality congruent with their preferences and values. Development of ACCESS will: (1) be informed by foundational research using qualitative research and conjoint analysis methodologies that will gain insights into patients’ knowledge, attitudes, beliefs, and drivers of decision making regarding the different CRC screening test options; and (2) be built in partnership with patients, clinicians, implementation scientists, user interface and experience experts, and computer scientists. It will be validated through a pilot randomized controlled trial that tests whether provision of the ACCESS decision tool, through optimizing shared decision making and improving the patient-clinician interaction, leads to selection of a screening modality that accurately maps to a patient’s values, and as a result, increases acceptance and completion of CRC screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE The environment of lung tumors is hostile requiring tumors to adapt to be able to survive and grow. Part of this adaptation is a change in metabolism and increases the antioxidant, glutathione to combat the augmented oxidative stress. In this proposal we will address the mechanism whereby this increase in glutathione occurs and offer new strategies to prevent the increases in glutathione from happening. We will test whether this strategy can be used to augment the therapeutic efficacy of the chemotherapeutic drug, cisplatin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Staphylococcus aureus (SA), in particular methicillin-resistant SA (MRSA) is a major human pathogen causing significant mortality and morbidity in the US and around the world. There is no vaccine available for this pathogen. The majority of MRSA infections are skin and soft tissue infection (SSTI). SSTI is a major cause of morbidity with over 11 million doctor visits per year in the US. It is also a breading ground for increasing antimicrobial resistance. We are developing a multivalent toxoid vaccine against SA SSTI. In this project we intend to perform a set of immunological studies in patients to determine the markers of immune protection in humans and evaluate the feasibility of a toxoid vaccine. Furthermore, studies in mouse models are proposed to evaluate the mechanism by which toxins modulate the immune response to SA. Our studies will be critically important for future clinical trials for development of vaccines for SA-SSTI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The long-term goal of this research program is to gain a thorough and mechanistic understanding of the regulatory processes that control signaling by G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are the largest family of signaling receptors expressed in the human body and largest class of druggable targets. The proper regulation of GPCR signaling is critical for maintaining cellular homeostasis, dysregulation of these pathways, through either aberrant increases or decreases in signaling drives disease progression. An understanding of how GPCR signaling is regulated in normal cellular physiology and dysregulated in disease is critical for advancing the status of GPCRs as viable drug targets for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research aims to provide a better understanding of the mechanisms by which calorie restriction can impede ovarian cancer progression. Our study will show that calorie restriction can improve anti-tumor immunity by affecting the cellular metabolism of macrophages. This work is directly relevant to public health as the findings of this study will help guide the design of low-cost life-style interventions and precisely targeted therapies for ovarian and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enteroviruses are amongst the most common human infections worldwide. These viruses are primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route, where they target the human gastrointestinal epithelium very early in their infectious life cycles. We propose studies to interrogate the mechanisms by which enteroviruses infect the human GI epithelium utilizing human and mouse models. These studies will provide fundamental insights into the mechanisms by which enteroviruses breach the GI barrier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) are at risk for disease related cognitive deficits that contribute to academic failure and decreased vocational attainment. A critical gap exists in the development of feasible and acceptable evidence-based behavioral interventions to address the functional consequences of cognitive deficits in patients with SCD. This proposal will adapt and test a behavioral intervention for preschoolers with SCD and facilitate the development of future interventions with great potential for improving quality of life for all children living with SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dynamic nature of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) enables these sensory proteins to recognize and bind a wide range of extracellular molecules with different shapes and chemical properties. We plan to directly visualize the dynamic behavior of GPCRs in real-time using single-molecule fluorescence microscopy, which reveals hidden structural characteristics that should provide new insights into GPCR functions in native-like environments. We initially apply this state-of-the-art microscopy technique to investigate the dynamic behavior of two human GPCRs: an adenosine receptor that regulates inflammation and a glucagon receptor that binds the main metabolic hormone in the human body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Graduate science education plays a critical role in the success of the U.S. workforce and economy, attracting and producing a diverse work force of researchers, innovators, educators, and leaders. We developed an innovative graduate program relying on the traditions and experience of one of the oldest pathology training programs in the country, but incorporating creative approaches to provide operational (cutting edge in-depth knowledge), technical (state-of-the-art methodology) and professional (transition into careers) skills that will lead to the output of true translational, diverse scientists. The Cellular and Molecular Pathology (CMP) graduate training program at the University of Wisconsin provides rigorous didactic training in fundamental basic biomedical sciences combined with interdisciplinary and innovative training in the pathogenesis of major human diseases. According to the Commission on Pathways Through Graduate School and Into Careers, “between 2010 and 2020, about 2.6 million new and replacement jobs are expected to require an advanced degree, with a projected increase for jobs requiring a doctorate or professional degree” (www.pathwaysreport.org). The primary mission of the CMP program is to prepare graduates for diverse productive careers in biomedical and clinical research, education, industry or government and to position them to make significant contributions toward the health-related research needs of our nation. The CMP program provides graduate students with interdisciplinary and integrated training in the pathogenesis of human diseases with emphasis on molecular, cellular and biochemical approaches. We seek to increase each individual student's appreciation of how specific disease processes directly impact individual patients, while fostering the application of the student's specific research area to potential new concepts in clinical care and treatment. As basic and clinical sciences have evolved, new approaches to apply multidisciplinary knowledge in the field of medicine are required. The CMP graduate program is unique in that it encompasses both basic and clinical research, thereby providing the highest quality graduate education to the next generation of biomedical scientists.
PROJECT_TERMS: human disease;Molecular;Pathogenesis;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Graduate Training in Cellular and Molecular Pathogenesis of Human Diseases
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - A[TWD-A]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common cause of liver disease worldwide; progression to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) cirrhosis occurs in a subset of patients and is the second leading indication for liver transplantation in the United States. Studies suggest that estrogen deficiency may be an important mechanism underlying the development of NAFLD and progression to NASH. The proposed randomized, placebo-controlled study of low-dose transdermal estrogen replacement therapy to postmenopausal women with NASH has the potential to further our understanding of this disease process and identify new therapeutic targets where few currently exist.

PHR: Project Narrative Substance abuse and addiction continue to be major public health problems with enormous personal, society, and public health costs. The goal of the NIDA P30 Center at Temple University is to support high quality, innovative research on drugs of abuse, addiction, HIV, and pain. The Core facilities will provide state-of-the-art resources and expertise to enhance and expand the scope of research in the field, to promote research synergy, and provide training for future generations of researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate the therapeutic and mechanistic role of apolipoprotein A1 (ApoA1) protein in repair of damaged endothelial cells (ECs), specific cells comprising the border between blood and tissues in the brain and spinal cord, using an animal model of ALS. Our studies will determine whether beneficial effects can be provided by administration of ApoA1 and elucidate the mechanism(s) of protein actions involved in EC restoration. The envisioned result is a protein-mediated therapy for vascular repair in ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription hubs are hotspots in the genome with elevated transcription activities. The proposed research seeks to understand how transcription hubs assemble on the endogenous DNA loci in cell, and how they engage with enhancer and promoter to activate transcription. This work will have implications to various diseases where transcription hub is dysregulated, such as neurodegeneration and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipid-based nanoparticles (LNPs) are the most powerful material for drug and gene delivery with multiple systems currently in use such as the mRNA COVID-19 vaccine and many more under clinical trials. One of the biggest challenges in RNA and DNA delivery is the process at which LNPs must evade endosomal entrapment. Membrane fusion and fusion-pore formation is the main mechanism of LNP and nucleic acid endosomal escape but how these processes occur in living systems is still not well understood. In this proposal we will develop a microscopic understanding of LNP-endosome fusion and explore a new handle, tuning the often-ignored Gaussian modulus of membranes, to design super fusogenic LNPs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Stroke and other neurodegenerative disorders are a leading cause of death, disability and loss of quality of life. The project objectives are to understand the actions of Parthanatos Associated AIF (apoptosis-inducing factor) Nuclease (PAAN) also known as MIF in stroke and determine whether a first in class, MIF nuclease inhibitor is protective in stroke models and explore the contributions of PAAN/MIF’s nuclease activity in the activation of cGas and STING pathway and subsequent NLRP3 activation. These finding could offer innovative therapeutic approaches to treat neurodegenerative diseases and stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although some risk factors for urinary stone disease are known, including urinary supersaturation, other pathogenic events remain elusive. Our preliminary data suggests that altered populations of renal inflammatory cells may contribute to urinary stone risk. We propose formation of a multidisciplinary team that includes early-stage investigators to rigorously investigate renal inflammatory cells in a novel animal model and human stone patients in order to provide important preliminary data for future grant applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed studies in rodent models will yield essentially the first comprehensive test of the hypothesis that chronic stress accelerates transcriptional markers of brain aging. The studies will illuminate sex differences in stress and stress hormone responsiveness and the potential protective and mediating roles, respectively, of progesterone and SGK1 (a key effector in glucocorticoid system signaling) in gray and white matter. Even if our working hypotheses are rejected, the proposed studies should have translational value for geriatric medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiomics models, or imaging biomarkers, have been proposed to allow automatic computer-aided diagnosis, classification, and scoring of various diseases based on imaging study data. Radiomics research and development is a rapidly growing field with the increasing availability of large imaging databases and access to sophisticated software and modeling tools; however, successful radiomics models typically require careful data curation and understanding to limit variability associated with the imaging chain (in contrast to the desired variability in the underlying patient anatomy which contains the target biomarkers). This work seeks to provide a rigorous mathematical framework with models for predicting the undesirable variability associated with the imaging device, acquisition protocol, and data processing; as well as strategies for standardization across those dependencies to rigorously estimate the underlying imaging biomarkers, thus permitting high-performance radiomics model development and application across a broad range of data sources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the mammalian intestine, Lgr5+ stem cells (ISCs) drive the rapid renewal of the intestinal lining and its adaptation to diet including to fasting, which enhances the ability of ISCs to repair damage after injury. Although fasting extends lifespan and promotes health in mammals, little is known about how it stimulates the function of ISCs to mediate this repair process in the intestine or how fasting-induced changes in ISCs impact intestinal tumorigenesis—a process often initiated by stem cells. In this proposal, we will investigate the mechanisms by which fasting mediates intestinal stemness and how fasting contributes to intestinal tumor initiation, progression and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims understand the role of chromatin-tethering proteins in organizing the genome at the nuclear lamina. Emerging data suggest that chromatin organization at the nuclear lamina is a critical mechanism of epigenetic regulation of the genome, instabilities of which lead to premature aging, some forms of heart failure and tumorigenesis. Understanding how chromatin is tethered to the nuclear lamina will advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the cause of these diseases, while also adding to our fundamental knowledge of spatial genome organization in the nucleus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our long-term goal is to accurately identify who is at risk of driving decline, to establish whether daily driving behavior can be used as a neurobehavioral biomarker of cognitive impairment and dementia, to forecast when driving decline will occur, to intervene before the time of decline, and to prevent a significant number of crashes, injuries, and death. By 2050, 1 in 4 drivers will be age 65 or older, and currently, motor vehicle crashes are a leading cause of injury and death among older adults, with symptomatic Alzheimer disease (AD), while sensory and motor functioning independently increasing the risk of a crash. Driving data continuously collected from the natural environment can establish a unique driver profile, determine whether that profile can predict preclinical AD via molecular biomarkers and the onset of dementia, and ascertain whether various cognitive and behavioral measures improve its predictive ability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This prospective, longitudinal study follows monolingual English- and monolingual Spanish-speaking toddlers born preterm from birth to 18 months of age (corrected for prematurity) to explore the unique and overlapping contributions of social-environmental and neurobiological factors on the development of language processing efficiency, a skill with short- and long-term consequences for learning. Social-environmental predictors are assessed through day-long naturalistic audio recordings and laboratory observations of caregiver-child interactions while neurobiological predictors are measures of brain white matter, assessed through two complementary methods of structural neuroimaging. The results will contribute to our theoretical understanding of the pathogenesis of impairment after preterm birth and to identirication of targets and strategies for intervention in infancy to improve long-term language outcomes in this and other at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Though episodes of lucidity (EL) in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) which are reported to occur near end of life, have significant implications for care, they are poorly understood due to underdeveloped methodological approaches for capturing and measuring these events. We propose to address these gaps through longitudinal audiovisual observation among persons with ADRD surrounding end of life to inform data- driven definitions for EL, distinguish these events from routine fluctuations in ADRD, and establish a repository of observational data for future research. Herein, our long-term objective is to clarify conceptual, operational and epidemiologic understandings of EL in ADRD and our short-term objective is to establish the needed preliminary data and infrastructure to enable systematic investigation of EL, and thus further this long-term goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Supervised exercise therapy (SET) is recommended by practice guidelines as first line therapy for people disabled by lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD). However, travelling to an exercise center three times weekly for exercise is burdensome and few people with PAD participate in SET. In addition, 45% of people with PAD do not respond to walking exercise interventions. This study will use a Sequential Multiple Assessment Randomized Trial (SMART) to test whether our home-based exercise intervention that incorporates behavioral change methods improves 6-minute walk more than SET at 12-week follow-up and whether biologic augmentation of exercise with nitrate-rich beetroot juice significantly helps patients with PAD who are initially unresponsive to exercise attain gains in walking performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE AMPA receptors mediate fast communication between neurons, contribute to high cognitive functions, and are implicated in numerous neurological diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease, amyotropic lateral sclerosis, epilepsy, and ischemia. We plan to use single-particle cryo-electron microscopy combined with protein biochemistry and electrophysiology to study AMPA receptors, their complexes with auxiliary subunits, and the mechanisms of activation and desensitization. Our studies will advance understanding of the molecular basis of excitatory neurotransmission and provide knowledge essential for the future structure-based drug design.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Although recent research has found that neighborhood contexts are associated with brain structure, function, and behavior in relation to executive function (EF) and emotional functioning, central questions remain as to the role of neighborhoods in developmental change in these systems during adolescence, whether neighborhood disadvantage may also increase vulnerability to the stress and school disruption of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the modifiable contextual factors that may protect against adversity and foster resilience. The proposed study will capitalize on the longitudinal Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD), as well as the staggered onset of the pandemic across waves of data collection in ABCD, which creates an innovative quasi- experimental design to address these questions. This study will thus identify potential neurodevelopmental pathways related to neighborhood disadvantage and COVID-19 as targets for intervention as well as modifiable contextual factors that can inform immediate policy and programmatic interventions across disciplines and the prevention of long-term sequelae and disparities for subsequent pandemics or disasters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will investigate the role played by specific neurons within the brainstem in opioid- induced respiratory depression (OIRD). Neuronal circuits within the brainstem are critical for maintaining breathing rhythms, and many of these neurons are severely impacted by opioid consumption, as they express opioid receptors. Identifying functional markers expressed in the MOR-expressing neurons that specifically mediate OIRD will provide a stepping stone to developing novel therapeutic interventions that selectively rescue OIRD without altering analgesic effects of opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: CENTRE HOSPITALIER DE L'UNIVERSITE DE MONTREAL (UNIVERSITY OF MONTREAL HOSPITAL)
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living with HIV (PLWH) are aging and experience a greater risk of age-related illness such as cardiovascular diseases (CVDs), bone diseases and frailty that appear to manifest at an earlier age (premature aging). We have identified the novel human inflammatory cytokine IL-32 as a key factor associated with CVD. The objective of this proposal is to study the potential impact of IL-32 on bone health and frailty, which will likely establish the link between HIV-mediated inflammation and premature aging of organs other than those involved in the immune response.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veterans with traumatic brain injury (TBI) frequently experience insomnia, which can delay their recovery and cause disability. Growing evidence suggests that misalignment between the timing of circadian rhythms—the daily changes in physical and behavioral processes that help the body stay healthy— and desired sleep may contribute to insomnia after TBI. Measuring the timing of the body’s central clock is necessary for detecting and treating this circadian misalignment; however, practical methods of measuring circadian timing have only been tested in a few limited research and clinical groups. This project aims to test the feasibility of two novel methods for measuring circadian timing in the homes of Veterans with TBI and insomnia, as well as explore the relationships between circadian health, disability, and sleep. In doing so, this research will help develop personalized treatments for insomnia in Veterans with TBI, which may aid recovery and improve functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake in Louisiana is among the lowest in the country, and few solutions have been developed to address the unique barriers to optimal PrEP uptake in the state. This project focuses on the use of machine learning algorithms embedded within the electronic health record (EHR) of large health systems in Southeastern Louisiana to identify persons at increased risk for HIV infection. The project will also evaluate approaches to best utilize the output from these algorithms to inform effective health-system based HIV risk status notification strategies on a population level, with input from community stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disorder without a cure. Using two mouse models representing familial and late-onset sporadic AD, we will investigate whether alcohol exposure has sex and/or age-dependent effect exacerbating the onset and development of AD. Our research will provide comprehensive data and critical biological evidence to establish the preclinical criteria and provide translatable information to clinical studies in regard to the impact of alcohol on AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE In the 4.5 years since our initial award, we have established CHERISH (Center for Health Economics of Treatment Interventions for Substance Use Disorder, HCV, and HIV) as a National Center of Excellence for health economic research related to substance use disorder policy and HCV and HIV care of people who use substances. In this renewal period, we propose to expand our focus to add population data and modeling components, develop economic evaluation methodologies, and improve knowledge translation strategies for health outcomes and implementation research that is conducted at the individual, system, and community- levels. The Center includes 3 Scientific Cores (Methodology Core, Population Data & Modeling Core, and Dissemination & Policy Core) and 2 Supporting Cores (Pilot Grant & Training Core, Administrative Core).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative While older women are disproportionately affected by chronic diseases and conditions associated with aging, including both physical and cognitive impairments, that can be alleviated or delayed by regular physical activity, few physical activity programs have been developed specifically with their needs in mind. This research aims to evaluate, in insufficiently active older women from the national WHISH pragmatic trial, the added effects of a technology-driven environmental barriers intervention called Our Voice compared to a “light-touch” remote educational program alone that has been delivered as part of WHISH. This study will add important information on the benefits and trade-offs of combining these remotely delivered and practical behavioral health delivery approaches to promote physical and cognitive health for the fast-expanding demographic group of U.S. older women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with HIV (PWH) may have poorer cancer outcomes than people without HIV (HIV-), but few large studies have evaluated differences in specific cancer care delivery outcomes by HIV status. Within the Veteran's Administration and Kaiser Permanente, we will investigate reasons for disparities between PWH and matched HIV- persons in delays in cancer treatment initiation, completion and safety, as well as short- and long-term outcomes of cancer recurrences, mortality, and risk of chronic health conditions. Study findings have potential to identify intervention targets, inform HIV-specific cancer treatment guidelines, and improve cancer care delivery and outcomes for PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative A better understanding of the prevalence and co-occurrence of relatively common comorbidities among children and adolescents with prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) is essential in order to intervene in clinically meaningful ways. These complex comorbid conditions are often the most challenging, disruptive, and costly health issues that families with a child affected by alcohol must cope. This study will document the prevalence and co- occurrence of early-stage indicators of possible or probable future chronic disease in children/adolescents with PAE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: K.220.8: PROJECT NARRATIVE Failure to resolve sources of phenotypic and genetic heterogeneity within AUD obscures efforts to understand its distal and proximal correlates, sequelae, and treatment implications. This research will draw on a combination of cross-sectional and longitudinal phenotypic and genetically-informative data to (1) characterize sources of phenotypic and genetic heterogeneity within AUD and (2) delineate its specific interface with other psychopathology, in turn ascertaining its unique and transdiagnostic features, putative underlying mechanisms, and interface with other psychopathology. Findings will elucidate major domains undergirding AUD and characterize specific AUD vulnerabilities, which will inform future precision medicine efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The North American Star Consortium for UM1 ETCTN trials consists of leading investigators from the Moffitt  Cancer Center, Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, VCU-Massey Cancer Center, University of Texas  Southwestern Simmons Cancer Center and Northwestern University Lurie Cancer Center. This consortium is  focused on producing and enrolling patients on high-quality clinical trials to significantly impact cancer  outcomes, the incorporation of state-of-the-art precision science in the trials, the accrual of minority,  underserved, elderly, and adolescent and young adult patients, and training the next generation of physician  researchers in cancer drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medical decisions in chronic diseases of older adults are becoming more complex as we learn to individualize targets and treatments based on clinical characteristics, genetic profiles, treatment preferences, and social circumstances. This award will allow Dr. Elbert Huang to devote 25% of his time to training the next generation of researchers in medical decision making and expand his research in epidemiology, pharmacoepidemiology, and decision support interventions. Improving the quality of medical decision making in chronic diseases of older adults has the great potential to improve the quality of life of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The development of perioperative stress hyperglycemia in patients without a known history of diabetes undergoing general surgery is a significant predictor of hospital complications and mortality. The likelihood of developing stress hyperglycemia is amplified in the presence of underlying dysglycemia, including prediabetes and undiagnosed diabetes. This proposal seeks to identify and characterize patients at greatest risk of developing hyperglycemia postoperatively in order to target hyperglycemia prevention in a high-risk population and improve hospital outcomes related to suboptimal glycemic control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Bipolar disorder is a severe and chronic illness associated with significant functional impairment, enormous public health costs, and high rates of suicide. Offspring of parents with bipolar disorder are a particularly high- risk group who typically display early onset and severe course of illness. Thus, effective and readily disseminable early assessment and intervention for the children of parents with bipolar disorder focused on specific, readily measurable, and modifiable risk factors has the potential to prevent or ameliorate the progression of bipolar disorder in those at highest risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Using mouse skin as model, this research takes molecular and genetic approaches to decipher how stem cells, as the natural units of tissue repair and homeostasis, are able respond to respond to local tissue and injury signals, replenish worn cells and repair wounds. Specifically, we aim to uncover how epidermal and hair follicle stem cells perceive external signals, remodel their chromatin and enter a plasticity state during wound repair, and how this differs in inflammation and malignancy. These findings will contribute to regenerative medicine and advance research for new diagnostics and therapeutics in treating inflammatory disorders and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This proposal seeks to continue for another five years the MSM and Substances Cohort at UCLA Linking Infections Noting Effects (MASCULINE or the “mSTUDY”) established in 2013 following across the HIV Prevention and Care Cascades a cohort of 514 younger mostly substance-abusing men of color who have sex with men (MoCSM) who are HIV+ and high risk HIV-. In this key population the mSTUDY cohort and its UCLA- based bio-behavioral repository creates a matchless platform to investigate basic, biological, and behavioral effects of active substance use, especially stimulant use (i.e., methamphetamine, amphetamine, cocaine, crack, ecstasy, and nicotine), cannabis, and opiates in MoCSM. We propose to address NIDA's 2016-2020 Strategic Plan priority focus areas and cross-cutting themes by rigorous assessments of the complex factors influencing substance use trajectories, health disparities, and biological effects of substances on immune function and HIV infection in very high-risk HIV– and HIV+ MoCSM contributing biobehavioral high impact science to address the public health challenge of curtailing HIV infections and comorbidities among substance-using MoCSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Worldwide infections with the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae are a major problem, and increasing antibiotic resistance in this organism necessitates developing new approaches for prevention and treatment. The major manifestations of gonococcal infection worldwide are genital tract infections and conjunctivitis in the eye, the latter a major problem in infants born in low and middle income countries, manifest as ophthalmia neonatorum. This project will develop a mouse model to study N. gonorrhoeae conjunctivitis in adult and neonatal mice to evaluate vaccine candidates and mechanisms whereby they induce antibodies that can protect against infec- tion in the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE MicroRNAs have been used as biomarkers for the diagnosis of many different diseases. Our recent discovery suggests that microRNAs become tiny RNAs upon viral infection, suggesting that tiny RNAs will serve as new potential biomarkers. This study will obtain the comprehensive profile of tiny RNAs during viral infection and reactivation, providing a solid foundation for diagnosing viral infection-driven neurological diseases.

PHR: Narrative The nervous system has been implicated in age-related bone loss, but the underlying mechanisms through which it directly promotes bone resorption are understudied. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the most common source of late-life dementia, as well as the third leading cause of death in the United States, and currently has no effective treatment. Leveraging the most advanced BRAIN Initiative neurotechnologies in circuit tracing, sparse neuronal labeling, single-cell molecular profiling, and informatics, we will identify cell-type-specific connectional and molecular disruptions across age and in two AD mouse models, and will develop an integrated informatics pipeline and web-based visualization portal for data sharing. Together, our study will provide a rich resource to study selective molecular, cellular, and circuitry vulnerabilities in AD, and to provide novel readouts in two next-generation AD mouse models to study disease mechanisms and to test candidate therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE World Trade Center (WTC) responders show elevated rates of mild cognitive impairment (MCI), an early sign of AD or a related dementia (ADRD). This study will examine small non-coding RNAs in monocyte subpopulation of Stony Brook WTC Health Program responders within a longitudinal study design, and integrate them with monocyte transcriptomic data to identify molecular mechanisms underlying monocyte dynamics and the biological processes involved in the progression of MCI to dementia. This knowledge will help researchers identify novel blood-based biomarkers for early detection of Alzheimer’s disease, and inform development of novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Failure of the islets of Langerhans leads to diabetes as a result of insufficient insulin release.  Cells within the islet are highly variable and show extensive crosstalk, yet how this variability  affects the way the islet releases insulin is poorly understood. A precise understanding of  these factors, including within human islets, will provide information as to how the  islet can become dysfunctional in diabetes, thus identify drug targets for preventative  treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE Artificial intelligence (AI) and its associated data-driven methods are rapidly changing how we analyze biomedi- cal and behavioral datasets – but they are not at all perfect. The Bridge2AI Initiative is a transformative oppor- tunity to discover how AI can better serve everyone, realizing its potential promise to improve health and healthcare for all. Our BRIDGE Coordination Center will provide a cohesive organization across the Cores tack- ling the emergent sociotechnical issues surrounding the use of AI, working closely with the Bridge2AI Data Gen- eration Projects to ensure a successful and productive outcome for this landmark NIH initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is among the most pressing and costly medical challenges confronting modern society. Our recent findings suggest a novel link between systems regulating circadian rhythms and energy homeostasis. Since disruption of molecular clock genes disrupts circadian rhythms and leads to obesity and associated metabolic disorders, this work is poised to fundamentally advance our understanding of circadian control of energy balance and has the potential to identify new avenues for the prevention and treatment of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal describes the integration of a Mendelian Genomics Research Center (MGRC) at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston Texas. It builds on past successes of rare disease research programs at Baylor, including the 9-year Baylor Hopkins Center for Mendelian Genomics, and leverages a long tradition of rare disease discovery, translational research, and basic science research that are each internationally recognized components of a collaborative research framework within the Department of Molecular and Human Genetics. We will develop a Genomic Medicine Toolbox and Comprehensive Genomics approach to study challenging rare disease cases with a goal to identify the genetic causes of human disease and seamlessly integrate these findings into clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will build a foundational metabolic understanding of tonsils and lymph nodes, common immune organs playing a pivotal role in immunity, and their structure and functional alterations during aging. This proposal leverages cutting-edge spatial metabolite and protein profiling technology to define chemical regulators and defects in controlling a key cell type, B cell, in human tissues from diverse aged donors while simultaneously testing physiologically relevant differences between anatomically distinct T cells and B cell subtypes with unique functional changes in aging. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIA’s mission of obtaining new knowledge on how the immune system is dysregulated in the elderly compared to young individuals through tissue-level molecular studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative People aging with HIV are at higher risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, and although physical activity is a promising target to mitigate such risk, this population engages in low levels of physical activity. Few studies have tested cognitive effects of exercise interventions or examined mechanisms of adherence to long-term exercise among diverse samples of midlife and older people with HIV. The current study will leverage an existing R01 to address these gaps and provide implications for development of personalized approaches for the treatment and prevention of cognitive impairment and dementia in older people with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: This study will examine everyday driving behaviors and physiological measures obtained by in-car monitors during common driving situations (e.g., intersections, freeway ramps). The goal is to build a model that uses features from these in-car measures to detect small driving changes that may be the earliest indicators of cognitive decline and dementia in older adults. Utilizing data gathered unobtrusively from vehicles is cost effective, readily available, and may alert individuals and health care providers of early cognitive concerns, as well as potential safety issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Preventive genomic medicine, particularly identification of individuals with inherited cancer risk, can improve longevity and quality of life, yet adherence to risk management following cancer genomic testing is poor. The proposed research refines and evaluates two highly scalable population management interventions, web resources and personalized outreach, designed to improve access and use of recommended risk management following cancer genetic testing. Research activities will be conducted in a vertically integrated health system and federally qualified health center and will address post-testing quality and patient safety concerns that are minimizing patient benefit and slowing investments in real world genomic medicine implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: In this study, we are targeting electrodes in a difficult-to-reach part of the somatosensory cortex with the goal of characterizing how information about the force, length and change in length of different muscles is organized in that brain area. Then we will apply stimulation to the electrode locations that encode muscle force and test if animals perceive the stimulation as an increase in their own muscle force. This technology could be used to restore arm movement sensation to paralyzed individuals or amputees who use assistive technology to move their arms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL PENNINGTON/LOUISIANA NORC) Obesity and the resulting metabolic consequences are major drivers for the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus and considerably increase risks for cardiovascular diseases, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, sleep apnea, many forms of cancers and other chronic diseases. The Pennington/Louisiana Nutrition Obesity Research Center is formulated around three scientific cores that create opportunities to perform innovative research with a true potential to advance the field of “nutrition, obesity, and metabolic health through the lifespan”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This project has strong implications for public health, particularly given the ongoing changes in legislation making cannabis more broadly available and accepted, and therefore potentially more accessible to teenagers. If age- related sensitivities to cannabis contribute to escalating use, and, moreover, if adolescents who develop cannabis use disorder (CUD) show differential change in sensitivity over time, then we will have identified key processes underlying long-term harms for teenagers who use cannabis. Supporting such scientific evidence to reduce adolescent cannabis use and the progression of CUD is important to the affected individuals and society and is a public health priority.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ultraviolet (UV) B radiation causes suppression of immune responses, which is a major risk factor for the development of skin cancers. This proposal is based on novel findings and will apply advanced technology to study the immune mechanisms by which triggering receptor on myeloid cells 1 (Trem1) regulates UVB induced suppression of immune responses. The study will use genetic and pharmacological approaches to target Trem1 molecules for prevention and treatment of immune suppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. Epilepsy is the second most common neurological disorder, but unfortunately, current treatments for epilepsy cannot control seizures in many patients. For this reason, identifying new methods and targets to control seizures is a high priority. Here we will activate a brain circuit that controls brain arousal and determine if doing so prevents seizures in several animal models, while simultaneously determining the connections in the brain that enable this circuit to stop seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Type 1 diabetes is a devastating disease caused by an autoimmune process that remains incompletely understood. This proposal aims to demonstrate the ability of an engineered beta cell to resist immune rejection in a biologic model of diabetes, preventing disease onset and protecting from hyperglycemia. These studies will contribute a better understanding of autoimmunity as well as improved curative approaches for diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory dysfunction after spinal cord injury in the primary public health concern. The proposed study is designed to test a novel therapeutic strategy to fight this complication by using respiratory training in combination with electrical spinal cord stimulation applied epidurally in patients with chronic spinal cord injury. This knowledge will help to reduce the burden of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Even though perceived as a less harmful alternative to conventional cigarettes, little is known about health consequences of long-term electronic cigarettes (ECs) use. We recently discovered that ECs can produce highly chemicals that may be capable of harming cells in the lung resulting in increased susceptibility to cancer development. Our proposed research will this by examining the impact of exposure of these EC chemicals on the lung in comparison with cigarette smoke in both laboratory animals and smokers. The outcomes will provide critical scientific information regarding EC oxidant exposures and inform the medical community of potential cancer-related risks of EC use.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a growing global need for training in vaccinology and the study of vaccine-preventable diseases. To address these needs, Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC), the Instituto de Investigacion Nutricional (IIN) and the Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia (UPCH) are joining forces to build the Peru-Vanderbilt Prevention through Vaccination Training Program (PREVENT). This new program will move IIN and UPCH toward a new horizon in the study of vaccine preventable diseases and address Peru’s need for a world-class workforce trained in vaccinology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is associated with an accumulation of repetitive RNAs that may play a role in development of the disease. The purpose of this research project is to determine if repetitive RNA accumulation in Alzheimer’s disease can be explained by age-related increases in these RNAs, and to determine if they contribute to the inflammation observed in both contexts. This work may help us understand how and why aging increases the risk for Alzheimer’s disease, and it could provide insight on potential therapeutic strategies for inhibiting these events.
