IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: CIC-DUX4 sarcomas represent an understudied and highly lethal subset of human cancer that affects children and adolescent and young adults (AYA). The proposed research is significant to the public health as there are no effective therapies to treat CIC-DUX4 sarcomas, leading to universal death in the metastatic setting. Upon conclusion of the proposed aims, we will reveal the role of MAPK-ERK mediated degradation of CIC-DUX4 oncoproteins as a prelude to the first precision-based therapeutic strategy to target CIC-DUX4 sarcomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Heavy and long-term alcohol drinking is a major cause of liver disease in the United States - sadly, there are no effective therapies. This proposal will investigate a new discovery that heavy alcohol drinking disrupts an intrinsic molecular biological oscillator or ‘clock’ in liver cells, impairing the ability of the liver to make energy needed for tissue repair and maintenance of overall liver health. The goal of this scientific research project is to increase understanding of the causes of alcohol-related liver disease with the outcome of this research having significant translational and clinical impact in terms of providing important scientific information that will accelerate new drug development to treat patients dealing with this serious liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Prenatal alcohol exposure is estimated to affect 2-5% of live births in the U.S., resulting in a range of physical, neurological, and behavioral effects referred to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD). The annual meeting of the FASD Study Group provides a premier forum for discussion and collaboration among researchers focused on this serious public health problem. This grant provides support for young investigators and experts outside the field of FASD to participate in the meeting and to inform and engage efforts to better recognize, prevent and treat FASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: United World Antiviral Research Network (UWARN) will address emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases by carrying out research on arboviruses, viruses transmitted by arthropods to humans, with collaborating partner research laboratories in Brazil, Pakistan, Senegal, South Africa and Taiwan. The research will develop innovative new diagnostic reagents, namely human viral-neutralizing antibodies and designed proteins that release light when antibodies to virus are present in blood. UWARN research will also improve understanding of how viruses manipulate the human immune system, facilitating development of better biomarkers to predict severe disease as well as host-directed therapies that could improve outcomes of viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Certain change in the human brain is strongly predictive of early disease processes (such as atrophy in the case of Alzheimer’s Disease—AD). However, using conventional image processing to detect this anatomical change in clinical MR scans taken across time is difficult due to various MR effects and subject motion, which can mask the anatomical change of interest relevant to AD diagnosis and research. The aims of the proposed project are to leverage the recent advances in deep learning to design, develop and evaluate an AD imaging and analysis framework that can resolve anatomical change with high accuracy, aiding in the early diagnosis and intervention before the onset of dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Notch signaling plays countless roles in development, regeneration, and diseases, including Alagille Syndrome. However, there is currently no well-established, standard drug to activate Notch signaling for basic and biomedical studies. We have validated a new Notch agonist and propose to investigate its use for rescuing Notch signaling in animal and cell disease models as a therapeutic approach for this genetic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute bleeding in the cerebrospinal fluid reservoir inside the brain can lead to a ballooning and pressure on normal structures in 37,000 people annually in the US. This is emergently and successfully treated with a drain that is placed through a small hole made in the skull, and carefully managed for weeks in the intensive care unit. We aim to validate automated models that can improve the challenging management of this drain, reducing infection, supporting early removal, decreasing length of stay, and improving outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early detection of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is paramount for prevention and treatment efforts, particularly in groups at increased risk for ADRD such as Hispanics/Latinos living in the United States. Consumer-grade mobile technologies present rich sources of data that can be collected passively in real world environments and can overcome the hurdles typically associated with traditional methods for identifying ADRD early. The proposed project will capture and analyze various streams of digital health data, passively-collected via smartphones and wrist-worn wearables, in order to identify digital signatures of ADRD risk in Hispanics/Latinos and reduce health disparities in this vulnerable and understudied segment of the U.S. population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are widely understood by progressive cognitive decline, yet relatively little is known about the incidence of paradoxical lucidity (PL) within ADRD, and the effect of PL on family caregivers. The proposed mixed-methods R21 will operationalize PL, while the R33 will administer a 3-wave longitudinal survey to 8,000 caregivers to assess prevalence and predictors of PL and link PL to caregiver outcomes. This work aligns with the mission of the NIA and will inform clinical practice around PL, increase the technical capacity of advocacy organizations to provide PL education, and establish a basis for epidemiological research on PL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Alterations in organ oxygenation contribute to the high prevalence of kidney, brain, and heart injuries that accompany major surgery. The effects of oxygen tension on mechanisms of organ injury are poorly understood, and oxygen administration during surgery is highly variable, unguided, and potentially harmful. We are investigating the impact of different oxygen tensions on mechanisms of perioperative organ injury in order to develop novel treatments to reduce organ injury and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the widespread acceptance that evidence-based treatments exist for alcohol use disorder (AUD), only one in nine individuals with AUD report receiving specialty treatment. The Certified Community Behavioral Health Clinic (CCBHC) Medicaid demonstration required clinics to provide nine services chosen to improve access and integration; to provide data on quality metrics; and to engage in prospective reimbursement. This project examines the effects of the CCBHC program on AUD identification, treatment receipt and quality and whether the CCBHC program led to improvements in public health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Tic disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder are commonly comorbid and are thought to have overlapping pathophysiology in the cortico-basal ganglia circuitry. Work in an animal model of pathophysiology and pilot data in subjects with tics and OCD have identified previously uncharacterized abnormalities in dopamine D2 and D3 receptors. We will use state-of-the-art positron emission tomography (PET) imaging to examine these receptors in vivo in the brains of individuals with tics, OCD, or both; this will characterize these systems in tic disorders and OCD for the first time and has the potential to elucidate targets for novel treatments, and to identify the particular patients who might benefit from them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Despite significant progress in the fight against pancreatic cancer, survival rates are dismal and the prognosis remains bleak, with only about 10% of patients living longer than 5 years following diagnosis. There is a dire need for new treatment strategies and pre-clinical models to evaluate emerging therapeutic approaches. This interdisciplinary proposal will evaluate High Frequency Irreversible Electroporation (H-FIRE), which is a non-thermal tumor ablation modality that induces transient nanoscale defects in the plasma membrane that ultimately results in cancer cell death and the activation of a systemic anti-tumor immune response that limits metastasis, in pre-clinical mouse and novel orthotopic pig models in support of future human clinical trials.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because social disconnection is a major risk factor for poor physical and mental health and it rises steeply during adolescence. PHR: Project Narrative  Cells need to respond quickly to the change of the nutrient level in the environment to adjust their survival strategy. The proposed research aims to investigate the dynamics of amino acid sensing using biophysical tools. We plan to recapitulate this biological process in vitro to gain fundamental understanding of how cells coordinate their behavior based on the nutrient availability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it centers on developing multifunctional porous soft materials for next-generation user-friendly skin-interfaced cardiac sensing patches with bimodality (concurrent monitoring of heart electrical and mechanical activities) and long-term biocompatibility for early detections and timely interventions of heart diseases. The enabling device is expected to simultaneously achieve skin-like com- pliance, high stretchability, high breathability, antimicrobial property and waterproof, as well as provide long- lasting, continuous, high-fidelity, concurrent measurements of ECG and SCG signals from human chests. The device is superior to existing ambulatory cardiac monitors and will benefit the people who suffer from heart dis- eases by providing unprecedented user-friendliness for patients to wear and collecting real-time, reliable, com- prehensive (ECG and SCG) data for physicians to make crucial care decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The process of somatic hypermutation alters antibody genes and is critical for effective vaccine responses and for the production of antibodies that provide strong protection against infections. We will determine the mechanisms and proteins that allow the somatic hypermutation machinery to act efficiently on antibody genes and how these mechanisms and proteins determine which areas of the human genome are susceptible to genetic damage by this same machinery. These experiments will provide a better understanding of the mechanisms that allow for effective immune responses and of the causes of chromosomal aberrations that are the hallmarks of cancer, particularly B cell lymphomas and leukemias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the most effective therapy for adults with major depression; however, some patients fail to respond despite an adequate trial, and ECT can produce negative cognitive effects. In this revised four site, prospective study we propose the first investigation of ECT outcome integrating multiple types of data including clinical and cognitive measures, whole-brain neuroimaging, EEG, and E-field modeling to establish the mechanisms underlying ECT-induced antidepressant response (response biomarkers) and negative cognitive effects (safety biomarkers). Using this approach in patients with major depressive disorder (n = 230), we will confirm the “sweet spot” of ECT dosing in order to maximize antidepressant benefit and cognitive safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chemokines and their cell-surface receptors form a network of signaling proteins that guide the homing and migration of white blood cells, stem cells and metastatic cancer cells to specific organs and tissues. These distinct and overlapping processes are controlled by the coordinated and non-redundant effects of dozens of different chemokine-receptor pairs, despite the extremely high similarity of all 46 human chemokines and an equivalent level of similarity for the 23 receptors. Our goal is to use advanced computational tools and experimental studies to decipher the ‘chemokine code’ that determines which receptor-ligand combinations orchestrate cell migration in the human body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE: Toward Connectomic Deep Brain Stimulation in Obsessive Compulsive Disorder Obsessive Compulsive Disorder is a leading cause of disability worldwide and identifying the brain networks causally involved in the disease will lead to optimized treatment in deep brain stimulation. Here, we leverage a technique recently developed by our group to identify the networks causally involved in mediating symptomatic relief based on a unique combination of deep brain stimulation and maps of human brain connectivity. Completion of this project will provide a clear framework to carry out optimized, symptom-specific and circuit- based deep brain stimulation for patients with obsessive compulsive disorder.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Repeated exposure to the inhalant anesthetic sevoflurane in infancy impacts cognitive and emotional development in rhesus monkey model, which has implications for childhood anesthetic exposure in humans. This project will test whether changes in mitochondrial structure and/or loss of synapses may account for those changes. We will then evaluate whether R(+)pramipexole (a mitochondrial protectant) given prior to anesthesia exposure can prevent the behavioral and neural changes associated with repeated sevoflurane exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal investigates the molecular mechanisms of adaptor-mediated ubiquitination using the yeast Nedd4 E3 ligase Rsp5 and ART family adaptors as the model ubiquitination platform. Delineating the physiological function of adaptors in substrate ubiquitination will reveal highly original mechanistic features of the ubiquitination cascade. Results from our proposed studies will further foster our understanding of human diseases caused by defects in ubiquitination and will forge new potential trails for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Brain chronic inflammation is a hallmark of the aging process, and promotes the progression of many brain diseases, and there is currently no approved therapy for preventing brain chronic inflammation. The focus of this application is to determine the molecular mechanism through which tiny nanoparticles derived from diet can interact with brain macrophages to inhibit brain inflammation. Defining these underlying mechanisms will provide a strategy for prevention/treatment of brain aging, and thus improve the health status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  People with sickle cell disease suffer from hemolytic anemia, and poor vascular function that can increase vasocongestion. Acute vaso-occlusive crises can occur in anywhere in the body, and are capable of inducing chronic organ injury, stroke, neurological injury and death. This application investigates how sickle cell disease impairs vascular function and designs novel therapies to improve vascular function and reduce vasocongestion.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a tremendous need to provide trainees with the fundamental knowledge pertaining to metabolism, omics approaches, and factors that contribute to host physiology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While nanoparticle therapeutics are being used clinically to manage diseases ranging from cancer to COVID-19, their performance is still hindered by difficulties surpassing immune, vascular, and tissue barriers. This MIRA will probe nano/bio interactions and evaluate new approaches to understand and overcome the biological barriers to nanomedicine, with the goal of improving nanoparticle delivery efficiency, safety, and therapeutic efficacy. By addressing knowledge gaps surrounding nanoparticles’ interactions with biological systems, this work will boost the clinical performance of nanomedicines to improve patient outcomes and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Utilization of new long-acting medications for opioid use disorder (OUD) is low despite major morbidity and mortality due to OUD in the United States. The proposed research uses health insurance claims data and qualitative interviews to study clinician behavior around adoption and scale-up of long-acting medications for OUD. The information learned from the study is relevant to public health efforts to increase access to and utilization of these life-saving medications; therefore, it is relevant to the part of NIDA’s mission of developing and testing strategies for implementing evidence-based treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently applied multiplex genome editing to reduce the alloreactivity of vascular smooth muscle cells and endothelial cells derived from human pluripotent stem cells by ablating the expression of MHC Class Ia and II proteins, while upregulating immunomodulatory factors, PD-L1, HLA-G, and CD47. Further, we have also developed new engineering approaches for the fabrication of mechanically robust, free-standing, ultrathin collagen sheets and related manufacturing tools for the scalable production of engineered living blood vessels. We believe that breakthroughs by the investigative team in genome editing, stem cell biology, materials science, and microfabrication offer an opportunity to evaluate a variety of tolerogenic strategies for the engineering of living blood vessels that evade alloimmune rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The surfaces of all mammalian cells are covered with glycosylated molecules. We develop chemical biology methods to study the function of glycosylated molecules and are working to identify genes that regulate the production of glycosylated molecules. Understanding the regulation and function of glycosylated molecules has relevance to human physiology, including susceptibility to infectious diseases and to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to automate objective differential diagnoses of middle-ear and conductive pathologies by taking advantage of pattern-recognition and classification capabilities of machine learning to infer details about the middle-ear status from wideband tympanometry clinical data. We will train an inference neural network with synthetic data obtained from validated and tuned computational models of the middle ear in the first step, which reduces the need for a large clinical dataset from pathological ears, and then retrain the neural network using a limited set of labeled clinical data using a concept called transfer learning. The trained neural network will allow for an objective and fast identification of conductive pathologies in individual ears to improve surgical specificity, minimize unnecessary exploratory surgery and imaging, and provide an objective clinical means of postoperative monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Overview of the Proposed Resource – Narrative The goal of the Center for Mesoscale Mapping is to drive the convergence of microscopic- and macroscopic- scale evaluation of brain structure and function for human translational neuroscience, by developing and applying tools to study the spatial distribution and temporal orchestration of mesoscopic events in the human brain. Our Collaborators will, through a dynamic “push-pull” relationship, provide unique problems which drive the development of these tools, and in return guide us in the design and optimization of our toolbox for practical use in a variety of normal and disease settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is in response to FOA RFA-ES-20-018. The proposal aims to identify shared genetic pathways that promote the establishment of persistent neurotoxic state for individuals residing in northern Indiana via in vitro functional genomics. We will select toxins via exposure history and combine subject-specific human induced pluripotent stem cell, as well as zebrafish and C. elegans animal models, to understand gene by environment induced persistent neurotoxicity.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The overriding goal of this proposal is to identify and characterize mouse atherosclerosis modifier genes and gain insight into their mechanism of action. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain from traumatic burn injuries is likely the most severe form of pain imaginable, yet reports suggest that burn- related pain is currently undertreated. Women report more severe pain and are more likely than men to experience chronic pain following burn injuries. In this proposed program of research, we will investigate the immune and neuroendocrine mechanisms behind these sex differences in pain following traumatic burn injuries.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 50% of infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss cases are currently without a genetic explanation. Disruption of retrotransposon activity in the mouse preimplantation embryo leads to altered global protein synthesis, improper uterine implantation that resembles human pregnancy complications and embryonic lethality. This project will adapt powerful proteomics, genetics, bioinformatics and CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing technologies to generate a meaningful understanding of the role of retrotransposon activity in development and disease that will reveal an overlooked and essential form of regulation present in early embryonic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Enterovirus D68 is a virus that causes large outbreaks of both respiratory illness and acute flaccid myelitis, a polio-like illness. This career development program will provide training that allows a pediatric physician scientist to develop an independent research career aimed at understanding in detail how the human antibody response modifies the course of enterovirus diseases. This work will inform vaccine design, and the antibodies studied can be used directly in humans as prophylactic and therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop new technologies for high-resolution, time-resolved structure determination of membrane proteins by overcoming current challenges in x-ray diffractive imaging of biological samples with x- ray free-electron lasers (XFELs). Membrane proteins perform many critical cellular functions, such as intercellular transport, signaling and enzymatic function, and are medically important—about a third of all human proteins are membrane proteins and account for more than half of all drug targets. Tools for determining the structure and the dynamical behavior of membrane proteins at room temperature with near atomic resolution will greatly improve our knowledge of biomolecular function with direct relevance and impact on biomedicine and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human immune response to virus infection is remarkably heterogeneous. The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the novel respiratory virus, SARS-CoV-2, revealed major gaps in our understanding of human anti- viral immunity, and the different responses and susceptibilities between individuals based on age, sex, and other factors. This proposed program will advance our understanding of human immune responses to viruses and vaccines by studying tissue sites where immune cells reside and function to obtain a more complete assessment of the factors which control immune protection than can be measured in peripheral blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pregnant women with Zika virus infection can transmit the virus to their unborn children, which results in mul- tiple birth defects including brain abnormalities, visual abnormalities, and hearing loss. It is important to define the full spectrum of symptoms, disease pathogenesis and early predictors of neurodevelopmental deficits in a controlled setting using a macaque model of Zika virus infection. This grant characterizes sensory and motor neurodevelopment in infant macaques and correlates these outcomes with brain abnormalities found on brain imaging and brain histopathology in order to identify early predictors of neurodevelopmental deficits that can be used to design future human clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Down Syndrome (DS) is the most common chromosomal disorder with intellectual disability and DS patients acquire neuropathological hallmarks of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), with a lifetime risk of >80% for developing clinical dementia (DS-AD). The existence of an aging DS population, along with an accelerated age of onset compared to the more general AD population, represents a significant public health concern and a dire need for research focused on the molecular mechanisms that contribute to DS-AD. A growing accumulation of studies highlight astrocyte-secreted proteins as key molecular modulators of characteristic phenotypes in DS and in AD, and this proposal will take both an unbiased approach to characterize astrocyte-specific secretome changes in DS-AD and AD as well as a targeted approach to investigate the potential of one protein candidate, Pleiotrophin, to ameliorate disease progression in DS-AD and AD mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The tandem threat of aging and obesity is rising in the U.S., resulting in a disease termed “sarcopenic obesity”, in which the aged experience synergistic muscle loss with both pathologies in combination with increases in body mass and adiposity. Combating the obesity epidemic and encouraging healthy aging is a top priority for the NIH/NIA and they recommend that doctors work closely with obese patients to encourage lifestyle changes, specifically exercise (more muscle mass), while simultaneously treating obese-induced pathologies (glycemic control and high blood pressure). This application seeks to understand the role of muscle mass and its influence on blood pressure regulation and will identify specific pathways and mechanisms induced by increased muscle mass to therapeutically treat obesity-induced hypertension and it’s many other complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because a significant proportion of men will experience lower urinary tract symptoms attributed to benign prostatic hyperplasia in their lifetime, but existing treatments have limited efficacy and important risks. Exercise is a promising intervention that targets novel frailty-related mechanisms of bothersome urinary symptoms in physically inactive older men. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIDDK’s scientific goal to advance pivotal clinical studies and trials to improve the health and quality of life for people with urologic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this project is to determine whether the Human Herpesvirus 6A (HHV6A) latency gene U94A plays a role in Alzheimer’s disease. The study is motivated by recent multiscale network analyses of Alzheimer patients that revealed specific and significant association of Alzheimer disease (AD) with HHV6A. We use Alzheimer patient derived cells and a new mouse model to test the overall hypothesis that U94A, which is expressed during latent HHV6A infection, is a disease-modifying factor that impairs the normal function of neurons and glial cells, and may increase patient vulnerability to other AD causing factors thereby accelerating AD onset and pathology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate cell growth and division is important for the development and survival of all organisms. When the controls on cell division are lost, this can lead to uncontrolled cellular proliferation and cancer. The goal of this project is to investigate the pathways that regulate cell division, which will provide insight into how they protect against the development of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rare genetic diseases are estimated to affect the lives of 25 to 30 million Americans and their families, and present a significant economic burden on the healthcare system. Currently, our knowledge of the broad spectrum of the 7,000 observed rare diseases is limited to a few well-studied ones, hindering our ability to make correct and timely diagnoses. The objective of this study is to improve the identification of patients with rare diseases in healthcare systems by developing data science approaches that automatically recognize rare disease-related patterns in patient health records and correlate them with genomic data, thus, aiding in diagnosis and discovery.

PHR: Narrative A pressing societal need is to ensure that the vast number of aging adults can maintain their independence and a good quality of life. Successful use of technology systems is critical to everyday functioning. Thus, examining issues surrounding aging and technology is important to the well-being and independence of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Hyperphosphorylated tau accumulation in the locus coeruleus (LC), the sole source of noradrenergic innervation in hippocampus, is the earlies insult in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), and loss of hippocampal noradrenergic innervation underlies cognitive deficits AD patients. We will use the novel TgF344-AD rat model to discover how LC damage alters hippocampal circuit function in a sex dependent way, and determine whether increasing the post-translational modification O-GlcNAcylation protects the LC system during disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastomas are a common form of brain tumor in both adults and children and DNA damaging treatments (radiation and chemotherapy) are still the most effective agents in this disease. We have identified features of glioblastomas that seem to predispose them to uncontrolled growth and this proposal will evaluate how those features could be leveraged as targets for new drugs, especially CHK1/2 inhibitors, to improve existing treatments for this disease by combination therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This study will examine Medicaid health plan policies related to delivery and management of alcohol use disorder treatment and their relationship with access to and outcomes of care for racial/ethnic minorities, women and rural Americans. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The utilization of brain biomarkers for the diagnosis and treatment planning of PTSD is hindered by the inaccessibility of affordable brain imaging technology. Access to cost effective and portable brain imaging technology would represent a transformative step for PTSD research and clinical work. I propose to develop novel brain imaging methods that enable the assessment of PTSD brain biomarkers in an affordable, portable, and repeated manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This MIRA application seeks to uncover the specific functions of a growing family of trans-editing proteins that play a universal role in maintaining the fidelity of protein synthesis. Our knowledge of the broader physiological functions of these proteins, especially in eukaryotes, will be addressed in this work. The therapeutic potential of trans-editing domains has not been exploited and represents another major gap in the field that we hope to address by our planned studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to the public health because more than 6 million Americans are currently living with Alzheimer's disease and desperately need life-improving therapeutics. Upon conclusion, we will provide the Alzheimer's research community with a new source of disease-causing Ab and tau oligomers and direct new targeting therapies by defining the structural components of a toxic oligomer. Additionally, we will build a tool to describe complex intercellular network responses to Ab and tau oligomers opening yet another line of therapeutic discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in PKD2 cause many forms of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). PKD2 forms an ion channel in primary cilia of the collecting duct and aberrant cilia Ca2+ is proposed to initiate cyst formation. We propose Ca2+ regulates PKD2 function though sites commonly mutated in the ADPKD population. We have developed novel tools to study the structural and functional biophysics of cilia PKD2— which yield results in real-time, at super and atomic resolution– thereby providing the most accurate description of the disease- causing mechanism involved in cilia Ca2+-dependent gene expression changes during cyst formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The NIA-Alzheimer’s Disease Family Based Study (NIA-AD FBS) has created a resource of 1,756 well- characterized families, 42.4% of whom are from under-represented race/ethnic group and that includes 8,697 consented family members and 1,096 unrelated controls with regular follow up. We have expanded sample acquisition to meet the changing needs of research on Alzheimer’s disease and related disorder, store all biological samples at the National Centralized Repository for Alzheimer's Disease at Indiana University and share all clinical, biomarker and genetic data acquired or generated through the National Institute on Aging Genetics of Alzheimer’s Disease Storage. The central goal of the NIA-AD FBS is to support research by making clinical data, samples and data generated from the samples broadly available to the AD research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To comprehensively understand the causes of diseases and prevent them, environmental exposures, especially the spatial and contextual exposome—social and ecological contexts in which the person lives their life (e.g., social capital, climate) or external agents to which the one is exposed (e.g., environmental pollutants), need to be systematically explored. There is also an increasing interest in spatiotemporally linking spatial and contextual exposome data, especially contextual social determinants of health (SDoH), to real-world observational data including electronic health records (EHRs) and administrative claims data, to answer various questions on how exposures to environmental factors affect health status, disease development and outcomes, and health disparities and equity. Responding to RFA-ES-23-002, the objective of this proposal is to develop an innovative SPATIAL AND CONTEXTUAL EXPOSOME SEMANTIC DATA INTEGRATION SYSTEM (SPACESCANS) with (1) an ontology-annotated knowledge graph of existing publicly available high-quality spatial and contextual exposome data from heterogeneous sources, along with (2) a user-friendly data integration tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma-associated inflammation and organ injuries remain a leading cause of death each year in the United States. We expect that our research will provide a new type of therapeutic target for trauma treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To better understand the effects environmental exposures such as air pollution on health, scientists must bring together varied types of data from sensors, along with information about where and when it was collected. Currently, we lack informatics tools that enable researchers to share, find, assess, and re-use environmental exposure data. Here, we will create tools that help research teams more easily conduct health research related to environmental exposures, using sensors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a great desire by the exposure science, epidemiology, and data science communities to use data and metadata standards to accelerate environmental research workflow, gain new knowledge, and increase data reuse. Bringing this desire to fruition requires the development of a set of community-driven standards for describing environmental exposures and linking them to human health and disease related data. Although our proposal focuses on the water contamination domain, the proposed approach is transferrable to other environmental health sciences domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative New treatments are desperately needed for the persistent symptoms of opioid use disorder (OUD), including changes in mood, motivation, and cravings. This proposal is designed to improve our understanding of how discrete aspects of prefrontal cortex neural circuit function are related to behavioral changes following long- term fentanyl self-administration. Our goal is to develop translational metrics that will guide the development and utility of next-generation treatments for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Faulty or dysregulated RNA levels have been linked to many human diseases such as cancer, neurodegeneration, and viral infections; yet drug discovery efforts targeting RNA molecules has proved challenging. In the cell, RNAs are often bound by RNA-binding proteins. Because dysregulation of these RNA- protein interactions has been implicated in many human diseases, in this project we describe our plans to expand the tools and technologies applicable to the study of RPIs to enable future drug discovery efforts for treating human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: To develop properly, mammalian cells must express master regulatory genes only in the proper cell lineages. This requires that both repressive states and active states of these genes be ‘remembered’ throughout the lifetime of the organism, functions carried out by gene products from the Polycomb-Group and trithorax-Group. This application continues our longstanding characterization of the functional mechanisms of these complexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Signal transduction, a process by which chemical and physical signals are transmitted through a cell, has a profound impact on human health and signal transduction pathways in bacteria and in humans are attractive targets for drug design. Understanding how signal transduction pathways function in bacterial and human cells is thus vital for our progress towards understanding and treating various diseases ranging from bacterial infections to cancer. We will use comparative genomics to better understand fundamental principles and molecular mechanisms of signal transduction in bacteria and elements of signal transduction in humans that are conserved throughout the Tree of Life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: It is challenging to design drugs that target the proteins and nucleic acids that are central to many human diseases due to the complexity of their structures or their propensity to adopt many different structures. We seek to leverage cutting-edge simulation techniques to understand which states of amyloidogenic proteins and G- quadruplexes can be targeted and to design small molecules that will bind them. Outcomes of this work are important for new therapeutics against Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases, and many types of cancer.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  The public health significance of the proposed project is high given the considerable burden of disease due to dengue, the importance of other infectious agents, and the impending threat of arboviruses' introduction in Puerto Rico that include most recently, chikungunya and Zika. The current proposal also includes close collaboration with the Puerto Rico Vector Control Unit, which will allow a better understanding of the vector and local epidemiological conditions that impact dengue and arboviruses transmission. This study will enhance the understanding of the etiology, epidemiology, and severity of arboviral diseases, allowing the United States to be better prepared and respond to critical vector-borne disease outbreaks that can lead to devastating morbidity and mortality. Through a better understanding of these disease threats, and their control and prevention, morbidity and mortality may be decreased and global health security increased.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: PUERTO RICO ENHANCED SURVEILLANCE AND CONTROL OF ARBOVIRUSES (PRESCA) PROGRAM

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE This study investigates the epigenetic mechanisms orchestrating the enduring alcohol-induced neuroadaptations of the brain following repeated cycles of abstinence/relapse. A combination of epigenetic, transcriptomic, pharmacological, gene editing and behavioral strategies will identify novel genes and pathways that hold promise as potential new therapeutic targets to curb alcohol abuse and prevent relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ischemic cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the USA; however, clinical therapies that can grow blood vessels in the ischemic organs are currently lacking. Over the years, we have generated both endothelial cells and smooth muscle cells, which are essential components of the vessels, from human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) and have developed a novel composite biomaterial to enhance transplanted cell survival. In this proposal, we will determine the neovascularization and therapeutic effects of a combination of hPSC-derived endothelial cells and smooth muscle cells encapsulated in a new injectable biomaterial on tissue ischemia models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol-related liver disease (ALD) is a prevalent clinical problem, with many knowledge gaps in the pathogenesis of ALD, including the role and regulation of inflammatory and tissue reactions. The extracellular matrix (ECM) is known to be important in ALD, is produced by resident cells in the tissue/organ and contains diverse components, including newly-described matrix-bound nanovesicles (MBV) that contain biologically active signaling molecules known to regulate and affect normal and diseased tissues. We hypothesize that MBV are important in regulating ALD pathogenesis and disease progression, and in this grant we will identify key changes in liver MBV during ALD/fibrosis, understand mechanisms of liver MBV effects in ALD, and test the ability of MBV to treat experimental ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolic pathways support cancer cell proliferation, but whether common cancer-associated metabolic alterations drive epigenetic changes that contribute to malignant progression remains poorly understood. We propose to investigate the hypothesis that metabolic control of the chromatin landscape is a major mechanism of p53-mediated tumor suppression in pancreatic cancer. These studies will provide fundamental insight into how metabolic reprogramming driven by the most commonly mutated gene in human cancer contributes to tumor progression and suggest metabolism-targeted strategies to activate tumor suppressive pathways in malignant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Diabetes affects 30 million people in the US, and another 50-80 million have metabolic syndrome or pre-diabetes, indicating that 1/3 of the US population has, or is at risk of getting, diabetes. Inadequate numbers of insulin- producing pancreatic beta cells underlie all forms of diabetes, an observation that has focused NIH efforts on developing drugs that will enable replacement or regeneration of human beta cells for people with diabetes. This application describes our progress to date in the development of human beta cell regenerative drugs, and our plans for further advancing this process to translational stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diarrheal infections are a top cause of death and illness in young children worldwide. We propose to use new epidemiological and big data methods to identify data sources, including biomarkers, that could help with the clinical management of children with diarrhea. Through these projects, we will build the capacity of Dr. Leung to mentor patient-oriented researchers in pediatric diarrhea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. The Akwesasne Research Center for Health (ARCH) project proposed by the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe (SRMT) will continue building on strengths for SRMT health research; identify cancer health implications as a result of local air and water quality; provide effective data on novel health promotion interventions and assessment towards advancing the fields of community health through sustainable workplace initiatives for obesity and liver disease prevention; and create new opportunities for SRMT youth to explore and better understand public health, health research, and cancer sciences. Collectively, these projects will support SRMT's strategic goals to build local health research capacity and implement data-driven decision making for the community that positively impacts health and wellness. The ARCH project contributes to SRMT's commitment to use their Indigenous Knowledge to prevent, address, and study illness today to help benefit generations to come.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cryptococcus neoformans is the most common cause of fungal meningitis and among the most important fungal pathogens, accounting for approximately 20% worldwide deaths from HIV/AIDS. This study will generate unique genomic resources including a whole-genome tagged strain collection and a genetic interaction map. These resources will enable the research community to develop a comprehensive understanding of how this pathogen causes disease and responds to drugs thereby laying a new foundation for combatting invasive fungal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Kinase inhibitor drugs have changed the face of therapeutics and are projected to remain a major focus of drug development, however, their long-term efficacy is variable because of biological complexity and resistance. We are developing assay strategies that can be used to study kinase signaling biology, and screen new drugs and drug combinations in a way that better mimics biological complexity. These could someday also be used as companion diagnostics for the drugs they help discover, to monitor the effectiveness of treatment, finding resistance earlier so patients can try alternatives that could improve their treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cathepsin B is a lysosomal protease that plays a significant role in the neurotoxicity caused by HIV-infected macrophages, which are the main reservoirs of HIV in the brain. Cannabinoid receptor type 2 (CB2R) activation by agonists decrease cathepsin B secretion, neurotoxicity, HIV-1 replication, and inflammation in macrophages. Therefore, understanding the mechanisms of CB2R activation in macrophages and cathepsin B neurotoxicity will permit the development of alternative strategies against HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Neural circuits in the inferior colliculus contribute to speech recognition, sound localization, hearing in noise, and other computations that are essential for hearing. The proposed research is expected to determine how two novel classes of inferior colliculus neurons process identified sources of input, influence targets in other brain regions, and respond to simple and complex sounds. These results will provide a framework for understanding how defined neural circuits in the inferior colliculus support sound processing and how auditory prostheses can more effectively engage these circuits to improve hearing for the hearing impaired.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Phagocytosis is a fundamental biological process in development, tissue homeostasis, and immune defense whereby extracellular material is engulfed by phagocytes and subsequently degraded. Phagocytosis proceeds via a series of steps which begins with cargo recognition, engulfment, and phagosome maturation; however, the molecular details by which this occurs remain unclear. Our research program seeks to develop a quantitative, molecular understanding of how phagosome biology is controlled with the ultimate goal of addressing fundamental questions in cell biology and using this knowledge to advance therapies where appropriate phagosome activity is essential.

PHR: NARRATIVE The UCSD Training Program in Experimental Endocrinology takes a multidisciplinary approach to prepare Physician and Ph.D. scientists to become the future leaders in academic medicine and in biopharmaceutical companies related to healthcare. Ph.D. and/or M.D. scholars will be trained in the fields of endocrinology and metabolism including thyroid disease, bone metabolism, diabetes, lipid metabolism and atherosclerosis through advanced basic research experiences in world-class laboratories, or by engaging in state-of-the art clinical investigation. Outstanding Faculty from the Division of Endocrinology in the Department of Medicine, and from other related basic and clinical departments, chosen to be Mentors in this program because of their proven records of fostering and encouraging careers of their Trainees, will prepare our Trainees to be future leaders in the field of Experimental Endocrinology and Metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Translation in eukaryotic organisms represents a final point of genetic regulation. Here we apply biochemistry, biophysics and structural biology to illuminate the mechanism of translation initiation, elongation and termination in real time, and probe the origins of regulation by RNA structure, RNA modifications and regulatory proteins. .

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our study is to leverage telemedicine to improve evidence-based management of acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs) across different healthcare settings and for patients of different racial/ ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds. ARTIs are the most common reason for antibiotic prescriptions in ambulatory care, and half of the prescriptions are inappropriate. We will use a mixed methods approach and a multisite implementation strategy to identify patients appropriate for telehealth visits (THVs) for ARTIs, create appropriate materials for the THV in collaboration with providers and patients, and gauge implementation and effectiveness outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing Telemedicine to Improve Appropriate Antibiotic Prescribing for Acute Respiratory Tract Infections

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but white matter lesions of presumed vascular origin are an independent contributor to cognitive decline in AD patients. Capillary dysfunction has been proposed as a potential physiological mechanism contributing to white matter lesion burden, but white matter hemodynamic impairment underlying these lesions remains unclear. The goal of this work is to characterize white matter hemodynamic function in older adults at elevated risk for AD using 7 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) protocols.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, the outcome of wound healing is often formation of a fibrous scar, which can severely impair the function of the repaired tissue or organ. This proposal will examine how microfibril-associated protein 5 (MFAP5) modifies the fibroblast response in wound repair to promote fibrous scar formation. The proposed studies will lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms by which microfibril-associated proteins and apoptotic cells influence fibroblast function as well as wound healing outcomes and may suggest the development of novel therapeutics to treat fibrotic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There are currently no therapies to restore mobility and sensation following spinal cord injury or vision after optic nerve damage. We will combine single-cell approaches and epigenomic approaches in mouse and human sensory neurons to understand the neuronal and non-neuronal mechanisms orchestrating nerve repair. We propose a multifaceted research program that may lead towards novel strategies to increase the extent of axon regeneration, which may improve recovery after nervous system injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bulk-tissue RNA-seq datasets are now available in tens-of-thousands of samples, often coupled with potentially highly informative phenotypic data and other -omics data, such as that collected in electronic medical records or by NIH initiatives such as the Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) project. However, current computational tools are insufficient for interrogating this bulk-tissue RNA-seq data at the level of the constituent cell-types, which has been shown to obscure biological mechanisms and insights. We propose developing computational tools that will allow us to interrogate large bulk-tissue RNA-seq at the cell-type level, by leveraging small reference single- cell RNA-seq datasets generated on the same tissue type—we will also expand these computational methodologies for the analysis of emerging spatial transcriptomics platforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project as moved from suspecting there were genes contributing to lupus three decades ago to the present point where we have a strong infectious cause and nearly 200 genes. This project will determine whether the proposed infectious cause of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), the Epstein-Barr virus that also causes most mononucleosis, works together with the genetic changes to participate in processes that have the plausible potential to cause SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE This training program is designed to address the significant and costly public health problem of substance use disorders by training postdoctoral biomedical, biobehavioral, health care, and other public health scientists to conduct addiction intervention research. Our program draws on many scientific disciplines, including biological sciences, epidemiology and etiology, prevention, clinical, and public health research, and emphasizes multidisciplinary approaches to achieving innovations in addiction research. Cutting-edge training of the next generation of addiction researchers has the potential to accelerate the pace of science in developing effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance The mechanisms that bacteria use to regulate gene expression are crucial for their ability to grow and adapt in different environments. The goal of my lab is to establish an essential framework for understanding bacterial gene regulation by uncovering how transcription, translation, and mRNA degradation are performed and regulated inside a single bacterial cell. This work will suggest new ways to control gene expression in bacteria— an ability that has potential applications to human health issues, such as promoting healthy microbiomes, killing pathogens, and improving industrial processes to reduce pollution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Flavivirus lead to recurrent epidemic outbreaks and are a global threat to human health without any effective antiviral treatment. This project will develop and deploy a novel nanopore tweezers approach that can provide a complete conformational dynamics, binding thermodynamics and kinetics profile of the flaviviral protease to guide the discovery and design of new inhibitors. The nanopore tweezers platform, operating independent of the enzyme activity, will also provide a new paradigm for label-free, single molecule and high-throughput drug screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is one of the most common neurodegenerative dementias after Alzheimer disease (AD). The proposed study will provide novel insight into the pathophysiological brain changes in individuals with DLB, compared to AD and healthy older adults, using diffusion-weighted MRI (dMRI) and task- based high-density electroencephalography (EEG). This research has the potential to inform future development of dMRI and EEG as potential biomarkers for DLB, to examine longitudinal progression of disease, and determine whether therapeutic interventions are having expected effect(s) on brain microstructure and cortical activity.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how and why antisocial behavior (e.g., aggression, rule breaking) develops in the context of disadvantage is of critical importance to promoting health in adolescents and decreasing societal costs related to these disruptive behaviors. The proposed project will use longitudinal methods to examine whether socioeconomic disadvantage increases risk of engagement in antisocial behavior via reward-related brain structure and function. Results will inform reward-related interventions for adolescents at most risk for deleterious outcomes due to exposure to disadvantage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Current understanding of the development and function of the peripheral nervous system is almost entirely neuron-centric and little attention has been given to the important contributions of glial cell types. This proposal aims to rectify this gap in knowledge by investigating a glial population in the developing heart that actively modulates cardiac function. A better understanding of glia supports a more complete model of neural control over peripheral physiology and pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral assembly is a tightly regulated process driven by a series of conformational changes and interactions between viral proteins. The proposed research is relevant to human health because the portal protein is essential for the formation of infectious dsDNA viruses, including herpes and adenoviruses, making it a viable drug target. This work will use bacteriophage P22, a paradigm for dsDNA viral assembly, to investigate, in detail, how the portal protein is involved in infectious virus production to aid the development of novel anti-viral therapeutics.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delivery room (DR) resuscitation is paramount to the survival of extremely premature neonates, yet there is significant variation in DR practices and outcomes within the US. This variation highlights the need for improved and consistent care, but there are no comprehensive approaches to assess DR care and no validated DR quality metrics to help explain and rectify this variation. This proposal seeks to (1) define and validate DR quality metrics and (2) develop comprehensive DR models to identify systematic factors that impact quality that can be used to develop, predict, model, and evaluate future interventional studies aimed at decreasing variation and improving neonatal outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging Human Factors to Evaluate Quality of Neonatal Delivery Room Care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early detection of viruses replicating within cells leading to the production of interferon is crucial for immune activation to limit further viral replication and spread. Using a combination of cellular and biochemical assays and murine infection models, we will dissect the mechanism by which HOIL1, a ubiquitin ligase and component of the Linear Ubiquitin Chain Assembly Complex, differentially regulates the production of interferon through the RIG-I Like Receptor signaling pathways during infection with distinct viral species. We expect our findings will aid in the identification of novel therapeutic strategies to treat viral infections and interferon-mediated inflammatory diseases.

PHR: Commensal microbes play crucial roles in human health and disease, and particularly in modulation of mucosal immune responses, however, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We have identified a novel role for intestinal epithelial cells in transporting proteins from commensal microbes for induction of a protective anti-inflammatory Th17 cell response. Here we will investigate the role of IECs and commensal Th17 cells in mucosal homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all cellular processes are influenced by small RNAs and their dysregulation has been implicated in fertility defects and disease. This study uses genetics and genomics to advance our understanding of how small RNAs control gene expression in the germline. The results will uncover new roles for small RNAs and mechanisms underlying small RNA function that preserve fertility and health from one generation to the next.

PHR: The current study will investigate the improvements of a recombinant full-length, non-toxic botulinum neurotoxin vaccine compared to a chemically inactivated toxoid vaccine by analyzing protection against botulism and the immune response in two animal models. Understanding of the properties of bacterial toxins allows for production of Next Generation vaccines that are safer, less expensive, easier to produce, and genetically malleable than chemically inactivated toxoids. The studies proposed will direct these advances in toxin vaccinology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by memory impairments and cognitive deterioration. Aging is the major risk factor for AD. Furthermore, increasing evidence indicates that astrocytes and microglia are implicated in the pathogenesis of AD. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified polymorphisms in genes enriched in microglia (e.g. ABCA7 and TREM2) and astrocytes (e.g. APOE and ABCA7) that increase the risk of developing AD. Cellular and animal models to study genotype-phenotype relationship of AD genetic variants enriched in astrocytes and microglia are missing. We have developed a novel bioengineered model of iPSC-derived neural tissue. Our silk-collagen protein-based ‘donut’ scaffolds can support compartmentalized, 3D brain-like tissues over a year, without necrosis. Thus we propose to use our model to study the extent to which AD-linked variants in genes enriched in glial cells produce AD cellular and molecular phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggressive community policing, school discipline, and the school-to-prison pipeline criminalize adolescents and ensnare them in the legal system rather than provide support for underlying educational and developmental needs; these phenomena are a hypothesized population driver of adolescent substance use and mental illness, and racialized disparities therein. We will collaborate with the New York City Office of School Health to create unprecedented, geocoded, longitudinal data linkages between police stops/arrests; school- and student-level exclusionary discipline records; and restricted school- and student-level substance use/mental health records. We will estimate direct and mediated relationships between community policing and school discipline on school- and student-level substance use and mental health outcomes; and test whether the spatial concentration of policing around schools, as well as structural and institutional racism, modify these relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project is relevant to human health through its focus on bacterial interspecies interactions, which are fundamental to the formation and function of dynamic communities such as the human microbiome. The mechanisms evolved by bacteria to sense and respond to different species of bacteria are poorly understood. The project is relevant to the mission of NIH for the fundamental discoveries of bacterial adaptive physiological responses to competitor species and to the discovery of specialized metabolites that induce these responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a new program project that brings together experts in Epstein-Barr Virus latency, epigenetics, metabolism, and carcinogenesis with core expertise in medicinal chemistry, drug discovery, bioinformatics, and animal models of EBV cancer. The overall goal is to address the unmet medical need associated with EBV epithelial cancers that exceed 180,000 new cancer cases per year and receive generic, non-viral cancer treatments and have high rates of failure, relapse and resistance. The Program brings together multiple institutions and collaborators to elucidate the basic mechanisms of viral latency and oncogenesis in EBV epithelial cancers, and to identify vulnerabilities and strategies for development of new viral-specific therapies to treat EBV epithelial cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 – PROJECT NARRATIVE EBV epithelial cancers are an unmet medical need accounting for over 170,000 new cancer cases per year. To date, there are no EBV-specific therapies to treat these viral-driven cancers. In this proposal, we investigate how the epigenetic state of the virus and host are deregulated in EBV-associated nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) and gastric carcinomas (EBVaGC). This information will provide fundamental insights into how EBV epigenome is deregulated in EBV-epithelial cancers and provide new strategies to treat EBV cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As adults with type 2 diabetes age, they are increasingly vulnerable to treatment-related hypoglycemia and its related complications (including hospitalization and death). We propose to evaluate, in a randomized clinical trial, a strategy of expanded advance care planning (ACP) to support older adults in value-aligned re- assessment of T2D treatment regimens with their primary care team. If the aims of this project are achieved and incidence of clinically-significant hypoglycemia is reduced, this expanded ACP care strategy could be scaled and applied in a wide variety of healthcare settings and chronic conditions in which evolving risks, benefits, and consequences of treatment require re-assessment with age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The American Society for Virology (ASV) fosters the training of junior virologists and teachers of undergraduate virology by encouraging their participation at its annual general meetings. ASV’s annual meeting is the only large general virology meeting in North America. The breadth of virology covered enhances collaborations and opportunities for cross-fertilization of ideas and technologies across the whole of the virus world. This contributes to meeting the health promotion and disease prevention objectives of the NIH mission. There remain major threats to domestic and international health from new and emerging virus diseases, such as the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic of 2020, in addition to more familiar viral diseases that are not yet controllable. This makes the continued training of junior investigators and undergraduate teachers in virology highly relevant. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NIH/NIDDK Project Narrative The purpose of this training grant to provide intensive short-term training in research areas of interest to NIDDK for 30 selected pre-doctoral medical students in the most outstanding laboratories and training sites in the Yale University School of Medicine. The specific research experiences will range from fundamental molecular biology, cellular and organ physiology to applied clinical research. The program is designed to attract the most highly qualified Yale medical students into careers as physician-scientists in the biomedical sciences in areas of interest to NIDDK.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia in the United States, but recent drug trials have failed to show an improvement in cognitive outcomes. Cortical excitability (measured using noninvasive brain stimulation) has the potential to serve as a novel prognostic marker or treatment target, and is relevant to public health due to its potential future applications in Alzheimer’s disease clinical trials. This is directly relevant to the NIH’s mission of advancing the diagnosis, prevention, and cure of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The INSPIRE-ASP Trial (INtelligent Stewardship Prompts to Improve Real-time Empiric Antibiotic Selection for Patients) for Abdominal and Skin and Soft Tissue Infections  The INSPIRE-ASP Trial (INtelligent Stewardship Prompts to Improve Real-time Empiric Antibiotic Selection for Patients) for Abdominal and Skin and Soft Tissue Infections is a randomized trial of 60 hospitals and nearly 100,000 infected patients to improve physicians’ choice of antibiotics for hospitalized patients by reducing the unnecessary use of broad-spectrum antibiotics. This trial provides prescribers in half the hospitals with prescribing advice based on the probability that a patient is infected with antibiotic resistant bacteria. Unnecessary broad-spectrum antibiotics carry risks, and the goal of this trial is to limit their use to situations in which the patient is likely to require them, while maintaining excellent patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Nanoparticles have emerged as highly specialized multifunctional probes for disease targeting and delivery of small molecule drugs to treat cancerous lesions. Non-toxic ultrasmall fluorescent core-shell silica nanoparticles that induce a potent form of cell death in cancer cells has emerged as an alternative anti-cancer strategy offering wide-ranging potential that harnesses the unique intrinsic therapeutic potential of these particles to combat disease without the need for a cytotoxic agent, in addition to activating immune cells within the tumor microenvironment. The proposed studies will identify particle structural and chemical features that can maximize these intrinsic therapeutic responses in melanoma models, in addition to elucidating their underlying molecular mechanisms and relative contributions to anti-cancer therapies – solutions that may better inform our in vivo study designs and offer a more effective path for product translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  This proposal develops a novel delivery platform for the direct delivery of miRNA and siRNA therapeutics to Triple Negative Breast Cancer. RNA nanotechnology’s cancer targeting ability will be applied to exosomes for high payload delivery directly to the cytosol through the control of the orientation of asymmetric nanoparticles for selective surface decoration or exosome loading. Delivery of tumor-suppressing miRNA and siRNA in addition to anti-oncogenic miRNA therapeutics will be tested on patient derived xenograft murine models for tumor treatment and safety profiles.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current sepsis guidelines and national quality measures strongly encourage clinicians to administer immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics and bundled care to all patients with suspected sepsis even though more than a third turn out to have non-infectious diagnoses. A major obstacle for clinicians, hospitals, and policy makers is a limited understanding of which clinical presentations truly require immediate antibiotics and which processes of care are most important to optimizing patients' outcomes. In this project, we will leverage detailed electronic health record data from millions of encounters from two large healthcare networks to 1) develop evidence- based, objective, and electronically computable definitions of sepsis “time zero” that can be used to identify which patients with possible infection require immediate antibiotics, while also facilitating efficient monitoring of sepsis care, 2) systematically evaluate the associations between each sepsis bundle component and mortality and compare the full bundle to simpler, streamlined versions, and 3) assess whether and how optimal treatment strategies differ for commonly encountered and easily recognizable sepsis phenotypes. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Developing Evidence-Based Sepsis Time Zero Criteria and Quality Metrics Using Electronic Health Record Data

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Investigating the neural circuits underlying sensory perception provides a critical window into understanding how the brain functions normally and in disease. Using the sophisticated genetic tools and advanced imaging approaches, this proposal will dissect the mouse brain circuits that impart behavioral valence on odor stimuli. Our work seeks to elucidate fundamental principles in sensory neurobiology that are generally applicable to neuronal processing, with the long-term hope that these principles will provide insight into neurological disorders of sensory systems. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Transposable element sequences occupy fifty times more space in our genome than those coding for proteins, yet we know surprisingly little about the significance of these elements in health, disease, and evolution. This project combines genomics and functional assays to test the transformative idea that transposable elements directly impact fundamental developmental processes in vertebrates. We seek to harness these new insights in the promotion of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A widely conserved hallmark of aging is the decline in muscle mass and strength, which promotes frailty, loss of independence and disability. Based on new evidence we garnered in aging WT mice and mice with muscle- specific inducible PGC1a ablation, we hypothesize that the bioenergetic stimulation induced by intermittent glucocorticoid dosing rescues aging muscle quality through a coordinated action on mitochondrial dysfunction and sarcopenia. We will use our newly generated inducible transgenic models to establish the previously unrecognized roles of mitochondrial regulators PGC1a and Lipin1 in aging physiology through ablation AFTER natural aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Food Allergy is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition, affecting approximately 32 million people in the US, for which there is currently no cure. We developed an innovative berberine nanomedicine called NIT-X that showed excellent preclinical bioavailability, safety and nearly complete suppression of IgE and protection from peanut and tree nut anaphylaxis. NIT-X is not specific for any food and represents a novel food allergy treatment, even for those who suffer from multi-food allergies or have very high risk of reactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE C – PROJECT NARRATIVE This core supports the research Projects with viral, cell- and animal-based experimental tools and models, but also conducts experiments. The infrastructure comprises collections of EBV+ and EBV- nasopharyngeal and gastric carcinoma cell lines, gastric organoid cultures, and cell-derived and patient-derived xenograft models - each reflecting different aspects of EBV-associated cancers.
