IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of my research program is to understand functional roles of noncoding variants in personal genome. Recent advent and development of whole genome sequencing data with paired multi-omics functional assays offer us a great opportunity to identify rare casual variants and individual-specific casual variants. I will develop a novel class of machine learning, statistical and system biology approaches for the identification, prioritization and interpretation of noncoding variants by integrating GWAS, WGS and multi- omics functional assays, which will empower precision medicine by identifying individualized biomarkers for disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this proposal is to optimize and prepare to commercialize a novel, collapsible vaginal pessary and applicator for the non-surgical treatment of pelvic organ prolapse (POP), a condition that symptomatically affects 3.7 million women in the United States. Recent medical studies suggest that surgical treatments for POP are less effective than once believed, and current pessaries in common use are limited by a rigid and fixed design, which can make them uncomfortable as well as difficult or impossible for patients to remove and insert independently. Consequently, there is an imperative to develop non- surgical treatment alternatives for women who suffer with POP which are easy to use, accepted, effective, comfortable, and cause minimal complications.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: We develop innovative causal inference methods grounded in health equity frameworks and apply these to estimate the impacts of Comprehensive Primary Care Plus on the health care of Black Medicare beneficiaries. We study variation in program impacts across subgroups with intersecting identities of gender, disability, and dual eligibility and across provider characteristics and environmental contexts. This proposal advances science and public health by enabling researchers to formulate causal questions, assumptions, and estimation methods appropriate for health equity evaluations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Examining payment and delivery model impacts on health equity using novel quasi-experimental causal inference methods

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE D – PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the EBV Genomics and Bioinformatics Core D will be to provide an EBV-specialized functional genomic methodologies and integrative bioinformatics support to all research Projects within the Program. Core D proposes two Specific Aims: 1) develop and implement functional genomic approaches to study viral and host genomes and epigenomes using diverse Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) approaches; and 2) provide bioinformatic support for each Project through a centralize hub responsible for data management, quality control, analysis, and transfer within the program. The scope of service will include: 1) providing expertise and capabilities in genomic approaches including mRNA expression by RNA-seq, CHIP- and ATAC-seq library preparations, DNA methylation studies by RBBS, and HiC ; 2) ensuring seamless coordination of ‘omics’ efforts across projects as they develop new insights about EBV and performing integrative analyses to combine data from different experiments across the various projects; and 3) assisting with final reports, abstracts, manuscripts, and future funding proposals. Core D’s broad, long-term objective is: to provide leading-edge functional genomics and comprehensive bioinformatics and data management support for the Program members, and proper deposit in public database repositories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite effective antiretroviral therapy, HIV-1 persists in cytotoxic CD4+ T lymphocytes and survives viral cytopathic effects and immune clearance. Using single-cell multi-omics profiling, we will examine how antigen responses and cytokine stimulation promote the persistence of HIV-1-infected, clonally expanding, cytotoxic CD4+ T cells. Our study will identity immune programs that drive HIV-1 persistence and guide HIV-1 eradication strategies.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this study is to examine EHR usability and usefulness in nurses in relationship to patient safety outcomes, at 3 sites using a human factors multi-methods approach. Data will include surveys, observations, interviews, real-time mobile monitoring, and EHR data analytics to relate usability/usefulness concerns to perceived missed nursing care and medication errors. From these data, patient safety analysis will be conducted that aims to reduce EHR burden, missed nursing care and medication errors.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: EHR usability and usefulness, perceived missed nursing care and medication errors in critical care
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We recently showed that a single intravenous dose of an oncolytic Vesicular Stomatitis Virus encoding human interferon beta and the sodium iodide symporter imaging gene (VSV-IFNβ-NIS) is able induce shrinkage of multiple tumors in 5 patients (2 complete responses, 3 partial responses) with aggressive, treatment refractory TCL out of 10 that were treated. In this grant, we are seeking funding to increase this efficacy signal by combining virotherapy with immunotherapy to further improve therapeutic outcome and durability of clinical responses in patients with relapsed refractory TCL, as well as looking for factors that drive response in the patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Uncorrupted gene expression is critical to cell function and human health. Our cells encode a multitude of RNA quality control machineries that detect and degrade defective RNAs that have the potential to interrupt gene expression, some of which have been linked to neurodegenerative disorders. The objective of this proposal is to uncover the mechanisms whereby these pathways detect and degrade defective RNAs in human cells, and the consequences of defects in these pathways to cell function and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Salmonella enterica infections of humans in the industrialized world are typically accompanied by acute gastro- intestinal symptoms; while most patients make full recoveries from such acute infections, a small, but significant, proportion of patients (~5%, or about 100,000 patients annually in the US alone) develop a debilitating chronic inflammatory disease called Reactive Arthritis (ReA). As ReA is currently incurable and has limited treatment options, understanding how Salmonella and other enteric infections result in ReA, and whether the pathways involved in this process are therapeutically targetable, each represent important unanswered questions. Here, we identify ZBP1-driven necroptosis as driver of Salmonella-triggered ReA, outline studies to understand how this pathway contributes to disease, and describe ways in which it can be exploited for therapeutic benefit in ReA.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The DECREASE SSI Trial (Decolonization to Reduce After-Surgery Events of Surgical Site Infection)  The DECREASE SSI Trial (Decolonization to Reduce After-Surgery Events of Surgical Site Infection) is a multi-center pragmatic randomized clinical trial to reduce post-discharge surgical site infection following open colon or small bowel surgery by comparing routine post-discharge wound care to chlorhexidine bathing plus nasal decolonization in the 30 days following discharge. This trial seeks to enhance the care of the 675,000 patients annually who undergo colon and small bowel surgery by finding simple and efficacious interventions to reduce SSI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal metabolism of sugars, fats, and related molecules is a central feature of human aging and plays major roles in age-related conditions like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and dementia. Dr. Mukamal has undertaken broad-based epidemiological research on metabolic determinants of aging, including recent research to understand the health effects of fatty acids that circulate in the blood and affect organs throughout the body. The goals of this K24 award are to enable Dr. Mukamal to expand his knowledge in the measurement of dementia in large clinical studies of metabolism and to train new clinical investigators in research devoted to metabolic aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Projective Narrative Membrane remodeling governs essentially all neuronal functions including synaptic vesicle exocytosis and endocytosis. Defects in these processes lead to neurological disorders, and thus, mechanistic understanding is necessary. In this proposal, we will develop novel approaches in electron microscopy and leverages these tools to understand the millisecond-by-millisecond progress in membrane remodeling during synaptic vesicle cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Brewer The proteins and regulatory networks that choreograph genome replication are conserved across eukaryotes; through our study of genome replication in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, we have discovered that the timing of replication of the rDNA (the repeated locus that codes for the RNA component of ribosomes) is essential for coordinating genome replication with the exit from mitosis. We propose to continue our exploration of the temporal and spatial regulation of replication in yeast by focusing on the rDNA and on the proteins that define and regulate replication origins. This work will expand our basic understanding of the mechanisms regulating chromosome duplication and illuminate questions of importance to human health.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Sexually transmitted infections (STI), including HIV infection, cause substantial morbidity and mortality. To reduce the impact of STI, researchers must be able to work in interdisciplinary teams that bridge basic science, clinical medicine, epidemiology, and social and behavioral sciences. This application proposes to provide training to predoctoral students and postdoctoral fellows, including physicians, to create a corps of researchers with the skills needed to decrease the burden of STI in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medicare coverage expansions for telehealth and increasing demand for telehealth services during the COVID- 19 pandemic have led to a surge in telehealth use in skilled nursing facilities (SNFs), which may impact the quality of post-acute care for Medicare beneficiaries. This project will examine telehealth its patients clinicians, used provision in SNFs and impact on utilization, cost, and quality of care among Medicare beneficiaries in SNFs, with a focus on with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) . Results will provide new evidence to payers and policymakers on the uptake and impacts of telehealth use in SNFs, how telehealth is in SNFs for patients with ADRD, and characteristics of SNFs associated with telehealth use. ,

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposal addresses the trans-NIH Pain Consortium's mission to understand the transition from acute to chronic pain conditions, using a widely accessible study framework- women with menstrual pain. A longitudinal virtual study, using health assessments, symptom questionnaires, and a bladder test will identify which women are at risk for later development of chronic pelvic pain conditions. Those results, combined with data gathered from additional in-person sensory tests, brain activity measures, and inflammation assays, are likely to create a prevention paradigm, centered around identified, modifiable factors for the development of chronic pelvic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid use disorder (OUD) worsens the CNS injury seen in neuroHIV, and although excitotoxicity is a critical component of HIV and/or opiate-driven injury, our evidence suggests that a loss of inhibitory control contributes significantly to this damage since ‘disinhibition’ results in net excitation. We have shown that certain behavioral deficits and structural changes in neurons can be reversed when [Cl−]i balance inside of striatal neurons is stabilized by restoring activity of the K+-Cl− symporter KCC2. The proposed studies explore this theory about the mechanisms underlying synaptodendritic dysfunction/injury in neuroHIV-OUD comorbidity by systematically exploring Cl− regulation using electrophysiological, structural, optical imaging, and behavioral measures in 2 complementary transgenic models and in cultured murine and human cells, with multiple interventional approaches.

PHR: At the end of the support period, our experiments should begin to provide groundbreaking insights into how mouse immune aging can best mimic human immune aging, and how repeated daily stressors influence reactivation of, pathogenesis by and immunity against mCMV and the overall immune function in in old organisms. Information will pave way to specific immune interventions against CMV and immune (and, perhaps, general) aging in older adults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To reach HIV-uninfected pregnant and breastfeeding women in South Africa, who are at very high risk of HIV acquisition, we will test a new and innovative package of interventions: 1) pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), which is both safe and effective for preventing HIV in pregnant and breastfeeding mothers; 2) HIV self-testing for the participant and her partner(s); and 3) enhanced adherence counseling combined with home-based PrEP delivery for women who have difficulties with regular PrEP use. Our study will be among the first ever to evaluate the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of a PrEP intervention among pregnant and postpartum women and will play a key role in informing maternal PrEP interventions to eliminate HIV acquisition and transmission to partners and their infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), including elastography (MRE), is a promising technology for the non- invasive assessment of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), but still cannot reliably distinguish simple steatosis from non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) - the severe form of NAFLD that can lead to fibrosis, cirrhosis, and even death. This project will develop a new suite of rapid and robust free-breathing quantitative MRI techniques in combination with multi-parametric deep learning models to accurately classify simple steatosis versus NASH and measure the degree of fibrosis. The new MRI and deep learning technologies will be validated and tested in patients with NAFLD, ranging from simple steatosis to NASH, to characterize the classification performance and establish a framework that can be used in the future to improve management of patients with NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will determine the expected economic benefit from a prevention delivery and support system for evidence‐based preventive interventions (EBPIs) known as PROSPER (PROmoting School/community‐university Partnerships to Enhance Resilience) that has been shown to increase efficiencies for intervention delivery as well as cultivate sustainable funding streams to support long-term dissemination. Economic impact will be based on administrative data and other markers of well-being measured as participants are followed into adulthood, following up on already demonstrated project effects for reduced substance misuse as well as reduced rates of conduct disorder among adolescents. Importantly, this investigation will assess the expected variation in economic impact due to study implementation factors measured in detail in prior work, enabling further information for how resources may be most efficiently expended for the sake of prevention of long-term problems related to early substance misuse.

PHR: NARRATIVE The planned multi-site randomized trial aims to proof the superiority of personalized precision dosing of mycophenolate mofetil over current standard of care for the treatment of proliferative lupus nephritis in children. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Statistical learning and predictive processing are crucial for auditory perception and speech/language development. This project will identify the neural substrates of auditory statistical learning from the level of individual cells, which are within specific cortical laminae, to the level of brain networks across auditory cortical areas in non-human primates. The results of this proposal will enhance our understanding of the cortical bases of learning in normal populations, which, in tum, will provide insights into neurophysiological deficits underlying various clinical conditions in which statistical learning and predictive processes have been shown to be dysfunctional, such as in autism, ADHD, and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than one million children who are HIV-exposed but uninfected are born to pregnant people with HIV every year and have poorer health outcomes than their HIV-unexposed peers, including a >2-fold increased risk of growth stunting and higher risk of infectious morbidity and mortality. The causes of adverse health outcomes in children who are HIV-exposed are poorly understood but may be related to interactions between the gut microbiome and developing immune system. We will compare gut microbiome development in children with and without HIV exposure and growth stunting, define maternal and child antibody response profiles to enteric organisms, and link gut microbiome profiles to immune changes in growth stunted children using a multi’omics approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative The CROWN study (Comprehensive Research on Oral and mental health among WomeN) proposes to use interdisciplinary research to better understand the underlying mechanisms and interplay of psychosocial, behavioral, and social structural factors contributing to oral health, mental health, and oral health related quality of life in women with HIV. CROWN will leverage retrospective and prospective data collected in STAR (Study of Treatment and Reproductive outcomes) and the MWCCS (MACS/WIHS Combined Cohort Study) in women living with HIV and at risk of HIV in the US. CROWN will evaluate: 1) the effects of mental health on oral health related quality of life; 2) the effects of mental health on oral health clinical outcomes, and 3) the mediational role of oral health clinical outcomes between mental health and oral health related quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will inform how genetic instructions encoded in the genome are remodeled to generate differences in anatomy within populations and between species. It focuses on two focal traits in fruit flies that involve genes deeply conserved across all animal life, including humans. This work will explain how these genes cooperate with the cellular machinery to produce different traits in animals, and will yield general lessons that are pertinent to human development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our cells need to accomplish mechanical tasks such as segregating chromosomes in a timely manner during cell division. Currently, we do not know how the extensive protein networks needed to accomplish these functions regulate their force production, as many different specialized proteins are involved, and we therefore do not understand the link between the breakdown of these networks in diseases such as cancer. My lab will fill this critical knowledge gap by (1) building essential cytoskeletal networks out of purified components (2) applying advanced biophysical and microscopy techniques to directly measure these tiny forces while also watching how the proteins respond under conditions relevant to both healthy and diseased cells.

PHR: Cardiovascular disease such as vascular atherosclerosis kills more people than any other disease worldwide. Recent work has shown that sleep controls inflammatory pathways leading to cardiovascular disease. Inflammatory cells are produced in the bone marrow by a process called hematopoiesis. In this project, we will investigate how sleep controls hematopoiesis in the bone marrow and inflammation in the vessel wall.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Salmonellae are a leading cause of gastroenteritis and systemic disease worldwide, with widespread multi-drug resistance and a high global burden of morbidity and mortality. This proposal uses identification and mechanistic studies of natural human genetic variation regulating Salmonella invasion, replication, and host cytokine production, along with studies of human populations and mouse models, to improve our understanding of how Salmonella interacts with host cells and how this affects risk of typhoid fever and bacteremia. This study will reveal why certain genetic differences predispose individuals to Salmonella infections and may also reveal new targets for host-directed therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Delayed sleep in teens is an intrinsic, biological disruption characterized by being unable to go to sleep early enough and sleeping insufficient amounts; it is pervasive in teens. In addition to daytime fatigue, this loss of sleep is associated with negative behavioral (increased risk taking, depression, agitation, and hyperactivity), cognitive (poor academic performance), medical (increased obesity), and social (increased truancy, increased family tensions, difficulties with socialization) consequences. This project intends to examine a novel therapy for this disruption, one that would require minimal effort and cost to enact and could redefine how this disorder is treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to Public Health  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) disproportionately affects Black/African American older adults who have significantly less slow wave sleep (SWS) duration and higher prevalence of vascular risk factors (VRFs), both of which increase Alzheimer’s disease risk, and are associated with AD biomarkers in cognitive normal subjects. More importantly, identifying possible race-related biologic mechanisms driving AD disparities and asymptomatic blacks at higher risk of cognitive decline from AD is crucial to preventing its onset among blacks. The long-term goal of this K23 is for Dr. Bubu to become an independent investigator who identifies pertinent modifiable and possible race-related biologic mechanisms for AD expression e.g. SWS and VRFs, in order to develop strategies for intervention in the hopes to increase sleep quality, and control vascular risk factors as novel therapeutic targets for Alzheimer’s disease prevention in blacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The processes controlling blood stem cell regeneration remain poorly understood and appear to change over a person’s lifetime as diseases of the blood are associated with abnormal production as blood stem cells age. Blood cancers are treatable through transplantation of young, healthy blood stem cells but the availability of compatible donors and the inability to expand patient-specific blood stem cells in tissue culture makes blood stem therapy limited. The goal of this research will be to broaden our understand the basic requirements needed for blood stem cells and if low calcium conditions impact stem cell function to aid future attempts to improve the sources of blood stem cell to ultimately increase the availability of healthy blood stem cells available to patients with terminal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impediments to accurate DNA replication by DNA damage and other forms of replicative stress leads to genomic instability and underlies a number of heritable diseases including cancer. This proposal focuses on several pathways that ensure continued replication and suppress mutations by mechanisms that are not well understood. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms of the proteins involved will help to understand how cells maintain genomic integrity and may lead to new therapeutic strategies against replication associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), including the β2-adrenoceptor (β2-AR), play critical roles in brain physiology and pathophysiology. We seek to understand how these cascades are regulated at the cellular level. These efforts will provide novel insights into the regulation of neuronal function, and have the potential to enable the development of more efficient therapies for neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Training Program for Antiretroviral Discovery, Evaluation and Application Research (ADEAR) will provide a rich, dynamic, interactive and supportive environment to train outstanding post-graduate scientists in basic, clinical and translational research that will lead to improved treatment and prevention of HIV/AIDS. This will be accomplished through a collaborative effort between the faculty of the University of Colorado, Colorado State University and the University of Denver. ADEAR will be based at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus but will take advantage of the diverse research training opportunities available in the affiliated institutions to train the next generation of laboratory and clinical scientists to conduct the research needed to end the AIDS epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR BONE & MINERAL RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the US, African Americans (or Blacks), American Indians and Alaska Natives, Latinx, Native Hawaiians, and other Pacific Islanders are underrepresented at all career stages in biomedical and behavioral sciences. The American Society of Bone and Mineral Research (ASBMR) is committed to addressing this issue by offering the Excellence in Scientific Training and Professional Development (EXCEL) program, which will deliver state-of- the-art research techniques and high-quality professional development to early-career scientists/clinicians who identify as an underrepresented minority and who have research interests in fields related to the mission of the ASBMR and the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK). In addition, this program will educate the broader membership of ASBMR on topics in diversity, equity, and inclusion to render more accepting and supportive work environments by reducing cultural biases within the workplace.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because tumor cell heterogeneity is at the core of therapy resistance and relapse, which remain major clinical challenges underlying poor outcomes for many cancer patients. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge to reduce illness because it will establish technologies for deep profiling of cancer cell clones that are responsible for disease progression. These technologies will be applicable across cancers and have a far-reaching impact.
